ALS from Harding. Thanking them for a specially bound copy of From Printer to President. 1 p. with original envelope.
Forbes was appointed head of the Veterans' Bureau by Harding. He was later convicted of bribery and corruption.
TLS from Harding. Discussing Harding's nomination and the work that still needs to be done to secure the presidency. 2 pp.
TLS from Harding. Thanking Forbes for a letter and his efforts to secure the support of the Seattle Times, with mention of convincing the Blethens to vote Republican. 1 p.

TLS from Harding. Thanking Forbes for his efforts in support of the campaign, and explaining that he will not make a campaign trip to the West Coast as he does not want to become entangled in local and factional politics. 2 pp.

TLS from Harding. He has received a letter from Anna MacEachern of Seattle, who introduced herself as a radical candidate for Governor, claiming she has information of personal and national importance to Harding; asking Forbes if he will meet with her. 1 p.
TLS from Harding. Thanking Forbes for his friendship and political support, recalling the day they met in Hawaii. 1 p.
TLS from Harding. Telling Forbes that he cannot appoint him a member of the Shipping Board, but suggesting a possible position in Alaska. 2 pp.
TLS from Florence Kling Harding. Marked "Personal." Enclosing a letter from Estella Powers Wagner concerning the case of Private J.E. O'Hara [not included]. 1 p.
TLS from Florence Kling Harding. Marked "Personal." Enclosing correspondence from Raymond F. Long [not included]. 1 p.
TLS from Florence Kling Harding. Thanking him for handling her many requests. 1 p.
TLS from Harding. Encouraging Forbes to publicize the work he is doing as Director of the Bureau of War Risk Insurance. Enclosing a letter from Frank B. Kellogg to the same effect. 1 p. each.
TLS from Florence Kling Harding. Asking Forbes to locate the body of Private Frank Martin Charles at the request of his father, William H. Charles. 1 p.
TLS from Charles G. Dawes to Forbes, referring to his work at the Bureau of War Risk Insurance and cautioning not to publicize too early. 2 pp.
TLS from Florence Kling Harding. Acknowledging a letter and thanking Forbes for his recent assistance at a garden party where he served "co-patriots." 1 p.
TLS from Florence Kling Harding. Thanking him for handling some business concerning two soldiers. 1 p.
TLS from Harding. Asking if there is room in the War Risk Building to house the office of the Comptroller General. 1 p.
TLS from Florence Kling Harding. Thanking him for sending flowers. 1 p.
TLS from Florence Kling Harding. Thanking him for his concern for the President's health, with mention of relaxing weekend trips on the Mayflower. 1 p.
TLS from Harding. Telling Forbes he plans to nominate him as Director of the newly established Veterans' Bureau. 1 p.

TLS from Andrew W. Mellon, Secretary of the Treasury, to Forbes. Thanking Forbes for his service in the Bureau of War Risk Insurance, which had lately been separated from the office of the Treasury, and congratulating him on his new post [Director of the Veteran's Bureau] 1 p.
TLS from Harding. Asking for information concerning hospitals and a "reconstruction camp." 1 p.
TLS from Harding. Agreeing to consider the promotion of Charles R. O'Leary, U.S. Navy, recommended by Forbes. 1 p.
TLS from Harding. Notifying Forbes that he has petitioned the Secretary of the Navy to promote Charles R. O'Leary to Commander. 1 p.
TLS from Harding. Marked "Personal and Confidential." Ordering Forbes to make an unannounced inspection at a New York hospital, as he has received reports of inattention and untidiness there. 1 p.
TLS from Harding. Marked "Personal and Confidential." Telling Forbes to meet with Senator Elkins of West Virginia concerning vocational activities in that state. 1 p.
TLS from Harding. Marked "Confidential." Despite reservations, asking Forbes to grant a Dr. Bland an appointment as sub-district manager for the [Veterans'] Bureau in Ohio. 1 p.
TLS from Harding. Concerning the transfer of Colonel Bury from the Soldier's Home at Dayton to the one at Danville, Illinois. 1 p.

TLS from Harding. Marked "Personal." Enclosing a letter from a citizen of New Hampshire containing business to which Forbes should attend [not included], with mention of recognizing "those who belong to the party in power." 1 p.
TLS from Harding. Thanking Forbes for his budgetary report and commending him on the surplus in the Veterans' Bureau. 1 p.
TLS from Harding. Approving locations for the creation of new hospitals for the care of veterans of the World War. 1 p.
TLS from Harding. Introducing the bearer, Senator Overman, whose brother, H. J. Overman, desires a position in the Veterans' Bureau. 1 p.
TLS from Harding. Agreeing to forward a letter to the Department of Justice concerning the prohibition of alcohol and narcotics at Veterans' Bureau hospitals. 1 p.
TLS from Harding. Alerting Forbes that he has forwarded a letter to the Department of Justice. 1 p.
TLS from Harding. Concerning the Veterans' Bureau's possible purchase of a hospital in Dwight, Illinois. 1 p.
Signed photograph of Harding, with regards to Forbes.
TLS from Harding's secretary, George B. Christian, Jr., sending an autographed photograph of Harding. 1 p. letter with photograph.
ALS from Harding, Marion, Ohio. Agreeing to a speaking engagement in Middletown. 1 p.
TLS from Harding, Washington, D.C. Thanking Hammond for advice and an offer of assistance. 1 p.
Harlan worked for the Treasury Department as auditor for the Navy Department Office.
TLS from Harding, Washington, D.C. Accepting congratulations for a chairmanship and suggesting Harlan appeal to the chairman of the National Republican Committee for a job. 1 p.

TLS from Harding, Washington, D.C. Accepting congratulations for the part he played in the Republican convention in Chicago; expressing hopes that the nominee [Charles Evans Hughes] will win in November. 1 p.
Harrison was a leading member of the Commission of the United States to the Brazilian International Centennial Exposition of 1922.
TLS from Harding. Saying that he has not followed the activities of the Brazilian Exposition Commission. 1 p. with original envelope.
TLS from Harding. Responding to Harrison's letter complaining of Commissioners who are failing to execute their duties, recommending they be fired if that be the case. 2 pp.
TLS from Harding. Asking whether a Mr. Bliss might find an appointment with the Brazilian Exposition. 1 p.
TLS from Harding. Saying that he will accept Harrison's retirement from the Brazilian Commission, but encouraging Harrison to at least visit Brazil for a short period before giving up his post. 1 p.
TLS from Harding. Concerning additional buildings at the Exposition in Rio de Janeiro. 1 p. with original envelope.
TLS from Harding. Approving Harrison's plans to travel to Brazil via steamer and requesting a report of the situation there, with mention of Director General Collier. 1 p. with original envelope.
TLS from Harding. Asking for a meeting to discuss concerns about the situation in Brazil, expressing surprise that Commissioner McGibbons is old and unhelpful. 1 p. with original envelope.
TLS from Harding. Saying that Director General Collier will soon be arriving and will be able to address their problems in person. 1 p. with original envelope.
TLS from Harding. Asking for a personal meeting regarding the Brazilian Exposition Commission. 1 p. with original envelope.
TLS from Harding. Accepting Harrison's resignation effective immediately. 1 p.

TLS from Harding. Washington, D.C. Sympathizing with Hosterman's inability to find a position in the publishing industry yet declining to hire him at his own paper [The Marion Star]; suggesting he contact George B. Lockwood at the National Republican Weekly. 2 pp.
TLS from Harding, Washington, D.C. Asking Hosterman whether he might be interested in employment at the Poultry Division of the Food Administration. 1 p.
TLS from Harding, Washington, D.C. Referring to various job possibilities for Hosterman, including possible service in the Department of Commerce. 1 p.
TLS from Harding, Washington, D.C. Writing to ask whether Hosterman might be interested in a position at the Republican paper at Lima. 1 p.
TLS from Harding, Washington, D.C. Saying there are most likely no jobs to be had with the Republican National Committee at this time. 1 p.
TLS from Harding, Washington, D.C. Agreeing to procure a subscription to the Official Bulletin for Hosterman.
TLS from Harding, Washington, D.C. Thanking him for his support and friendship. 1 p.
TLS from Harding, Washington, D.C. Thanking Hosterman for publishing a notice of Harding's candidacy in his poultry magazine. 1 p.
TLS from Harding, Washington, D.C. Thanking him for a letter, giving suggestions for the promotion of the Advertising Club of Cleveland, and agreeing to send a photograph to Mrs. Knowles. 1 p.
TLS from Harding, Washington, D.C. Declining an invitation to a public dinner in Pittsburgh. 1 p.
TLS from Harding, Washington, D.C. Explaining that he cannot contribute directly to the Farm Journal, but will touch upon relevant issues in his upcoming acceptance speech. 1 p.

ALS from Harding, Washington, D.C. To "my dear Jim." Giving advice to a friend whose wife had expressed pro-German sentiments and thereby earned the ire of many, including Harding's wife [see folder for more]. 3 pp.

ALS from Harding, Washington, D.C. To "my dear Jim." Congratulating Phillips on his reelection to the presidency of Chautauqua; confirming positive reports of Lieut. Pickhart, who was courting Phillips' daughter; warning about the reliability of Coxton. 2 pp. with original envelope [part of address cut out].
TLS from Harding. Thanking them for their sympathy. 1 p.
TLS from Harding, Washington, D.C. Thanking him for his interest in Harding's campaign. 1 p. with original envelope.
TLS from Harding, Washington, D.C. Acknowledging verses and promising to sign a peace resolution if elected. 1 p. With 1921 newspaper clipping reporting the signing of the peace treaty.

TLS from Harding, Washington, D.C. Contributing a few words for an article to be published by the Sulgrave Institution, about the power and duty of English speaking peoples. 2 pp. mounted on cardboard.
TLS from Harding, Washington, D.C. Thanking Stewart for his observations on "the European Situation." 1 p.
TLS from Harding. Gratefully acknowledging Thomas' approval as expressed in a letter. 1 p.
TLS from Harding. Concerning American spending and the high cost of living as it relates to an investigation of the packing industry. 1 p.
Filed chronologically.
ADS. Receipt for rent of a house. On Harding Publishing Company letterhead. 1 p.
Signed photograph of Harding in golfing clothes.
Signed photograph of Harding inscribed "To David Rabkin/ with cordial greetings and very best wishes."
Signed photograph of Harding inscribed "To John Eyrsman/ with personal regards, high esteem, and best wishes."
AMs. "How We Advertise," a speech written for an advertising club. 20 pp.
British colonial governor. LS, New York. To Governor [Stephen] Hopkins. Announcing his arrival in New York and intention to keep up a regular correspondence. 1 p.
Lord Mayor of London in 1767. ALS to Hugh Powell. Expressing anxiety for General [John] Burgoyne and hoping that Sir William Howe is in possession of Philadelphia, with personal news. 2 pp.
American Revolutionary statesman. ALS, Richmond. To Tench Coxe. Asking for help in collecting an overdue bond from James Nourse. 4 pp.
Harrison served as twenty-third President of the United States (1889-1893).
Filed by recipient.
ALS, New York. Refusing a private interview since he promised to speak directly to some newspaper friends. 1 p.
ALS, Indianapolis, Indiana. Thanking Colfax for supporting him for the Senate and saying that he is not a candidate for a cabinet position. 2 pp.
ALS, Indianapolis, Indiana. Thanking Colfax for his support and congratulations. 1 p.
ALS, Des Moines, Iowa. About a proposed speech dealing with the tariff. With a suggestion to speak privately about Indiana affairs. On Republican State Central Committee letterhead. 1 p.
ALS, Washington. To his son. Reporting on political news before the Republican convention, with mention of [James G.] Blaine and [Walter Q.] Gresham. 4 pp.
TLS, Indianapolis, Indiana. Thanking him for sending a hat. 1 p.
DS, on vellum. Appointing William H. Forwood as a surgeon with the rank of Lieutenant Colonel.
Signed photograph of Benjamin Harrison.
Signed photograph of Caroline Scott Harrison.
Served as ninth President of the United States and died after only a month in office (March 4, 1841 â€“ April 4, 1841).
Filed by recipient.
ALS. Asking for a decision about the building of the Hamilton [Ohio] Court House. 1 p.
ALS to the Vice President. Giving an account of the devoted military service of the late Colonel John M. Scott of Kentucky. 2 pp.
ALS, North Bend. Touching on a variety of political matters including nullification and tariffs, with mention of [President Andrew] Jackson, [J.C.] Calhoun, [G.M.] Gibb, and [J.] Tyler. 3 pp.
ALS, Vincennes. Complaining about the difficulty of sending mail in the Northwest Territory, asking whether he might be given franking privileges to cut down on costs. 2 pp.
ALS, Washington. Forwarding a letter sent by [Oliver M.] Spencer, President of the Miami Exporting Company, about an account. 1 p.
ALS, Franklinton. To the paymaster of the district. Giving instructions for how payments should be made through the Pay Office, by order of the Secretary of War. 1 p.
ANS, Greeneville [sic]. Order to issue two gallons of whiskey to the Indians. 1 p.

ALS, Cincinnati. Concerning Todd's request for an appointment, private financial affairs, and Harrison's bid for the Senate, which will likely go unopposed. 2 pp.
DS. For 84 cords of wood issued to the garrison at Fort Washington. 1 p.
DS. For 112 cords of wood issued to the garrison at Fort Washington. 1 p.
DS. Order issuing supplies of powder, musket balls, and buckshot. With signatures of receipt. 1 p.
Vellum diploma of Thomas Selfridge. 1 p.
Served as nineteenth President of the United States (1877-1881).
Filed by recipient.
ALS, Fremont, Ohio. Quoting the first volume of Ohio in the War, which provides details of Hayes' service in the Civil War. 2 pp.
ALS, Columbus, Ohio. Forwarding various reports relating to the Civil War [not included]. 1 p.
ALS, Fremont, Ohio. Speaking of keeping busy with public service since the death of his wife, promising to look for the [W.E] Gladstone speech of 1867. 1 p.
ALS, Columbus, Ohio. Recommending Arnold Isler. 1 p.
ALS, Columbus, Ohio. Notifying Thurman of his election to the United States Senate. 1 p.
ALS, Fremont, Ohio. Sending a copy of a speech by W.T. Sherman, with directions for where to find more information on Sherman and [James B.] McPherson. 1 p.
DS. Signed by Hayes as Lieutenant Colonel. 1 p.
DS, on vellum. Appointing William H. Kell as First Lieutenant in the 22nd Regiment of Infantry. 1 p.
DS. Appointing William H. Kell companion of the first class of the Military Order of the Loyal Legion of the United States. 1 p.
Served as a major general in the Continental Army during the American Revolutionary War.
Filed by recipient.
ALS, Continental Village. To the Governor of New York. Congratulating him on the surrender of Cornwallis, with details of the final engagements. 2 pp.
LS, signed also by Henry Knox, Verplanck's Point. Sending a report of the proceedings between the U.S. (represented by Heath & Knox) and British commissions at Tappan. 2 pp.
DS. Ordering Ebenezer Hancock to pay Major [Coppin de] Lagarde $20 for enlisting a recruit into Colonel Fanueil's regiment. 1 p.
DS. To pay the soldiers of Colonel [David] Henley's foot regiment. With a table denoting how much each officer should receive. 4 pp.
Outlining the provisions due to officers of the army, based on rank. Noted as received from General Heath. 2 pp.
ALS, "Queen Anns County." To Tench Tilghman & Co. Dealing with various business transactions involving the buying and selling of tobacco, blankets, and sugar. 2 pp.
American revolutionary.
Filed by recipient.
ALS, Williamsburg. Concerning the use of state stores to supply Bland's first regiment of dragoons. 1 p.

ALS, Williamsburg. [To the Governor of North Carolina.] Exchanging congratulations on the treaty with France and warning about the encroachment of Carolina settlers onto Cherokee lands, which might lead to trouble and play into the hands of the British. 2 pp.
ALS with ADS enclosed, Red Hill, Charlotte County. About the sale of his land and that of his nephew in Kentucky, enclosing a signed description of one tract. 4 pp. total.
AD. "Estimate of the Inhabitants of the Quotas of each State." 1 p.

Law partner and biographer of Abraham Lincoln. ALS, Springfield, to a Mr. Wilson. Reluctantly refusing a request for Lincoln's autograph, as he gave them all away in the "autographic cyclone" following his assassination. With mention that he believes his biography of Lincoln is true and impartial. 2 pp.
American lawyer. DS, New York. Plea on behalf of his client, Bartholomew Rook, accused of assault & battery on Joseph Emms. 2 pp.
Served as governor of Plymouth County. DS. Warrant ordering the constables of Taunton to appear before a general court assembly. 1 p.
British politician.

"Extracts of letters addressed to the Right Honorable Lord Loughborough" by Sir John Coxe Hippisley, "on the subject of the Spanish colonies in South America, the probability of a successful attack, &c. &c." With a copy of a letter introducing the extracts to the Duke of Leeds. 14 pp.

"Extract of a letter from D[aniel] Corneille, Governor of Helena, to Mr. Hippisley" and "extract of a letter from Mr. Hippisley to the Governor General of Bengal" concerning the Spanish colonies in South America. 4 pp.
U.S. Naval Officer. ANS, Saunders. To a Mr. Whitelaw. Quoting David Farragut's famous line: "Damn the torpedoes! Signal full speed ahead!" 1 p.

Union General during the American Civil War. ALS to Dr. Wells. Complaining about a military charge under [Winfield Scott] Hancock, which had been reported glowingly in the press at the expense of Hooker's own division. 4 pp.

Merchant and legislator. ALS, Boston. To Schuyler Colfax, marked "Private &Confidential." Expressing his belief that the Republicans will stay in power, giving his opinion on who should be appointed to the Committee of Ways and Means, and looking forward to the return of his wife and daughter from Europe . 7 pp.
Served as thirty-first President of the United States (1929â€“1933).
Filed by recipient.
TLS. Responding to an article by Chambers in the Brooklyn Daily Eagle entitled "Hoover Will Fail Unless Housewives Help Him," concerning food conservation. 1 p.
TLS. About an official German acknowledgement of atrocities committed at Dinant [during World War I]; stressing the necessity of not condemning all Germans based on the actions of a few. 1 p.
TLS to "The President." Suggesting that the report of the Naval Oil Reserve Commission be turned over to the Oil Conservation Committee. With a penciled note by Coolidge signed "C." 1 p.
TLS. Looking forward to a meeting with members of the American Agricultural Editors Association at the Department of Commerce. 1 p.
TLS. Remarking on an unnamed gentleman who seems to believe delegates can be cheaply purchased. 1 p.
TLS. Thanking him for a note of friendship. 1 p.
TLS. "I have your letter, and I will do whatever is within my powers." 1 p.
TLS. Refusing an invitation to attend a Farmers Home Coming due to debt negotiations with the Belgians, French, and Italians. 1 p.
TMsS. Mimeograph copy of a speech celebrating Pennsylvania. 1 p.

DS. Unsevered pair of U.S. drafts. [Such drafts were used to pay interest on loans to the U.S. during the Revolutionary War. Forms printed in blue ink were for French loans, in red ink for Dutch loans.] 1 p.
ALS, Georgetown. To Nathanael Greene. Reporting multiple deserters from his corps due to lack of pay and clothing; asking for relief. 1 p.
American diplomat and politician. Letters filed by recipient.
TLS, New York. Suggesting Baruch and Untermyer as possible supporters for an unspecified "democratic cause." 1 p.
TLS with autograph note, London. Planning for a Mr. Paderewski to speak with Mr. Pulitzer. 2 pp.

TLS, Manchester, Mass. Thanking Seitz for a note and promising to share it with Governor [Franklin D.] Roosevelt; stating his intentions to avoid deep involvement in the upcoming Presidential election. 1 p.
TLS, Beverly Farms, Mass. Stating that his advisory role in the presidential campaign keeps him busy; promising to recommend Seitz's services [to the Democratic party]. 1 p.
TLS, New York. Looking forward to Howden's book on Cortes and offering resources for a possible book on [Robert E.] Lee & [Ulysses S.] Grant. 1 p.
TLS, New York. Suggesting Howden write an article for the Saturday Evening Post about an incident with a rum runner, as it is a convincing argument against the 18th Amendment. 1 p.
TLS, Manchester, Mass. Concerning [Franklin D.] Roosevelt's campaign for President, with plans to organize a "Roosevelt Club of authors and artists." 1 p.
TLS, New York. Various expressions of friendship with a commendation for a conversation Smith had with Powell. 1 p.
TLS, New York. Providing information about his father's blockade running during the Civil War. 1 p.
TLS, Beverly Farms, Mass. Saying that it appears the President will "work matters out," and mentioning an article to be published in The American Magazine. 1 p.
TLS, Beverly Farms, Mass. Asking Smith's input on House's estrangement with [Woodrow] Wilson and the President [Franklin D. Roosevelt].
TLS, Beverly Farms, Mass. Commenting on the validity of an article by Ike Hoover [in the Saturday Evening Post] about the estrangement between House and [Woodrow] Wilson. 1 p.
TLS, Beverly Farms, Mass. Stating that if Smith intends to write about House, the resulting work should not be published until House is dead, and he wants no responsibility for its contents. 1 p.
American statesman from New Jersey.
ALS, Princeton. [To John Winthrop.] Giving an account of his journey [from Massachusetts?] to Princeton and reporting various rumors from all over the colonies. 2 pp.
ADS, Princeton. Bill to the State of New Jersey for moving assembly chests and papers from Trenton to Princeton [to avoid the enemy taking possession of them]. 2 pp.
ADS. A petition to the Governor of New Jersey to raise militia for the protection of Bergen County. Signed by Houston as clerk. 1 p.
American soldier and politician. ALS to Colonel Henry Hollingsworth. On the collection of a debt owed to the state by W. Bird. 1 p.
Major general in the Continental Army during the American Revolutionary War.
LS, Tarborough. [To a North Carolina official.] Asking that South Carolina officers be allowed to recruit in North Carolina. 2 pp.
LS, Camp near Zubly's Ferry. Unknown recipient. Describing in detail the American defeat near Savannah. 6 pp.
ALS, Ridgefield. Unknown recipient. Reporting his activities since taking over his present post, and promising to forward information and news. 3 pp.
ALS, Fishkill. To Nathanael Greene. Thanking Greene and his wife for hospitality at Morristown and reporting on the bad situation in his new department. 2 pp.
ALS, West Point. Unknown recipient. Reporting on his being appointed to suppress the mutiny of the Pennsylvania and New Jersey troops with men from New England. 7 pp.
American Naval officer. Letters filed by recipient.
ALS, Boston. Describing his life in Boston, telling Read to keep in touch, and asking for his opinion on a pump for his ship. 4 pp.
LS, Charleston. To the President of the Board of Navy Commissioners. Explaining why he prefers watchmen over Marines as guards for the Navy Yard. 9 pp.
American soldier and politician. DS, Detroit. Ordering a horse to be supplied to John Beale. 1 p.

Hulton was a British official sent to American in 1767 as head of the commissioners to enforce the Stamp Act. Manuscript in several hands, England. Some Account of the Proceedings of the People of New England from the Establishment of a Board of Customs in America to the breaking out of Rebellion in 1775. Divided into 17 chapters, with an index, ending with an account of sufferings of the commissioners of customs. With two contemporary newspaper clippings located in Box 46 (oversize). 397 pp., bound.

Scottish historian and philosopher. ALS, London. Describing in details events in Parliament preceding the repeal of the stamp act; discussing the purchase of some plantations in the Caribbean. Lord Hartford, viceroy of Ireland, was the likely recipient. 4 pp.
ALS, New Windsor. To Colonel Jere Wadsworth. Complaining about the lack of news from Virginia. 3 pp.
A tribute to George Washington, eight stanzas of four lines each. [Dates after Washington's death (1799).] 1 p.
ALS, Coventry. To General [Joseph B.] Varnum. Replying to six theological questions on the nature of Christ. 12 pp.
American Revolutionary leader.
Filed by recipient.
Circular letter, signed. Forwarding Congressional resolves [not included] regarding state quotas needed to build up the Continental treasury. 2 pp.
ALS, Norwich. Acknowledging the receipt of various acts of Congress, as well as a resolution thanking France for their tribute to the memory of Benjamin Franklin. 1 p.

Circular letter, signed. Explaining the necessity of promptly raising money from the state of Pennsylvania [Reed was "President" of the state], with mention of French expeditionary forces coming to America. 3 pp.
ALS (draft), initials. Norwich. On the borrowing powers of the government, the ratio between senators and representatives, and the defeat of General [Arthur] St. Clair in Ohio. 2 pp.
DS, printed form. For the sloop Hartford, captain Ebenezer Barnerd. Signed by Huntington as "Gov. & Superintendent of Marine" and Comfort Sage, Naval Officer. 1 p.
Served as Governor of Massachusetts. A copy of the will of Mary Fisher, approved by Hutchinson while Judge of Probate. 2 pp.
"Lord Cornbury," served as Governor of New York and New Jersey. DS, Kingstowne. Commission of Johannis Schepmoes as lieutenant of militia. 1 p.
ADS. "Free speech is the brain, honest votes the breath, good money the blood and nationality--the very heart of this republic." 1 p.
ALS, Paris. To Arthur Lee. Stressing the need for convoys to protect merchants ships traveling to and from America; asking a favor for a Mr. Blake of South Carolina. 2 pp.
Served as seventh President of the United States (1829â€“1837).
Filed by recipient.
ALS, Hermitage. Referring to the correspondence between various diplomats on the establishment of the boundary of Texas. 1 p.
ALS, Captain Craig's [Tennessee]. Thanking Campbell for an "act of disinterested friendship." 1 p.
ALS, Hermitage. Concerning a business contract which he is entering with Campbell, with mention of Colonel [Aaron] Burr's arrival in a postscript. 2 pp.
ALS, Hermitage. Urging action to be taken against Silas Dinsmore, agent to the Choctaws. Enclosing a copy of The Democratic Clarion & Tennessee Gazette from 26 September 1812 [included]. 3 pp.
ALS, Hermitage. Concerning the movement of the Creeks and their possible alliance with the Spaniards, with instructions for Coffee and an outline of his own plans. 4 pp.

ALS, Hermitage. Asking Coll to recollect the circumstances surrounding a $1000 fine imposed on Jackson in 1815 when he declared martial law in New Orleans. In 1842 there was a motion to restore the fine with interest. 3 pp. with a January 1843 printed report explaining the history of the case. 53 pp. bound.
LS, New Orleans. To the Secretary of War, facilitating the transfer of some soldiers to new regiments. 1 p.
ALS, Hermitage. Ordering copies of the Republican to be sent to various friends. 1 p.
ALS, Washington. Acknowledging the receipt of an original report signed by a Mr. McEldry. 1 p.

LS, Nashville. To the Acting Secretary of War. Forwarding Lieutenant Wendell's application for transfer [not included] and remarking on the injustice of appointing citizens and cadets to higher posts than artillery officers. 1 p.

ALS, Philadelphia. Discussing legislative meetings; the impending presidential election; the relationship between Great Britain, France, and the United States; and sending regards to family and friends. 3 pp.

ALS, Washington. To his daughter-in-law. About his frustration with Congress and issues of political demagogy and nullification. With a November 25, 1831 statement of marriage between Sarah and Andrew Jackson Jr., signed by Pastor Albert Barnes. 4 pp. total.

ALS marked "Private." Defending his actions in removing Secretary of the Treasury [William J. Duane] upon his refusal to remove deposits from the Bank of the U.S.; citing historical precedents set by former presidents Washington, Adams, and Madison. 5 pp.
ALS, Hermitage. Insisting Lewis forward Jackson's carriage and baggage immediately as he must leave the next day for Fort Jackson, with directions for purchasing and distributing weapons. 1 p.
ALS, Washington. A lengthy justification of his stance on secession and nullification, with an analysis of [Thomas] Jefferson and many general remarks on law and government. 7 pp.
ALS, Fort Strother. Asking for additional volunteers to help end the Creek War; giving his immediate plans to join with General Cocke. 2 pp.
ALS, Hermitage. Giving an account of the commendable service of General W.O. Butler during the War of 1812. [McAfee was nominating Butler for Governor of Kentucky.] 2 pp.
ALS, Major Goodson's. Addressing some business dealing with horses and offering advice and concern over the publication of Reed's book on the late war. 2 pp.
ALS, Mrs. McCarty's plantation. Repeating the instructions he gave to Captain Humphries about the disposition of ammunition for the troops. 2 pp.
LS, Madison County. Thanking the General Assembly of Alabama for honoring him. 1 p.
ALS, Montpelier. Agreeing to employ Rutledge's son, and explaining that they do not have a permanent residence yet and are therefore rooming with military officers. 2 pp.
ALS, Nashville. Sending news of the surrender and impending trial of Aaron Burr (accused of treason), and attacking General [James] Wilkinson, who is expected to be called as a witness. 3 pp.

ALS. Chiding Snodgrass for prioritizing the wrong tasks; insisting he abandon efforts to finish a fort and instead immediately focus on building boats and bringing foodstuffs and cattle to the troops on the front lines. 1 p.
LS, Hermitage. To the Superintendent of West Point. Introducing and recommending the bearer, a Mr. Bradford of Lexington, Kentucky. 1 p.
ALS, Washington. Arranging for payment of various bills for his son and daughter and for freight shipments. 1 p.
ALS. Sending news to an unnamed government official that the British are to take over Pensacola under a secret treaty with Spain. 1 p.
LS (body in the hand of nephew Andrew Jackson Donaldson). "Camp 4 Miles below Orleans." Reporting on the January 8 victory at New Orleans, giving losses on both sides. 3 pp.
DS. Provision return for the regiment of Tennessee Volunteer Cavalry under command of Colonel John Coffee. Signed by Jackson as Major General. 1 p.
DS. Ordering payment to James Tatum for services, forage, and subsistence. 1 p.
DS, on vellum. For the Dartmouth, commander Thomas Brock. 1 p.
DS. Ordering the Secretary of State to affix the Seal of the United States to an exequatur granted to Armand de la Rue de Villeret. 1 p.
DS, on vellum. Appointing Benjamin Roberts as Second Lieutenant in the 1st Regiment of Dragoons. Signed also by Lewis Cass, Secretary of War. 1 p.

Served as Senator and Governor of Georgia. ALS to General [Anthony] Wayne. Enclosing an extract of a letter reporting the impending evacuation of Savannah by the British, with his plans in response to the news. 2 pp. with attached extract.

Confederate general "Stonewall" Jackson. ALS, Woodstock. To General J[oseph] E. Johnston. Reporting his and the enemy's movements in the Shenandoah Valley, the capture of supplies, and his readiness to support Johnston. On the back is a June 8 note from Robert E. Lee, submitting the letter to Confederate President [Jefferson Davis]. 2 pp.
American politician. Letters filed by recipient.
ALS, Philadelphia. Reporting a rumor of British men of war at the Capes, the success of American privateers, and Lord Dunmore's leaving Virginia. 1 p.

ALS, New York. To the Marquis of Landsdowne. Remarking on new principles of trade & finance, hoping for conciliation between their countries, and defending the security of persons and property in the United States. 2 pp.

Thomas Jefferson was an extremely influential American statesman who served as the first U.S. secretary of state (1789-1793), the second vice president (1797-1801, under John Adams), and the third president (1801â€“1809). This series largely consists of letters written by Jefferson, the contents of which provide a veritable who's who of American Revolutionary leaders. Topics range from subjects of personal interest (e.g. what materials should be used to decorate Monticello, his Virginia estate) to matters of national and international importance. Not one to mince words, Jefferson strongly states his opinions on political rivalries, government policies, and international relations, often touching on multiple issues within single letters. The letters also provide a glimpse of his scientific and inventive pursuits including a diagram for an improved water wheel and his establishment of a nail manufactory (see letters to Zane and Remsen respectively).

The correspondence is arranged alphabetically by name of correspondent. The Papers of Thomas Jefferson (Princeton: Princeton University Press, 1950-2007), an extensive project to publish all of Jefferson's writings, is currently underway at Princeton University. At the time of this writing, 34 volumes have been published covering Jefferson's life up to July 1801; these volumes were consulted during the preparation of this finding aid. Letters in this collection that are published contain a bracketed notation citing volume and page numbers. RC indicates the item is the original recipient's copy. A separately numbered retirement series ( The Papers of Thomas Jefferson: Retirement Series) was also consulted. At the time of this writing, four volumes have been published. Letters published in this series contain an additional Retirement Series notation. Miscellaneous documents written by or about Jefferson are included at the end of the collection.
Patrons will be given access to surrogate, photoduplicated copies of the Jefferson materials.
Filed alphabetically by correspondent.

ALS, Washington. On the recent work of Congress, the strength of republicanism over federalism, suggesting Barlow move to Washington, D.C. and write a history of the U.S., mentioning John Marshall's forthcoming book on the life of [George] Washington, with a postscript about the house and land of Gustavus Scott, who has gone bankrupt and is selling his property. 2 pp.
LS, to the inhabitants of the town of Beverly. Explaining the background of the embargo acts and the necessity of keeping them in place. 3 pp.
ALS, Monticello. Thanking Botta for a promised work on the American Revolution, remarking on the age of revolutions it ushered in. 1 p. [Retirement Series, Vol. 2: 529-530]

ALS (RC), New York. Complaining about the detention of ships' registers at Hispaniola using Captain Brown and the sloop Polly at Port-au-Prince as an example; hoping French authorities will issue an order against the practice. 1 p. [Vol. 17: 417]

LS, Philadelphia. Noting how busy he is as Secretary of State; mentioning Congress' failure to pass an act regulating the function of Consuls; attributing the prosperity of the nation to good government, agriculture, and manufacturing; hoping for peace with the Indians; and warning Bourne not to meddle with internal disputes between France and her colony [Haiti]. 4 pp. [Portions of this letter were copied and sent as a circular to other U.S. Consuls. See Vol. 20: 401-404 for more.]

ALS (RC), Monticello. Thanking him for a pamphlet on manufactures, commenting on how the U.S. should handle its own agriculture and manufactures in light of market rivalries from South America and Europe; updating Briggs on the status of a request for compensation. 1 p.

These two letters to Callender became part of a Federalist campaign against Jefferson, in which he was accused of paying Callender to write The Prospect Before Us, a work critical of George Washington and John Adams. Multiple copies of the letters were made and put on display as evidence for both sides. Augustine Davis, who is noted as having received the letters from Callender, was an editor at a Federalist newspaper in Richmond. For more, see Volume 31: 180-182.

Letter (copy), Monticello. Mentioning troubles with the post office, subscribing to Callender's next book, and saying that violence and rebellion are rare in Virginia and will not be tolerated. With brief mention of [Jonathan] Robbins being delivered to the British. The letter is noted as being "given by Mr. Callender to A. Davis." 1 p. [Vol. 31: 179-182]

Letter (copy), Monticello. Referring to previous letters concerning the Comte de Vergennes and the high cost of a treaty with Algiers; explaining how each state chooses electors; saying he will soon stop signing and writing letters for fear his words will be perverted in the eyes of the public. The letter is noted as being "given by Mr. Callender to Aug. Davis." 2 pp. [Vol. 31: 200-202]

ALS (RC), Monticello. Commenting on the recent truce which he will not call "peace" until American seamen are no longer impressed; discussing the effects of Napoleon's downfall; expressing his hope that Congress will now focus on creating stable military and financial systems. 2 pp. with a draft of a September 9, 1815 letter from Campbell to Jefferson. 3 pp.
Letter (copy), Washington. To the King of Spain. Saying that David Humphreys, U.S. minister to Spain, is retiring. Assuring continued friendship and peace between the two nations. 1 p.

did.unittitle: Chaumont, Jacques Donatien Le Ray de

scopecontent.p: ALS (RC), Monticello. Remarks on the growth of local agricultural societies, with hope they will someday expand to the state and national level. 1 p.

Letter (copy). To the Senate & House of Representatives. Forwarding three letters [not included]: 1) from the U.S. minister at London regarding a treaty; 2) from the U.S minister at Paris, concerning the effects of a recent imperial decree; 3) from Cowles Mead, acting governor of the Mississippi Territory, saying that Aaron Burr has surrendered. 1 p.
ALS (RC). Written in third person. Returning a book, dealing with port charges at Port-au-Prince, and asking about the kind of money used in the French West Indies. 1 p. [Vol. 22: 414]

ALS (RC), Monticello. Discussing their failed attempt to found a newspaper; describing the results of the Virginia congressional elections with harsh words against [Patrick] Henry. 2 pp. [Vol. 31: 112-114]
ALS, Monticello. Recommending William Henry Kennon for midshipman. 1 p.
ALS. Citing the reasons why it is illegal for the Governor of East Florida to enlist soldiers for an expedition against the Creek Indians. 1 p.
ALS, Washington. Concerning decorative choices for his home with mention of composition ornament, woods for his parlor, and drawings for a fireplace. 1 p.
ALS (RC), Monticello. Ordering wine, olive oil, macaroni, and anchovies. 1 p.

ALS (RC), New York. Concerning his efforts to straighten out a situation involving the Secretary of the Treasury [Alexander Hamilton] and an abusive letter to Donald; mentioning the possibility of war in Northern Europe. 1 p. [Vol. 16: 325]

ALS (RC), Monticello. Concerning the publication of Destutt de Tracy's Elemens d'Ideologie and the recent failures of the British (in the War of 1812), mentioning the Battle of New Orleans and the Hartford Convention. 1 p.
ALS (RC), Monticello. Asking Dufief to undertake the payment of some of his bills in Philadelphia; ordering books. 1 p.

ALS, Washington. To his daughter, "Maria." Reporting on the status of a measles outbreak at Monticello, promising that by the time she arrives any infected persons will have been removed; giving directions for her health and travel; mentioning that Tory newspapers are attacking her husband's publication. 1 p.
ALS (RC) to the U.S. Minister at Madrid. Introducing and recommending the bearer, Mr. George Ticknor, a young American gentleman traveling through Europe. 1 p.
ALS (RC), Monticello. Thanking the professor for a copy of a work on algebra, commenting on different mathematical methods. 1 p.
ALS, written in third person. Apologizing for a delayed invitation to dine, explaining that Fenner's name was somehow lost among the list of gentlemen who called on Jefferson. 1 p.

ALS, Monticello. Responding to a pamphlet written by Fishback, offering his belief that society should be ruled by the moral precepts on which all religions agree and not disturbed by the points on which they disagree. 2 pp. [Retirement Series, Vol. 1: 565-566]

ALS (RC), Paris. Discussing his opinion of the new constitution and his esteem for the framers, but expressing concern that they have planted "seeds of danger" by presuming succeeding rulers will be as honest as themselves. 1 p. [An enclosure originally accompanied this letter, a copy of which is now housed in the Library of Congress. Vol. 12: 475-79]
ALS, Washington. Concerning various kinds of business and upkeep at Monticello, mentioning nail rods, nurses, and tenants. 1 p.

ALS, Monticello. Citing suspicious accounting as the reason Gerry's brother was removed from office; explaining how certain officers from the previous administration were also removed in order to make room for republican appointees. 2 pp.
Harrison was a Virginia delegate to the Continental Congress and Governor of Virginia from 1781 to 1784.

ALS (RC), In Council. Reporting the arrival of a British fleet in [Chesapeake] Bay, suspected to be hostile; asking for advice from the General Assembly. Docketing on the back notes that the letter was laid on the table by the Assembly. 1 p. [Vol. 4: 289-290]

ALS (RC), Annapolis. Sending news of Congress and the topics it will address including treaties of commerce, Indian affairs, and western posts. Answering a question about loan office debt. Discussing how many states have yet to adopt the impost. 2 pp. [Vol. 7: 225-6]
ALS (RC), in third person. Forwarding tuition fees of Benjamin and Lewis Randolph [sons of his daughter, Martha]. 1 p.

ALS (RC), Boston. Transmitting his decision to postpone a trip to France as the only ships currently available would expose him to an undesirable "crowd of passengers," mentioning that Mrs. [John] Adams and her daughter recently left on a crowded ship, and saying that the next time he sees Humphreys he will deliver a packet of papers from General Washington. 1 p. [Vol. 7: 311-12]

ALS (RC), Boston. 8 o'clock P.M. Hastily notifying Humphreys that Mr. Tracy, whose ship is bound for London, has agreed to stop at France; urging Humphreys to immediately come to Boston as the ship leaves in a matter of days. 1 p. [Vol. 7: 321]

ALS (RC), Boston. 6 o'clock P.M. Regretting that Humphreys was unable to join him for the passage to Paris, suggesting alternate travel plans, requesting that Humphreys board with him once he reaches Paris. With mention of Dr. [Benjamin] Franklin at Passy. 1 p. [Vol. 7: 363-4

ALS, London (RC). Responding to Humphreys' resignation as secretary to the commissions, commending and thanking him for his service, asking him to write with news from America and deliver a letter to [John] Jay. 1 p. [Vol. 9: 328]

ALS (RC), Paris. Mentioning some business he has undertaken following Humphrey's resignation, discussing the terms of commercial treaties with Portugal and Prussia, the hostility of England towards the U.S., and the anticipated death of the King of Prussia. 2 pp. [Vol. 9: 469]

ALS (RC), Paris. On the poor state of the public treasury; Algerian, Moroccan, and European affairs; his work with the Marquis de Lafayette to secure a commercial treaty; and painter [John] Trumbull's visit to Europe. 2 pp. [Vol. 10: 250-252]

ALS (RC), New York. Giving detailed orders for Humphreys to travel to London, Lisbon, and Madrid to deliver letters & papers and meet with specific individuals, with a warning that he should do his best to appear as a private traveler. 2 pp. [Vol. 17: 125-7]

ALS (RC), Philadelphia. Informing Humphreys that he has been appointed Resident Minister at the court of Lisbon, giving the title of a book, enclosing an act meant to reduce England's power at sea [not included], and providing directions for various communications and financial transactions. 3 pp. [Vol. 19: 572-4]

ALS (RC), Philadelphia. Partly in cipher with interlinear deciphering. Complaining about Mr. Carmichael's failure to keep the U.S. government apprised of his actions and intelligence; directing Humphreys and [William] Short to carefully procure information on Brazil without provoking suspicion from the Court of Lisbon; sending various papers [not included]. 2 pp. [Vol. 20: 209-210]
ALS (RC), Philadelphia. Marked "Private." Ordering a book of letters by Cortez and a history of Christopher Columbus; discussing samples of wine shipped from Lisbon. 1 p. [Vol. 20: 210-211]
LS (RC), Philadelphia. Introducing the bearer, John Wilcocks, Jr. 1 p.

LS (RC), Philadelphia. Announcing that Thomas Barclay has been appointed U.S. Consul at Morocco, giving instructions to Humphreys concerning Barclay's salary and governmental funds at his disposal. Included is a copy of a letter to bankers Willink, Van Staphorts, & Hubbard, and the official instructions sent to Thomas Barclay. [Vol. 20: 397-400, 406-7]

LS (RC), Philadelphia. Concerning the provisioning and ransoming of a group of captives at Algiers, with their names; briefly mentioning the war with the Indians, the National Bank, and the President. 4 pp. [Vol. 20: 624-5]
ALS (RC), Philadelphia. At the request of Robert Morris, inquiring whether William Duncan is being held captive at Algiers. [He was not, see Vol. 20: 677-8 for more.]

ALS (RC), Philadelphia. Briefly touching on many topics including war against the Indians, the Negro insurrection at St. Domingo, the soon-to-be-published census, legislative action, and domestic manufactures; with directions regarding Humphreys' post as diplomat. 2 pp. [Vol. 22: 353-4]
LS (RC), Philadelphia. Instructing Humphreys to investigate and pay Don Joseph Torino a sum of money for the Count de Espilles, who put out money for American captives at Algiers. 1 p. [Vol. 22: 400]

ALS (RC), Philadelphia. Briefly reporting on many topics including war with the Indians, General St. Clair's resignation, failures of stock jobbers, a Congressional bill concerning state representation, the insurrection at Haiti, and negotiations at Madrid. 2 pp. [Vol. 23: 386-7]

ALS (RC), Philadelphia. Saying that he is traveling to Virginia (following the President), reporting that Vermont is attempting to extend its boundary nearer to British posts, hoping for peace with the Indians. 1 p. [Vol. 24: 221]

ALS (RC), Philadelphia. On dealings with the Indians and the condition of agriculture; with a lengthy postscript complaining about Portugal's possible prohibition of American wheat and corn products, questioning how Portugal would respond if America decided to ban their wines. 2 pp. with separate half page postscript saying that the letter will be sent directly to Lisbon and not through London. [Vol. 24: 587-8]
ALS (RC), Philadelphia. Marked "Private." Notifying Humphreys of his intention to resign as Secretary of State, sending news of peace with the Wabash and Illinois Indians. 1 p. [Vol. 24: 595-6]

ALS (RC), Philadelphia. Sending papers and plans for the city of Washington, D.C. [not included], reporting the result of elections and an upcoming treaty meeting with the Western Indians, and inquiring about the grain market. 2 pp. [Vol. 25: 8-9]

LS (RC), Philadelphia. Giving directions for Humphreys to travel to Gibraltar to deal with Moroccan affairs and handle diplomatic business in the wake of the deaths of [John] Paul Jones and Mr. Barclay; appointing Nathaniel Cutting as Humphreys' secretary. 3 pp. [Vol. 25: 420-422]

ALS (RC), Philadelphia. Strongly urging Humphreys to negotiate with Portugal to accept U.S. flour; insisting on the preservation of neutrality should a general war break out in Europe, asking for new from various nations, and sending some confidential papers and letters to be forwarded [not included]. 2 pp. [Vol. 25: 426-7]

ALS (RC), Philadelphia. Marked "Private." Saying his resignation has been slightly delayed but will occur within the year; giving a lengthy explanation of his efforts to get Captain O'Brian out of Algerian captivity; and expressing frustration that [William] Carmichael, diplomat to Spain, has sent but one letter in three years. 3 pp. [Vol. 25: 427-9]

ALS (RC), Philadelphia. Writing a shorter version of his March 21, 1793 letter to Humphreys (giving directions for completing business in Algiers) as a vessel is sailing directly to Lisbon and can carry the letter. 1 p. [Vol. 25: 468-9]

ALS (RC), Philadelphia. Asking Humphreys to delay drawing on the full amount of a bill so as not to entirely deplete the funds for foreign legations; saying that [Nathaniel] Cutting has been delayed due to the outbreak of war between France, Great Britain, and Holland. 1 p. [Vol. 25: 532]

LS (RC), Philadelphia. Announcing the President's proclamation of neutrality, discussing how Humphreys should proceed should Portugal become involved in the war, and forwarding a copy of the letter of neutrality sent to various foreign ministers [included] 1 p. and 2 pp. respectively. [Vol. 25: 587-8]
ALS (RC), Philadelphia. Describing the Yellow Fever epidemic and continued disagreements with the Indians. 1 p. [Vol. 27: 90]

ALS (RC), Philadelphia. Announcing his resignation as Secretary of State and the appointment of [Edmund] Randolph in his place. [Copies of this letter were sent to various U.S. diplomats]. 1 p. [Vol. 28: 4-5]
LS (RC), Philadelphia. Forwarding various acts [not included]. 1 p.
ALS (RC), in third person, Monticello. Thanking him for a copy of the vindications of the proceedings in the Seminole War. 1 p.

ALS (RC), Monticello. Commending Lambert on his scientific endeavors including fixing a meridian for the country and a projected publication. With harsh words for the British Constitution, declaring it "the most corrupted & corrupting mass of rottenness which ever usurped the name of government." 2 pp. [Retirement Series, Vol. 1: 511-512]

Letter (copy), Philadelphia. Sending a copy of the declaration of independence, mentioning his plans to travel to Virginia and his wish for a successor. 1 p. [Vol. 1: 455-6; an accompanying copy of the declaration can be found in the Documents folder]

ALS with subscription and postscript in Jefferson's hand (RC), Richmond. Planning a line of express riders to relay timely and confidential information between northern and southern posts; with mention of the expected arrival of the French fleet. 2 pp. [Vol. 3: 444-445]
ALS, Washington. Written in third person. Thanking Legaux for a bundle of grape vine plants to be sent to Monticello. 1 p.
ALS (RC), Washington. Concerning the expenses of Mansfield's trip to Washington and a monetary advance for his surveying instruments, arranged by [Albert] Gallatin. 1 p.
ALS (RC), Monticello. About the importation of two cases of wine, with directions for future imports of books & wines from Europe. 1 p.
ALS (RC), Albemarle. Asking Mercer to verify the amount of a debt and send any news of the British army and French intervention. 1 p. with docketing and a note by Mercer on back. [Vol. 2: 199]

ALS (RC). Clarifying confusion over a group of French sailors in the jail at Philadelphia; saying they are technically in the custody of the Judiciary authority and therefore the Executive will not interfere. 1 p. [Vol. 27: 605]
ALS, Washington. Forwarding a letter of Thomas Paine [not included], asking Minor to inquire whether the Virginia legislature might help him. 1 p.
ALS (RC), Poplar Forest. Asking Monroe to forward a letter of condolence to the daughter of his late dentist, Dr. Thomas Bruff. 1 p.
ALS (RC). To the President. Breaking his rule of not asking government officers for favors as a Mr. Patrick Gibson of Richmond greatly needs help. 1 p.

Letter (copy), Philadelphia. A lengthy letter outlining the inappropriate behavior of Edmond Charles Genet, French minister to the United States, who repeatedly refused to respect U.S. neutrality. 43 pp. [Vol. 26: 697-715]
ALS (RC), Washington. About final payment to sculptor [Jean Antoine] Houdon for a statue of [George] Washington. 1 p.
ALS, written in third person. Ordering four barrels of cider, arranging for shipment and safe payment. 1 p.

ALS, Washington. Saying it is up to the Senate to accept the treaty [with Napoleon], giving an update on Rufus King's work in London, complaining about incidents at the Spanish port of Algeciras, with mention of Louisiana and the census. 1 p.
ALS (RC), Washington. About the Burr conspiracy, mentioning [James] Wilkinson, [John] Adair, Ogden, and [Henry] Dearborn. 1 p.

ALS, Paris. Sending the letter through Colonel Le Maire with news of European politics, a report on animal magnetism [not included], and some phosphoric matches; asking for news from the assembly. 2 pp. [Vol. 7: 514-5]

ALS (RC), Washington. Asking for the contents of the letter to remain secret. Saying the U.S. mint will likely be suppressed by Congress, reporting that too many of the general government offices are filled by Virginians, and asking whether Page might be interested in taking the collectorship at Petersburg as Colonel Heath must be removed from the post due to his temper and "the fury of his federalism," discussing the duties and salary of the position. 2 pp.
ALS (RC), Monticello. Expressing joy over the passage of the university bill, discussing the qualifications of a professor, giving family news, and awaiting the arrival of Italian stonecutters. 1 p.

ALS. Suggesting a course of study for his grandson while in Philadelphia including Peale's museum, [William] Hamilton's garden, and surgical operations; agreeing to exchange polygraphs in the hopes that Peale can fix his. 1 p.
ALS, Monticello. About the registration of a deed for a mill in Kentucky. 1 p.
U.S. Minister at London.
ALS (RC), Philadelphia. Forwarding a letter addressed to the Governor of Pennsylvania, with instructions on patronage. 1 p. [Vol. 24: 646]

ALS (RC), Philadelphia. Marked "Private." On the result of Congressional elections and the rise of republicanism, saying that he expects Adams to be elected Vice President despite opposition. 2 pp. with detached address sheet. [Vol. 24: 696-7]

LS, Philadelphia. To Pinckney and [Gouverneur] Morris. Giving directions for U.S. ministers to encourage and aid in the liberation of the Marquis de Lafayette. A postscript in Jefferson's hand notes that [David] Humphreys was also sent a copy. 1 p. [Vol. 25: 387-9]

ALS, Monticello. Concerning Plumer's intention to write a history of the United States; offering any information in his possession with the warning that he has no papers or records beyond his correspondence and his own memories. Commenting on the rise of Federalism in 1808. 1 p. [Retirement Series, Vol. 2: 505-506]

ALS (RC), Paris. Reviewing European affairs and the prospects of war between various nations, characterizing England as "totally absorbed in self interest," discussing the treaties he is negotiating and the U.S. debts to France and Holland. 2 pp. with docketing by Read on the back. [Vol. 7: 515-6]
ALS (RC), Monticello. Thanking Remsen for sending gongs and a threshing machine, discussing his own establishment of a nail manufactory. 1 p. [Vol. 28: 304-5]

ALS, Monticello. Asking Roane to provide his legal opinion of a financial situation that Jefferson fears may bankrupt him. 2 pp. Manuscripts explaining the details of the case are included: a draft and a polygraph copy of AMs labeled "The case of the exrs of W.C. Nicholas with Morrison, and of the same with Owings," 4 pp. each, and a draft and polygraph copy of AM entitled "Abstracts from sundry Documents in the case of the Exrs of W.C. Nicholas with Morrison and of the same with Owings," 4 pp. each. [The Nicholas in question is Wilson Cary Nicholas.]
ALS, written in third person. Concerning the expected effects of the U.S embargo on European nations. 1 p.
ALS (RC), Monticello. Describing his continued frustration with the attitude and actions of England; remarking on embargo laws and the homespun movement; urging a visit. 3 pp.

LS (RC), New York. Partly in cipher with interlinear deciphering. Concerning certain specifics of the treaty with France, describing a Mr. Campbell who presented himself and claimed to be a minister from Denmark but had no authenticating papers, and writing in code about the payment of the debt to France. 7 pp. [Vol. 17: 431-5]
ALS (RC), Monticello. Asking for information about the abilities of a Mr. Runnels, an applicant for a consular appointment. 1 p.

ALS (RC), Monticello. Pleased to hear the principles of navigation he submitted in 1793 are finally being considered; discussing the future and hopeful prospects of Richmond; commenting on his old age and the youth who now take over the country. 1 p.
ALS (RC), Monticello. Thanking him for material related to the establishment of primary schools in Maryland, discussing the educational system in Virginia. 1 p.
LS, Philadelphia. To Messrs Ternant, [F.P.] Van Berkel, and [George] Hammond [foreign ministers]. Forwarding a copy of the President's proclamation of neutrality [not included]. 1 p. [Vol. 25: 583-4]

AL, written in third person. Forwarding secret state papers for revision and approval, and questioning whether it might be "safe and useful" to share certain papers with [William] Short and the Marquis de Lafayette. 1 p. [Vol. 17: 120-1]
ALS (RC), Monticello. Discussing the advisability of reprinting Baxter's History of England a new digest of Coke Littleton printed by Thomas. 1 p.
Bankers at Amsterdam.
LC, Philadelphia. Asking them to honor any bills of David Humphreys relating to the maintenance of captives in Algiers. 1 p. [Vol. 20: 626-7]
ALS, Philadelphia. Concerning drafts for [Thomas] Pinckney, Nathaniel Cutting, and David Humphreys. 1 p. [Vol. 25: 413-4]
Zane conducted the Marlboro Iron Works in Frederick County, Virginia.

ALS (RC), Monticello. Planning for the payment and pick-up of iron pans (used to obtain salt from seawater), mentioning the relative success of the draft, and asking whether Zane might part with his spirit level. 1 p. [Vol. 2: 174-5]

ALS (RC), Philadelphia. Sending a thermometer with directions for recording the temperature of a cave; giving news of the treaty and recent Congressional business; and providing a diagram and suggestions for an improved water wheel. 2 pp. Housed with a group of printed pages relating to meteorological observations and the 1793 outbreak of yellow fever in Philadelphia, with handwritten annotations (not by Jefferson). 16 pp. [Jefferson letter published in Vol. 6: 347-9]
LS (RC), Williamsburg. On the historic office of Justice of the Peace in Great Britain and America, with remarks on ways of vacating the office. 2 pp. [Vol. 3: 242-3]

Ms, A Declaration by the Representatives of the United States of America, in general Congress assembled. Jefferson sent a manuscript copy of the declaration to Richard Henry Lee on July 8, 1776 (see Correspondence). This is a contemporary copy of that copy [i.e. it is not in Jefferson's hand]. A note on the back, made by the unidentified transcriber, says that the alterations and interlinear additions were taken from Jefferson's original manuscript, which was meant to conform to the final printed text. 12 pp.
DS. Grant of 610 acres in Virginia to Fleming Bates. Signed by Jefferson as Governor. 1 p. with state seal.
DS, in French. A receipt listing five works presented by the French king to two American universities, with signature and date in Jefferson's hand. 1 p.

DS. Certifying that the attached printed copy of "An Act making Provision for the Reduction of the Public Debt" is true. With ADS of Dutch Minister, 1 Sept. 1790. Signed by Jefferson as Secretary of State.1 p.
DS. Printed Act of Congress. "An Act for the relief of certain Widows, Invalids and other Persons." Signed by Jefferson as Secretary of State. 2 pp.

DS. Recognizing Marc Antoine Alexis Giraud as commissary of commercial relations of the French Republic for the states of New Hampshire, Massachusetts, Rhode Island, and Connecticut. Signed by Jefferson as President and James Madison as Secretary of State. 1 p.

DS, on vellum. Patent issued to Elisha, Oliver, Otis, and George Bartlett for a machine for making hot wrought nails by rolling and pressing. Signed by Jefferson as President and James Madison as Secretary of State. 2 pp.
DS, on vellum. Papers for the ship Favourite, commander James Mackie. Signed by Jefferson as President and James Madison as Secretary of State. 1 p.
DS. David Humphreys' certificate of membership in the American Philosophical Society. Signed by Jefferson (President of the Society) and multiple other officers. 1 p.
Ship's papers for the brig Lucy. Form printed in French, Spanish, English, and Dutch. Signed by Jefferson as President and James Madison as Secretary of State. 1 p.

"Conversation of D.M. Randolph respecting Th. Jefferson." Manuscript by an unknown author relating the conversation of David Mead Randolph at a dinner party on February 15, 1805. Randolph spoke at length about Thomas Jefferson, claiming that in 1793 he had attempted to form his own political party and undermine Washington's administration, that he lied about a debt, and that he was intimate with Sall[y Hemings]. 4 pp.
Copy of a Presidential Proclamation. Responding to continued abuses of American neutrality by the British, ordering all British vessels to leave American waters. 7 pp.

Manuscript in an unknown hand consisting of copies of five Jefferson letters and documents [all in this collection], and the 25 April 1808 deposition of John Smith, Senator from Ohio, who testified that Jefferson tried to foment rebellion in the Floridas and Louisiana and acted falsely with regard to his knowledge of the Burr conspiracy. 44 pp.

AMs, Poplar Forest. Giving detailed directions to overseer Jeremiah A. Goodman for work at Poplar Forest and Jefferson's other Bedford County farms including the type and location of crops, ordering supplies, making arrangements about livestock, providing for slaves, etc. 5 pp.

AN. On a small slip of paper, notes on the purchase of plinths and fascia for 5 rooms and a hall. The note was gifted to Mary C. Day by Septimia R. Meikleham, granddaughter of Thomas Jefferson. Included in the folder are two letters and an envelope from Meikleham to Day.
AMsS. A list of books ordered from Joseph Milligan. [After 1796]. 1 p.
Autograph notes on the value of the dollar and its alloy proportion. 1 p. [Dates from after 1772]
Served as seventeenth President of the United States (1865â€“1869) following the assassination of Abraham Lincoln.
Filed by recipient.
LS, Washington, D.C. To the Acting Secretary of War. Asking that an order be issued to extend the time for convening a court martial in the trial of Colonel J.C. Crane. 1 p.

ALS, Washington. Marked "Private." Lengthy letter referring to the last year of [John] Tyler's administration, the tariff controversy, nullification, and mentioning Calhoun, Van Burne, Polk, Webster, Cass, etc. 5 pp.
Printed certificate with stamped signature, on vellum. Conferring the rank of Captain by brevet on William H. Forwood. Signed by Edwin M. Stanton, Secretary of War. 1 p.
Carte de visite, signed and dated on verso.
Carte de visite, signed beneath photo and on verso.

Served as Deputy Agent of Indian Affairs under his father-in-law William Jones. AMsS, an official copy of a Treaty of Peace with the Delaware Nation signed May 8, 1765. With extracts from minutes of a conference with the Six Nations and Delawares held at Johnson Hall, May 2-11, 1765. 37 pp. total, bound.
Naval officer during the American Revolutionary War. Letters to Benjamin Franklin.
LS, Brest. Enclosing a letter for the Countess of Selkirk and mentioning a rumor spread by the British that his raid on Whitehaven was a result of bribery from the French court. 2 pp.
LS, L'Orient. Forwarding a letter from Captain [Pierre] Landais with copies of papers concerning his ship Alliance [a privateer]. 1 p.

American statesman. ALS, Petersburg. To Seaborne Jones. Asking him to collect some debts, referring to the failure of an Indian treaty, and discussing the upcoming presidential election as [George] Washington has announced he will not serve another term. 2 pp.
American Revolutionary officer. ALS, Kingsbridge. To J.P. Palmer. Describing the retreat of the Continental Army from Long Island and Manhattan, with high praise for George Washington. 4 pp.

Armand-Guy-Simon de Coetnempren, comte de Kersaint; French sailor and politician. ALS, in French, Charleston. To Francois, Vicomte de Fontanges, Describing the siege of Savannah and criticizing d'Estaing. 3 pp.
Served as Union general during the Civil War. ALS, New York. To A.G. Grey. Ordering him to obey his commander, Colonel Harvey Brown. 1 p.

American politician and diplomat. ALS, Washington. To Nicholas Low. About the political moves in the establishment of a new U.S. Bank, and some reflections on the conduct of the war and peace-making. 4 pp.
Served in the Continental Army and as the first U.S. secretary of war. Letters filed by recipient.
LS, War Department. To the Governor of Connecticut. Ordering him to assist Colonel Rochefontaine in the erection of fortifications in Connecticut. 2 pp.

LS, War Department. To the Indian Commissioner, clarifying some confusion about boundary lines as defined in treaties between the Creek and Cherokee Indians in Georgia, with extracts from the treaties. 12 pp. total.
ALS, Boston. To the Secretary of War. Recommending Major Isaac Winslow of the Massachusetts militia for a commission in the expected war against the "immoral set of usurpers" in France. 4 pp.
LS, War Department. Giving official instructions for the Indian Campaign in the Northwest Territory. 6 pp.
Gilbert du Motier. French general and statesman. Letters filed by recipient.
ALS, La Grange. Discussing the political situation in France and the theory and practice of liberty as exemplified by the United States, with friendly news. 3 pp.
ALS, Richmond. To the citizens of Charlottesville, accepting an invitation to visit the city. 1 p.
LS, Hanover Court House. Reporting his movements and the action of the British forces in Virginia. 2 pp.
In French.
Eldest grandson of Thomas Jefferson.
ALS, La Grange. Entering a subscription for Thomas Jefferson's published correspondence and sending regards to the Jefferson family and friends at the University [of Virginia]. 1 p.
ALS, Paris. Explaining the impossibility of securing a copyright for publication [of Jefferson's correspondence] in France. 2 pp.
ALS, Paris. Forwarding a letter [not included]. 1 p.
French educator and politician. ADS, in French. An attack on Andrew Jackson and his actions, praising the pirate Laffite at the battle of New Orleans. 4 pp.
American explorer and Union general during the Civil War. LS to General [Charles P.] Stone. Requesting clarification of an order for additional troops. 1 p.
American lawyer and politician.

ALS, Fort Edward. Relaying information acquired from British prisoners captured by the Mohegans; expressing concern that the army is encroaching on the fishing rights of the Native Americans; mentioning widespread digestive illness; introducing the bearer. 2 pp.
ALS, Saratoga. Reporting various bits of news including a retreat to Fort Miller, a skirmish, his belief that the enemy will be stopped, and [Benedict] Arnold's intention to resign. 3 pp.
Served as U.S. secretary of state from 1915-1920.
TLS, Washington. To Representative E. J. Hill. Replying to a recommendation of Matthew E. Hanna for the diplomatic corps. 1 p.
TLS to Charles Gallup, enclosing an AMsS of an excerpt from a speech on "Prussianism." With a contemporary newspaper clipping reporting the speech.
American soldier and statesman. ALS to General [Nathanael] Greene. Suggesting relief for the 3rd Regiment and suggesting the supply of horses be hastened. 3 pp.
Governor of Connecticut. DS, Printed form. Appointing law officers. 1 p.

These documents relating to the League of Nations were gathered by Clarence M. Peacock, who was involved in the printing of various documents published by the American Commission to Negotiate Peace and other League of Nations committees. The file includes Peacock's own accounts of how, when, and where the documents were printed, and his honor at being involved in the League, if only from a mechanical standpoint. A few of the documents contain inscriptions from political leaders, acknowledging Peacock's role in the printing. Some of the documents are printer's proofs.

AMS. Describing the circumstances behind the printing of various documents used by the American Commission to Negotiate Peace, with mention of Ray Stannard Baker (Woodrow Wilson's press secretary). Also included is a piece of cardboard labeled "Proofs" and noting a "change of print."
TMs. Peacock's typed account of his involvement with the League of Nations. 7 pp.
The constitution of the League of Nations. With an autograph inscription to Peacock from David Hunter Miller, Technical Advisor to the Commissioners. 6 pp. with paper covers.
Covenant of the League of Nations. 9 pp.
Preliminary Peace Conference: Report of the Commission of the League of Nations. Woodrow Wilson inscribed and signed the cover. 20 pp.
Printed by the American Commission to Negotiate Peace.
Summary of the Conditions of Peace as presented to the German Plenipotentiaries at Versailles. 27 pp.
Preliminary Peace Conference, Protocol No. 1. 16 pp.
Preliminary Peace Conference, Protocol No. 2. 40 pp.
Preliminary Peace Conference, Protocol No. 3. 27 pp.
Preliminary Peace Conference, Protocol No. 4. 23 pp.
Annexes to Preliminary Peace Conference, Protocol No. 4. 20 pp.

Preliminary Peace Conference: Report of the Commission on the League of Nations. With an autograph inscription to Peacock from Whitney Shepardson, Secretary of the Committee of the League of Nations. 20 pp.
American Commission to Negotiate Peace: Composition and Functions. Listing officers. 7 pp.
Six Reasons Why America Should Become Mandatory for Albania. By C. Telford Erickson, Honorary Delegate of the Albanian Federation to the Peace Conference. 4 pp.

p.emph: Reports of the Central Committee on Territorial Questions to the Supreme Council.

scopecontent.p: Concerning the frontiers between Belgium and Germany. 4 pp.
Concerning the frontiers between Poland and Germany. 3 pp.
Concerning the frontier between Denmark and Germany. 5 pp.
Concerning the frontiers between Polish and Czecho-Slovak States, notably in the region of Teschen. 3 pp.
Concerning the future frontiers of Roumania [sic]. 6 pp.
Concerning the future frontiers of Yugoslavia. 8 pp.
Concerning the future frontiers of Greece with Enemy Countries (Bulgaria). 5 pp.
Oversize filing containing photostats and original copies of various documents related to Clarence M. Peacock and the covenant of the League of Nations. 13 pp.
American diplomat during the Revolutionary War.
Filed by recipient.

LS, Paris, partly in code (deciphered). Reporting that there will be two main subjects during an upcoming negotiation with Spain: affordable masts for Navy ships and the cession of Florida. Asking for instruction on both matters. 1 p.

ALS (draft), L'Orient. Written in both French and English, Lee denies that he intended his letter of April 17 to be menacing and returns contempt for Gerard's indifference. Written in response to an April 28 letter from Gerard (included). 2 pp. total.
LS (copy). Describing "atrocious injuries" received from unnamed persons who seek to malign Lee's character and undermine his work. 4 pp.

ALS, Paris. Complaining that Virginia's failure to send tobacco as payment for supplies is destroying Lee's reputation; discussing allies in the war; approving of the new French ministers; and promising to help a young cousin of the correspondent. 4 pp.

Ms draft, in French, of the treaty of alliance between the United States and France. With corrections in the hands of Arthur Lee and others, with ANS by Lee on the final page. 27 pp. Together with a copy of a document in which Louis XVI appoints Conrad Alexander Gerard to execute the treaty. 3 pp.

Major General in the Continental Army during the American Revolutionary War. ALS, Prato Rio (VA). To his sister, Sidney Lee. Defending his actions and integrity, expressing sympathy for the hardship of war on both America and Britain. 3 pp.
British politician who served as Lord of Admiralty. Many of the documents are in his hand, others were sent to him or relate to the business he conducted.

A copy of a "memorial" sent by the King of Great Britain to the King of Spain, complaining that the Spanish have continually violated the 1667 treaty of commerce by unlawfully searching and seizing British ships in the West Indies. 2 pp.
An account of Spanish depredations and the proofs of them laid before a Committee of Council. 12 pp.

From Roger Drake to Sir George Lee. Sending extracts of letters and petitions concerning Spain's inappropriate treatment of British ships in the West Indies. [See extracts below. The letter is dated 1737, but should likely read 1738.] 2 pp.
Memorial presented by West India merchants to the Duke of Newcastle, responding to the situation with Spain. 8 pp.
Minutes from a meeting of West India merchants updating on the status of petitions to the British and Spanish governments. 1 p.
Extract of a letter from Mr. Keene to the Duke of Newcastle. Discussing his numerous attempts to communicate grievances to the Spanish Governor in the West Indies. 1 p.

A translated copy of an order sent by the Marquis de Torreneuva to the Governor and Captain General of Cuba calling for Spanish interference with British shipping to cease, with a copy of a 1732 agreement between Britain and Spain. 4 pp.

A translated copy of an order issue by the King of Spain to the Governor of Puerto Rico. Outlining an incident wherein a Puerto Rican cruiser captured and plundered the ship St. James, Captain John Custis. Asking for restitution of the ship and cargo. 3 pp.
Printed "List of British Merchant Ships, Taken or Plundered by the Spaniards." Naming 52 ships, where they were bound, and when and where they were taken and plundered. 3 pp.
Extracts from a proposal by British Viscount [William] Barrington to raise a regiment of foreign Protestants in America. 3 pp.

"State of the Trade & Commerce of the Colonies in America." Reporting on American exports and imports, suggesting that an illicit trade with other nations is occurring among the colonists, proposing British ships of war be given power to search and seize American ships suspected of illicit activity. 3 pp.
Extracts from a July 22, 1745 letter written from Sir Peter Warren to Rhode Island Governor Gideon Wanton, evidently related to the capture of the Notre Dame Deliverance. 2 pp.
From William Wood to Sir George Lee, giving an account of the defeat and death of General [William] Braddock in the French and Indian War. enclosing the London Gazette [see below]. 2 pp.

Printed. The London Gazette from August 23-26, 1755, giving an account of Major General [Edward] Braddock's death in the French and Indian War. 2 pp. Send with the above letter from William Wood to Sir George Lee.
From Edward Clarke to unknown recipient. Giving an account of recent troop movements near Halifax in preparation for an attack on Louisburg, with mention of Admiral [Edward] Boscawen. 2 pp.
Eldest son of Robert E. Lee. ALS to a cousin, concerning an application submitted to [C.G.?] Memminger on behalf of another family member. 2 pp.
American Revolutionary officer and statesman nicknamed "Light Horse Harry" Lee.
Filed by recipient.
ALS, Williamsburg. Concerning supplies and the British attack on Norfolk. 3 pp.
ALS, Carters Tavern. Giving his plans to cross the Dan and stay close to the enemy, promising to keep Greene informed; requesting camp kettles. 1 p.
ALS. Reporting on the enemy's camp at Eutaw Springs and the death of General Leslie in a shipwreck, and suggesting a location for Greene to cross the Santee. 3 pp.
LS, Richmond. Appointing Lewis Captain in the volunteer militia to be raised for the protection of Russel [sic], Wythe, and Montgomery Counties (Virginia). With autograph postscript. 3 pp.
ALS, Richmond. Introducing the bearer, a Mr. Hopkins. 1 p.
ALS, Alexandria. Concerning the publication of Lee's memoirs and the possibility of incorporating Rhea's suggestions. 1 p.
ALS to the Governor of Upper Canada. Asking to renew a regular correspondence, commenting on revolution in France, thanking him for the gift of a map, and sending many well wishes. 7 pp.
ALS. Concerning a business matter with Sullivan who failed to turn over papers and deeds to creditors Anthony & Vaughan. 3 pp.
ALS. Referring to assumption of government by the U.S. Consul and apologizing for postponing payment of a debt. 1 p.
DS, on vellum. Granting acreage in Wythe County to Thomas Muse. 1 p.
American statesman from Virginia. Letters filed by recipient.
LS with autograph postscript, Chantilly. Saying that he will again become a "public man" and serve in the Senate (if elected), since he believes amendments to the Constitution are necessary. 2 pp.

ALS, Philadelphia. Sharing gossip that a British general wishes to defect to the Continental Army, and disagreeing with the actions of the Maryland legislature; with mention of negotiations in Canada, capture of a British transport, and relations with the Six Nation Indians. 3 pp.
ALS, Williamsburg. To his brother. Congratulating William on his marriage and announcing his own intentions to wed again; with comments on the "noble spirit of liberty" abroad in the colonies. 3 pp.
Confederate general during the American Civil War.
Filed by recipient.
ALS, Coosawatchie, S.C. Giving his recollection of the reports of General [P.G.T] Beauregard before the battle of Manassas. 2 pp.
ALS. Concerning the possible retirement of General [John C.] Pemberton and the defense of Charleston. 2 pp.
LS. Asking Davis to consider where the troops should be placed for the winter, and reporting on the successful destruction of many of the enemy's railroad lines. 3 pp.
LS, Headquarters. Planning to trick the enemy into sending troops to Savannah and thereby draw them away from Charleston, which he considers the more important of the two cities. 3 pp.
ALS. Complaining that a recent act passed in the House of Representatives that allows any soldier to be relocated to his home state will only cause trouble. 2 pp.
ALS, Camp Fredericksburg. Speculating as to the plans of the enemy with worries that the swollen rivers leave the Confederate troops with no clear advantage. 2 pp.
ALS. Reporting that the enemy has retired across the Rappahannock and Union General Stoneman was easily thwarted; mourning the loss of Major [John] Pelham. 1 p.
