LS. Offering a survey of the Confederate position at various locations with recommendations for defending Charleston and Fort Sumter and reports of the strength of Union General [Joseph] Hooker's army. 4 pp.
ALS, Camp near Orange Ct. House. Marked "Confidential." Updating on the movement of various Confederate and Union troops. 3 pp.
ALS, Richmond. Planning for the defense of Richmond by reporting what troops are available and suggesting precautionary measures. 2 pp.

ALS, Camp Orange. Reporting on the enemy's movements based on accounts from various spies, expressing concern over the size of Union General [George] Meade's command, strategizing the rearrangement of troops. 2 pp.
ALS, Camp Orange. Reporting that Union General Rosecrans is receiving reinforcements and Confederate General Bragg should therefore be supported to draw him out. 1 p.
ALS, Camp Orange. Suggesting the rearrangement of the commands of various generals, with notes by Jefferson Davis and S. Cooper on the back. 2 pp.
LS. Expressing concerns over the Confederacy's position in Georgia and Tennessee, and warning about the dangers to be expected from [Ulysses S.] Grant's army. 3 pp. (extremely faded).
LS. Again requesting that the Conscript Law be changed [see Jan. 13, 1864 above]. 3 pp.
LS, Orange County. Suggesting that the Confederacy take advantage of the approach of spring and plan a surprise attack on the enemy, offering two possible courses of action. 2 pp.
ALS. Reporting that the enemy is concentrating troops and saying he will soon require all the troops of the Confederacy. 2 pp.
ALS. Expressing the dire need of rations for both men and animals, and the necessity of curtailing "pleasure travel" to focus on getting supplies to the troops. 1 p.
ALS. Clarifying some discrepancies in former reports about the enemy. 2 pp.
ALS. Explaining the rationale behind keeping certain regiments together and separating others. 2 pp.
ALS. Responding to a report that Union General [Ambrose] Burnside is marching towards the Rappahannock, suggesting Confederate troops be drawn to meet him. 2 pp.
LS. Again reporting on Union General [Ambrose] Burnside's movements and suggesting countermovements for the Confederacy. 2 pp.
LS. On his present position opposite Grant and a scheme for capturing Washington. 5 pp.
ALS. Discussing the plans of General [Jubal] Early and stressing the need for regular and constant supplies. 2 pp.

ALS, Camp Petersburg. Stating that the Confederacy is entirely dependent upon itself; the European powers offer no sympathy or aid since they conceive of the war as a battle over "abstract slavery." 2 pp.
ALS. Giving reports on the movement of both Union and Confederate forces. 2 pp.
ALS, Petersburg. Asking whether Mobile should be defended or evacuated. 2 pp.
LS. Rescinding a proposition to rearrange troops as the idea did not prove agreeable to General Johnson. 2 pp.
LS. Saying that General Rhodes' position is unsafe and should be changed immediately. 1 p. (very faded).
ALS, Richmond, to the Governor of Virginia. Recommending four young men for military appointments. With autograph endorsement of Letcher and his secretary, P.F. Howard. 1 p.
ALS, Camp Fredericksburg. Concerning a shortage of food and the need to issue smaller daily rations. 1 p.
Secretary of War of the Confederate States.
ALS, Fredericksburg. Planning for the movement of troops to better defend Charleston and Wilmington. 2 pp.
LS. Stressing the importance of immediately strengthening the ranks of the Confederate army in preparation for the next campaign. 1 p.
LS. Announcing the death of General [Thomas Jonathan "Stonewall"] Jackson and making arrangements for the movement of his body. 1 p.
ANS on the back of a letter from Colonel Francis J. Thomas requesting arms for Maryland regiments. Lee noted that arms and other supplies are in short supply. 2 pp.
Signed photograph of Lee.

ALS, "Flag-Ship, North Atlantic Blockading Squadron, James River." To General B.F. Butler. Refusing to order his gunboats up the river to Trent's Reach until the enemy batteries and torpedoes are cleared from the shore. 4 pp.
American merchant and diplomat. Letters filed by recipient.
ALS, Nantes. To Benjamin Franklin, Silas Deane, and Arthur Lee. Reporting the defeat of Cornwallis in the Jersies and relating the arrival of two privateer prizes from the West Indian fleet. 2 pp.
ALS, Bruxelles [sic]. To his brother. Asking him to send money, mentioning [Thomas] Hardy, and passing a rumor of a new military campaign in America. 1 p.

ALS (initials), Brussels. To his brother. Predicting continued English military operations in Virginia, questioning some missing Loan Office certificates, asking about schooling for his son, and denouncing the diplomatic conduct of Benjamin Franklin. 2 pp.
ALS, London. Concerning the shipment of tobacco between Virginia and London, with mention of a petition against American duties submitted to Parliament. 7 pp.

Collection of 24 orders and dispatches written by various individuals relating to the Battle of Leipzig during the Napoleonic Wars. All items are in French; four are signed by Napoleon. The portfolio of orders is said to have been lost by French Marshal Etienne MacDonald during the battle and rediscovered in 1934 by the family of Captain Karl Von MÃ¼nsterberg. 36 pp. total.
French-American architect and engineer. ALS to A. J. Dallas, Pennsylvania Secretary of State. Saying that he is too busy to comply with a request to plan a building for Philadelphia. 2 pp.

Edouard Jean Pierre Liais was a U.S Consular Agent at Cherbourg, France; the papers in this file are related to his service in that post. Of note are items related to the Alabama and Kearsarge, warships of the Confederate States and United States, respectively. On June 19, 1864, the two ships met and battled off the port of Cherbourg. Union ship Kearsarge was victorious, sinking the Alabama. The file also contain items of general business from the Cherbourg consulate. Three paper folders used by Liais containing miscellaneous notations on the Alabama, Kearsarge, and U.S.S. Richmond are housed in Box 46 (oversize).
Letters to and from Liais. Filed by correspondent.
A newspaper correspondent from The New York Herald.
ALS to Liais. Asking him to inform Kearsarge captain [John A.] Winslow of a change in travel plans. 1 p.
ALS to Liais. Saying goodbye and asking Liais to write him in Paris, mentioning a visit to the hospital at Cherbourg. 2 pp.
U.S. Minister to France, 1861-1864.
ALS to Liais. Marked "Confidential". Asking Liais to telegraph captain John A. Winslow of the Kearsarge with the exact time the Georgia will depart Cherbourg. 1 p.
LS to Liais. Thanking him for the role he played in connection with the battle between the Kearsarge and Alabama. 1 p.
Letter from Liais. Thanking Dayton for a letter and expressing hope that he might someday return to Cherbourg under better circumstances. 1 p.

Draft letter from Liais to the U.S. Consul at Liverpool. Discussing a shipment of wine, requesting a copy of the official U.S. Diplomatic Correspondence for 1864, and sending news from James O. Putnam [U.S. Secretary of State]. 2 pp.
ALS to Liais. Asking Liais to report information about deposits at the Cherbourg custom house, and requesting he distribute some photographs. 2 pp. with original envelope.
AL (draft) from Liais. Responding to the above letter. 1 p.

Letter (copy) to Liais. Discussing a pamphlet written by Edge and photographs of the fight between the Alabama and Kearsarge taken by a Mr. Rondin. 3 pp. with Edge's calling card and a sheet of paper with his address.
Letter (draft) from Liais. Thanking Edge for sending copies of the pamphlet he wrote, saying that photographs have been sent. 1 p.
LS from Liais. Concerning negative rumors surrounding American ship Sabine, asking permission to investigate the matter. 1 p.
Draft letter from Liais. Expressing further concern about some negative activity surrounding the Sabine. 2 pp.
LS to Liais. Announcing the appointment of E. Postel as successor to Liais. Asking Liais to copy and transmit to Postel all the archives in his possession. 2 pp. with original envelope.

Letter from Dwight Morris (U.S. Consul at Havre) to L.M. Goldsborough (Commander of the U.S. European Squadron). Confirming the fidelity and hard work of Liais, and promising to request that Liais continue his service at Cherbourg. 1 p.
U.S. Consul at Havre.
Draft letter from Liais. Tendering the resignation of [Eugene] Liais [Edouard's father] as Consular Agent. Asking that his son, Edouard Jean Pierre Liais, be appointed his successor. 2 pp.
Letter (copy) to Liais. Acknowledging Liais' acceptance of the post of Consul. Saying that the nomination has now been forwarded to Washington, D.C. 1 p.

LS to Liais from Read, Consulate General of the U.S., stationed in Paris. Marked "Personal." Acknowledging receipt of a note and thanking Liais for information about a Mr. Webb. 1 p. with Read's business card.
U.S. Secretary of State, 1861-1869
Letter (copy) from Seward to James O. Putnam (U.S. Consul at Havre). Approving the appointment of Edouard Liais as Consul at Cherbourg. 1 p.
DS. Official certificate appointing Edouard Liais U.S. Vice Consul at Cherbourg. 1 p.
LS to Liais, marked "Unofficial." Asking Liais to recommend travel and lodging in Paris to midshipman L. Wilson, son of a government official. 2 pp.
LS to Liais from the Paymaster of the U.S.S. Kearsarge. Asking Liais to forward some messages and congratulating him on the victory. 1 p.
U.S. Minister at Paris.

On one leaf, two draft letters from Liais. One to Washburne and the other to S.L. Glasgow. Both express astonishment and hurt at Liais' being so quickly and inexplicably dismissed from his post with no word of warning or explanation. 2 pp.

Letter to Liais from E.B. Washburne's secretary. Stating that Liais' complaint (above) has been sent to [U.S. Secretary of State Hamilton] Fish, and saying that the Legation at Paris never had any problems with how Liais conducted his work. 2 pp. with original envelope.
Captain of U.S.S. Kearsarge.
Note, dated 7.30 am. Captain Winslow acknowledging receipt of a telegraph. 1 (torn) leaf.
Letter (copy) to Liais. Responding to a rumor that the Alabama is to receive reinforcements, asking that this be prohibited as the Kearsarge has been denied the same right. 1 p.
LS to Liais, in French. Concerning suspicious characters who have left Cherbourg to board the Alabama. 2 pp.
Filed chronologically.
Copy of the sworn testimony of Thomas Connor, given before the Vice-Consul of the U.S., describing the wreck of American ship Luna, which crashed into rocks off the cost of Balfleur. 2 pp.
Official certificate appointing Liais U.S. Vice Consul at Cherbourg. In French. 1 p.
Cherbourg newspaper Phare de le Manche. 4 pp.
French newspaper. 4 pp.
A copy of rules for dealing with enemy ships. In French. 3 pp.
The U.S. Consular Agency's copy of the muster roll for U.S.S. Kearsarge, noting the type of ship, number of guns, crew members, etc. 1 p.
Statements of various accounts with the U.S. Consular Agency related to U.S.S. Kearsarge, with charges for things such as telegrams, supplies, food, etc. 7 pp.
Bills and receipts from various hotels in Cherbourg charging for the room and board of American sailors and prisoners from the Alabama; many noted as having been paid by Liais. 9 items total.
Receipts for telegrams sent from Cherbourg. 9 total.

Announcement [likely for publication in a newspaper] explaining the death of Union seaman William Gowan from wounds received in the battle between the Kearsarge and Alabama. With a penciled French translation on the back. 2 pp.
The New York Herald newspaper, featuring multiple stories under the headline: "The Naval Battle Off Cherbourg." 8 pp.

Document entitled "In re Alabama," comprised of questions about possible collusion between the Alabama and the Deerhound. [The Deerhound was a private yacht which rescued some of the officers and crew of the Alabama when it began sinking during the battle with the Kearsarge.] With penciled notations on back. On stationery embossed "Edouard Liais/ Cherbourg." 1 p.
Copy of receipt for money paid to a fisherman named Leonard for two and half months of watching the Confederate steamer Georgia by night. 1 p.
Copy of receipt for money paid to Liais (by the U.S. Government), reimbursing postage and telegram fees. 1 p.
DS by Dwight Morris, U.S Consul at Havre. Official declaration of Edouard Liais as U.S. Consular Agent at Cherbourg. Stamped with seal of the U.S. Consulate at Havre. 2 pp.
Telegraph from U.S.S. Richmond Captain Mulling, at Lisbon, to the U.S. consul at Cherbourg, asking about the Sabine. Liais' penciled response on back. 2 pp.
Report of the English steamer City of Richmond, Captain Scott. In French. Noting the size and cargo. Signed by E. Forgel(?). With English translation. 2 pp.
DS. Inventory of the archives of the U.S. consulate at Cherbourg, to be passed from Liais to E. Postel; signed by both. 2 pp.
Penciled notations concerning manufacturers in Cherbourg. In French. 1 p.
Portions of a firsthand account of the battle between the Kearsarge and Alabama. Written on tissue paper (mostly faded) and partially copied onto 1890s letterhead from a French court. 9 pp.

Abraham Lincoln served as sixteenth President of the United States, from March 1861 until his death on April 15, 1865. This series dates from 1839-1865 and includes correspondence and documents pertaining to his Presidency as well his many years as a lawyer in Illinois. The series is divided into five main sections: Correspondence, Law Partnership Documents, Presidential Documents, Autograph Clippings, and Miscellaneous. Brief descriptions of the holdings are provided at the beginning of each section.

Many of Lincoln's letters and documents have been published at various times and in various formats. For the purposes of this finding aid, two main sources were consulted. The first was the multi-volume series: The Collected Works of Abraham Lincoln, Roy P. Basler, editor (New Brunswick, NJ: Rutgers University Press, c1953-1990). Letters and documents in this collection that are published in this series contain a bracketed notation citing the volume and page numbers. The other main source was The Law Practice of Abraham Lincoln: Complete Documentary Edition, available on CD-ROM; a full citation is provided at the beginning of the law partnership files.
Patrons will be given access to surrogate, photoduplicated copies of the Lincoln materials.

The items in this file date from 1846-1864. Included are many appointments and promotions for government and military officers. A handful of letters deal specifically with the Civil War including a pair of letters to General Joseph Hooker and an 1862 letter to General Don C. Buell proposing a military strategy. Also of note are two letters to John A.J. Creswell and Henry W. Hoffman respectively, in which Lincoln strongly urges the ratification of a new Maryland constitution which would free the state's slaves: "I wish all men to be free." The file is arranged alphabetically by correspondent and contains letters both to and from Lincoln. The majority of the letters sent to Lincoln also contain some notation in his hand (noted in descriptions).

ALS, Executive Mansion. To the Attorney General. "The two Senators of Penn. with the brief before them recommend Alexander Murdoch for Marshall of the Western District, and Robert B. Carnahan, for Attorney of the same district. Send me the commissions." 1 p. [Vol. IV: 329]

ALS, Springfield. Clarifying a previous letter and explaining that he simply wishes to reunite the Whigs of Illinois, with reference to General [John J.] Hardin [his former political opponent]. 1 p. [Vol. I: 380]

ANS. "Let the appointment within requested be made." Written on the back of a May 17 letter from Blow to Lincoln, asking that Henry Wright be given the position of the late Captain C. C. Manwarring. 1 p.
ALS, Springfield, Ill. Warmly acknowledging a letter with news of Brady's move to Pittsburgh. 1 p. [Vol. IV, 76]
ALS, Hartford, Conn. Asking that [Horace] Greeley or [James Warren] Nye or another good man be sent to speak at Keene, New Hampshire, on Friday evening. 1 p. [Vol. X: 50]
ALS, Executive Mansion. Eulogizing the late Owen Lovejoy, his "most generous friend." 2 pp. [Vol. VII: 366-7]

LS, Executive Mansion. Proposing a military strategy in which Union forces simultaneously attack the enemy in different locations, suggesting it be coordinated between Buell and [Henry Wager] Halleck. Written in the hand of John Hay with corrections by Lincoln. 3 pp. [Vol. V: 98-99]
ALS, Springfield. To his aunt. Sending a detailed statement outlining her financial and real estate holdings. 3 pp.
ALS, Executive Mansion. Asking whether Burnside has a position for an old classmate, George Patten. 1 p. [Vol. VI: 7]
U.S. Secretary of War from March 1861 to January 1862.
ALS, Executive Mansion. Insisting on the appointment of William Patten as paymaster. Cameron noted underneath that he was appointed "additional paymaster." [Vol. IV: 398-9]

ANS written on the back of a June 5, 1861 letter from C[arl] Schurz to A.T. McReynolds, transferring command. Lincoln's note to Simon Cameron approves the transfer. There is also an ANS by Cameron. 2 pp. [Vol. IV: 406]
ALS, Executive Mansion. Urging the immediate appointment of J[ames] H[enry] Lane of Kansas as brigadier general of volunteers. With ANS endorsement by Cameron. 2 pp.

ALS, Executive Mansion. Written on the back of an August 6, 1861 letter from John S. Phelps and Frank P. Blair who wish to organize a volunteer militia in southwest Missouri (2 pp.). Lincoln's letter to Cameron requests that Phelps be appointed to oversee the regiments. 1 p. [Vol. IV: 475-6]
ALS, Executive Mansion. Directing promotions for David Hunter, G[eorge] H. Stoneman, W[illiam] F. Smith, and Henry W. Benham. 1 p. [Vol. IV: 483]

ANS approving the appointments of Stewart Van Vliet, J.G. Barnard, C.C. Augur, and John B.S. Todd. Written on the back of a Sept. 18, 1861 letter from General George B. McClellan to Simon Cameron; signed by both. 2 pp.
ALS, Executive Mansion. Appointing Dr. Edward E. Phelps Brigade Surgeon at the request of Vermont authorities. Underneath is an ANS by Cameron. 1 p. [Vol. V: 67]

ALS, Executive Mansion. Stressing the necessity of getting contraband cotton away from the enemy, mentioning high inflation, agreeing that more effort should be put into organizing the Louisiana state government, and mentioning a confidential telegram sent to [David G.] Farragut. 3 pp. [Vol. VIII: 163-5]
ALS, Executive Mansion. To the Secretary of the Treasury. Telling Chase to meet with a Mr. Wood, who may be able to help save in the cost of engraving treasury notes. 1 p. [Vol. IV: 326]
ALS, Springfield. Refusing to comment on the Fugitive Slave Law, as his printed speeches contain all he could willingly say, but adding "Justice and fairness to all." 1 p. [Vol. IV: 93]
ALS, Executive Mansion. Urging Maryland to emancipate its slaves, saying it is a matter of national consequence and would aid in ending the rebellion. 1 p. with original envelope. [Vol. VII: 251]
ALS, Executive Mansion. Asking Dahlgren's opinion as to whether the government should purchase some of [Orison] Blunt's new guns. 1 p. with original envelope. [Vol. IV: 399]
ANS. Returning a writ to the clerk of the Woodford County Circuit Court. 1 p. [Vol. II: 205]
U.S. Secretary of the Interior from March 1849 to July 1850.

ALS, Springfield. Concerning the backlash that has occurred in response to Lincoln's recommendation of Turner R. King for the Land Office. Asking Ewing to suspend judgment and consider that objections to King are part of a larger movement against Lincoln. 1 p. [Vol. II: 44-45]

ALS, Bloomington. Responding to rumors that the Pension Agency of Illinois is to be divided; questioning the legality and expediency of such a measure; expressing concerns that it would injure the current Pension Agent, who is Lincoln's brother-in-law. 1 p.

ALS, Springfield. About legal business concerning mortgages and real estate of [William W.] Blanchard and [Mordecai] Mobley. Regretting that he can do nothing about the Land Office at Danville. 1 p. [Vol. II: 63]

ALS, Executive Mansion. Ordering Jacob R. Freese to replace Mr. Wilson as Commissioner of Board of Enrollment for 2nd Dist. of New Jersey, mentioning the appointment is approved by Senator [John C.] Ten Eyck. 1 p. [Vol. VIII: 25]
ALS, Washington. Asking the general's best impression of the number of the enemy's forces north of Strasburg and Front Royal. 1 p. [Vol. V: 235]
ALS, Springfield. Giving instructions for taking depositions of witnesses. 2 pp. [Vol. II: 382]
ALS, Springfield. Saying he will soon be visiting Chicago and may be able to handle a case for Haines and [George H.] Rugg while there. 1 p. [Vol. II: 426-7]

ANS agreeing to staff changes involving Julius Stahl, S.P. Heintzelman, and [Percy?] Wyndham, with mention of [Joseph] Hooker. Written on the back of a letter from Heintzelman to Stahl. It appears to have been forwarded to Halleck, who endorsed it as well. 2 pp.

ANS. "Let them go." On the back of a letter written from Baltimore and addressed to the President or the Secretary of War, petitioning for the wife and daughter of Rev. Dr. E. C. Henkle to be allowed to accompany him into exile to the South. 1 p.

ALS, Washington. Acknowledging receipt of a letter recommending William M. Black for Registar of the Land Office at Vandalia, saying other applications have been received, refusing to commit to any one of the applicants at this time. 1 p. [Vol. II: 23-4]
ALS , Springfield. Asking Herrick to immediately clarify whether he will support Lincoln or Mr. Butterfield for Commissioner of the General Land Office. 1 p. [Vol. II: 52]

ALS, Executive Mansion. Responding to Hoffman's request for a few words from Lincoln, to be read at a Maryland public meeting to ratify a new state constitution. Lincoln responded that he wished the people to ratify the new constitution and thereby abolish slavery; "I wish all men to be free." 2 pp. [Vol. VIII: 41-2]

ANS. "Please extend the leave of absence of Albert Holmes, of Scott's Nine Hundred, for sixty days." Written on the back of a February 24 ALS from W.H. Holmes to Lincoln, requesting the leave of absence for his sick son. 4 pp. total.
ALS, Executive Mansion. To the Judge Advocate General. Asking for facts and a legal opinion in the complicated case of Ridgely Greathorn, who was convicted as a pirate in California. 1 p.
ALS, Washington. Asking whether heavy rain and other events have significantly altered his situation. 1 p. [Vol. VI: 199-200]

ALS, Washington. 8:30 pm. Sending news that the Confederate army is in possession of Winchester and Martinsburg and is crossing the Potomac at Williamsburg. Asking to hear from Hooker. 1 p. [Vol. VI: 276]
Letter from Mary Todd Lincoln, written in third person. "The President & Mrs. Lincoln will be pleased to have Mr. James dine with them, informally, this eve, at 6 1/2 o'clock." 1 p.

ALS, Springfield. Sending a poem requested by Johnston [not included], mentioning his own poetry, and sending regards to [Archibald] Williams [attorney in Quincy, Illinois]. Beneath the letter is a March 2, 1872 ANS by Johnston authenticating the letter. 1 p. Also included is a March 7, 1872 ALS from Johnston to Harrie Hough, an autograph collector, to whom he gifted the above letter. 4 pp. [Lincoln letter published in Vol. I: 366-7]

ALS, Springfield. To his step-brother. Sending a bid for a mail contract, saying that an unnamed man cannot get a pension, and reporting that his son [Edward Baker Lincoln] died the first of the month. 1 p. Also included is a May 12, 1875 letter from William H. Herndon to a Mr. Winslow, to whom he gifted the above letter. [Lincoln letter published in Vol. II: 76-77]
ANS (initials). "I rather wish to make this appointment." Written on the back of an April 1 ALS from Leary to Lincoln requesting an appointment for Robert Cathcart. 2 pp.

ALS, Washington. Encouraging Linder to support General [Zachary] Taylor and not [James K.] Polk, as supporting Polk (and his handling of the Mexican-American War) would alienate a number of Whigs. 1 p. [Vol. I: 453]
ALS, Springfield. Reporting the arrival of New York depositions and asking for the immediate delivery of related materials, as court is about to commence. 1 p. [Vol. II: 110]

ALS, Washington. 5:45 PM. Telling McClellan that Confederate General [Thomas J.] Jackson is recrossing the Potomac and must be hurt. [Written shortly before the Battle of Antietam.] 1 p. [Vol. V: 418]
ALS, Executive Mansion. To the Quartermaster General. Introducing C[ornelius] Vanderbilt, Jr., who has a business proposition. 1 p. [Vol. VI: 432-3]
ALS, Exeter, NH. Declining a speaking engagement due to an already packed schedule; asking Pomeroy to pass the same news on to Mr. William Silvey. 1 p. [Vol. III: 554]

ALS, Executive Mansion. Apologizing after receiving a report from Mrs. Lincoln about a faux pas he committed the previous evening, expressing his embarrassment as he did not realize he had made a mistake. 1 p. [Vol. VII: 262]
ANS by Lincoln directing Dr. William H. H. Scott to fill a vacancy. Written on a Dec. 24 ALS from Scott to Lincoln, requesting an appointment. 3 pp.
ALS, Executive Mansion. To the Secretary of State. "Please send me a nomination for Hon. Caleb Lyon, as Governor of Idaho Territory." 1 p. [Vol. VII: 166]
U.S. Secretary of War from January 1862 to May 1868.

ALS, Executive Mansion. Urging Stanton to halt the delivery of additional mortars and beds to Cairo, as it seems there are more than enough. 1 p. Written in response to an enclosed telegram from A. Montgomery to General W.C. Meigs on the same subject. 2 pp.
ALS, Executive Mansion. Asking for six Indiana colonels to be appointed Brigadier Generals of Volunteers. With ANS endorsement by Stanton. 2 pp.
ALS, Executive Mansion. Directing Stanton to promote Major Robert W. Allen to Brigadier General, at the recommendation of [Henry Wager] Halleck. 1 p.
ALS, Executive Mansion. Appointing Alfred B. Farnsworth Second Lieutenant at the request of Senator [Zechariah] Chandler. 1 p.
LS, Executive Mansion. Asking for the paperwork for the nomination of Ralph B. Buckland as Brigadier General of Volunteers. 1 p. [Vol. V: 299]
ANS. Submitting a recommendation from New York City Mayor George Opdyke for Theo. O. Ebaugh to be appointed paymaster. Written on the back of a July 29 ALS from Opdyke to Lincoln. 3 pp. total.

Autograph signed memo. About a request from Wisconsin Governor [Edward] Saloman for a general hospital, asking that the Secretary of War make inquiries so that all states will be dealt with equally with regards to this matter. 1 p.
ALS, Executive Mansion. Ordering the appointment of Lieutenant Keeler as provost marshal of Oregon on recommendation of A.G. Henry and Mr. McBride. 1 p.
ALS, Executive Mansion. Asking Stanton or Joseph G. Totten to find employment as an engineer for his longtime friend John Von Horn. 1 p.

ALS, Executive Mansion. Asking Stanton to: 1) suspend action with regards to 400 Southerners on the eastern shore of Virginia who are being asked to swear allegiance to the Union or be deported, 2) suspend assessment of a damaged light house, as both matters are serious and require propriety. 1 p. [Vol. VI: 427]
ALS, Executive Mansion. "Please send me a nomination of George M. Pinney to be Provost Marshal for Dakota Territory in place of George P. Waldron, removed." 1 p.
ALS, Executive Mansion. Reiterating an order for the discharge of James M. Philips at the request of E.H. Webster, as the first order appears to have miscarried. 1 p. [Vol. VII: 427]

ANS. "If the vacancy occurs as stated, let the appointment, as requested, be made." Underneath is an ANS by Stanton: "This appointment is suspended to consult Senator Ten Eyck who objects." 1 p. The page has been torn and the leaf containing details of the appointment is lost.

ALS, Executive Mansion. Saying that he has endorsed a note from Mrs. Stone to Mrs. Lincoln. Suggesting the note and endorsement be presented to the Secretary of War [E.M. Stanton]. 1 p. [Vol. VI: 295]
ALS, Executive Mansion. Directing various army appointments. 2 pp. [Vol. IV: 413]

ALS, Springfield. Thanking Vandyke for complimenting him at the Philadelphia convention and agreeing to support Judge [William Lewis] Dayton and Colonel [John Charles] Fremont [for the Republican presidential ticket]. 1 p. [Vol. II: 346]

ANS, third person. Confirming that Colonel [August] Willich has been appointed a brigadier general. 1 p. [Vol. V: 253] With an ALS of Washburne of the same date spreading news of the appointment. Original envelope included.
Secretary of the Navy.
ALS, Executive Mansion. Asking Welles to select the best available man for the post of Chief Engineer of the Navy, to be appointed by Lincoln. 1 p. [Vol. IV: 297]

ALS, Executive Mansion. Asking to be relieved of the remaining California appointments, and reporting that charges against Samuel Bell have been cleared and he should therefore be appointed Navy Agent. 1 p. [Vol. IV: 335]

ALS, Executive Mansion. Expressing doubt over Wood's suggestion that the Southern States are planning to send representatives to the next congress. Saying that the when they are truly ready to negotiate they know how to communicate with him. Asking Wood to keep the letter confidential for the moment. 2 pp. [Vol. V: 553-4]
ANS. "I submit the within from General [Daniel E.] Sickles on an old and very painful subject." 1 p.

Lincoln had three successive formal law partnerships: junior partner to John Todd Stuart, junior partner to Stephen T. Logan, and senior partner to William H. Herndon. Documents pertaining to cases involving these men are filed under the name of the respective partnership. Lincoln was also involved in the Illinois judicial circuit, which required him to travel to various counties to either assist local attorneys or directly represent local litigants. This occasionally resulted in temporary, informal partnerships. Documents from such partnerships and other miscellaneous legal documents are housed in a separate folder at the end. Many of the dates are taken from docketing by court clerks. Missing dates, names, and partnerships were verified using an electronic resource: The Law Practice of Abraham Lincoln: Complete Documentary Edition, Martha L. Benner & Cullom Davis, editors (Champaign, IL : University of Illinois Press, c2000), available on CD-ROM.
Lincoln was junior partner to John Todd Stuart from 1837-1841.
ADS, signed "Stuart & Lincoln." William H. Marsh v. William H. Wemwag. Sangamon Circuit Court. 1 p.
ADS, signed "Stuart & Lincoln." James Bell & Co. v. Garrett Elkin. Sangamon Circuit Court. 1 p.
AD. Samuel West v. Lucetta & Phineas Stevens. 1 p.
ADS, signed "Stuart & Lincoln." Joel Wright et al. v. James Adams in the Schuyler Circuit Court. 1 p.
AD, Isaac R. Braucher v. the heirs of James Sayles. 2 pp.
Lincoln was junior partner to Stephen T. Logan from 1841-1844.
ADS signed "Logan & Lincoln." Receipt for their $25 fee in the case of the People versus William Rhodes. On a small slip of paper.
ADS, signed "Logan & Lincoln." Nathaniel Hay(?) v. Nicholas Bryan. Sangamon Circuit Court. 2 pp.
AD, Samuel Renshaw v. James Boyd. Signed by Renshaw and the Judge of the Sangamon Circuit Court, S[amuel] H. Treat. Sangamon Circuit Court. 2 pp.
ADS, signed "Logan & Lincoln." George Bryan v. Seth M. Tinsley & others. Lincoln was attorney for the defendant. Sangamon Circuit Court. 1 p.
AD. Thomas E. Jackson v. Jacob Applegate. Sangamon Circuit Court. 1 p.
AD. Willis Groves v. Thomas Fortune & Samuel Garvey. Signed by Morris Bird concerning his financial indebtedness to the defendants. Sangamon Circuit Court. 1 p.
AD. Willis Groves v. Thomas Fortune & Samuel Garvey. Signed by Benjamin M. Kizer concerning his financial indebtedness to the defendants. Sangamon Circuit Court. 1 p.
AD. Willis Groves v. Thomas Fortune & Samuel Garvey. Signed by Moses Ellsworth concerning his financial indebtedness to the defendants. Sangamon Circuit Court. 1 p.
ADS, "Logan & Lincoln." Petition of Edmund Taylor, administrator of the estate of the late Washington Ray, requesting to sell certain lands to cover Ray's debts. Sangamon Circuit Court. 2 pp.
ADS, signed "Logan & Lincoln." Horatio M. Vendeveer v. James Baker, Andrew D. Northcutt, & Peter Porter. Christian County Circuit Court. 2 pp.
DS, signed "Lincoln for Deft." Charles H. Valentine & Co. v. John Delaney. Written and signed by M[ason] Brayman, attorney for the plaintiff. Sangamon Circuit Court. 1 p.
Lincoln was senior partner to William H. Herndon from 1844-1861.
ADS, signed "Lincoln & Herndon." John Calhoun v. John Warner & Lawrence Gros. 1 p.
ADS, signed "Lincoln & Herndon." Catharine Penny v. Henry McHenry & Matthias Yoakum. Sangamon Circuit Court. 3 pp.
ADS, signed "Lincoln & Herndon." Elizabeth Plunket v. Coleman Gaines & Madison A. Cartwright. Sangamon Circuit Court. 2 pp.
ADS, signed "Abraham Lincoln," "A. Lincoln," and "Lincoln & Herndon." Jane E. Allen v. Robert Allen, Jr. 2 pp. with two smaller slips of paper with notes in Lincoln's hand.
AD. Jane E. Allen v. Robert Allen, Jr. Sangamon Circuit Court. 1 p.
AD. Affidavit of John Allen for McDaniel et al. v. Correll et al. Signed by Allen. Sangamon Circuit Court. [Lincoln & Herndon also worked with James C. Conkling on this case.] 2 pp.
AD. Affidavit of William Hickman for McDaniel et al. v. Correll et al. Signed by Hickman. Sangamon Circuit Court. [Lincoln & Herndon also worked with James C. Conkling on this case.] 2 pp.
AD. Affidavit of Joseph McDaniel for McDaniel et al. v. Correll et al. Signed by McDaniel. Sangamon Circuit Court. [Lincoln & Herndon also worked with James C. Conkling on this case.] 1 pp.

ALS, Springfield. To Messrs. S C. Davis & Co. Refusing to continue to handle a land case as Davis & Co have been demanding and unresponsive; requesting the case be passed to lawyer William Fishback. Both the front and back contain notes by Lincoln's law partner, William H. Herndon, that the letter is "never to be published." 2 pp. [Col. III: 338]
ADS, signed [James C.] "Conkling & Lincoln & Herndon." Thomas Correll & others v. James McDaniel & others. 1 p.
ADS, signed "Lincoln & Herndon." A. Spencer, Nye & others v. Peter Ambos & others. Sangamon Circuit Court. 1 p.

Containing documents from informal law partnerships (including multiple cases with Ward Hill Lamon, who later became Lincoln's Presidential bodyguard), as well as miscellaneous other documents related to his legal career.
ADS. Receipt for ten dollars received from J.A. Crain as the fee for Crain v. Walter "except a contingent fee, as per his written promise to me." On a slip of paper.
AD. Joseph Gundy v. John Van Gundy, Vermilion County Circuit Court. [Lincoln worked with attorney John H. Sconce for this case.] 2 pp.
ADS, signed [Oliver L.] "Davis, Lincoln, and Lamon." William Bachop v. William M. Lamm. 1 p.
ADS, signed "Lincoln & Lamon." Samuel & George W. Titus v. Joseph B. Lamon. Signed also by "Davis for the pltff." 1 p.
ADS, signed "Lincoln & Lamon." John Clark v. John Hoxworth and others. Vermilion County Circuit Court. 1 p.
AD. James A. Barret v. William McDonald et al. Christian County Circuit Court. Signed by Barret. [Lincoln worked with attorney Horatio M. Vandeveer for this case.]1 p.
AMsS. A legal opinion regarding an act of Congress related to land surveys. 2 pp. [Vol. III: 348-9]
ADS. Michael Courtney v. Erastus French. 1 p.
AD to the U.S. Circuit Court concerning Joshua F. Speed. Post-1844. 3 pp.

Lincoln's Presidential documents are split into four sections: Memoranda, Discharges & Pardons, Commissions, and Orders. The majority of these items are official documents that merely contain Lincoln's signature and/or a quick notation in his hand.
Autograph memoranda in which Lincoln noted important details from meetings and conversations.
ADS noting a promise to [John Brooks] Henderson and [Charles W.] Noell to appoint Frederick Dodge paymaster in the Regular Army, or at least a grade higher in line. 1 p.
ANS, Executive Mansion. "I am in favor of Captain David V. Derickson for Provost Marshal, and Henry Fetter for enrolling commissioner...20th Dist. Of Penn." 1 p.
ANS. Noting that Samuel A. Pancoast of Hampshire County, West Virginia, had called that day asking for an appointment, following 17 months of imprisonment. 1 p.
ADS. Noting that Messrs Bonifant and J.F. Wagner requested Colonel John C. Holland be appointed provost marshal for the 5th Dist. of Maryland. 1 p.
ANS written on the front of a stamped envelope addressed to Lincoln, giving his decision not to interfere with a matter involving the Provost Marshal General.
Autograph memorandum concerning J. Wesley Greene, who met with Lincoln and pretended to be an associate of Jefferson Davis. 1 p. [Possible date December 1862; see Vol. V: 517 for more.]

Friends and family members of soldiers often wrote to Lincoln pleading for an official discharge or pardon for their loved one based on age, illness, or family situation. Lincoln noted his responses on the back of the letters, frequently granting the requests.
ADS. Rescinding an order designating William H.H. Hampson a deserter, after learning from James F. Wilson that Hampson is seriously ill and unfit for service. Ordering a proper discharge. 1 p.
ANS. "Let Thomas Bedford, named within, take the oath of allegiance, and be discharged." Written on the back of an October 20 letter from Brutus J. Clay to Lincoln. 1 p.
ANS. "Let the boy be discharged." Written on the back of a March 7 letter from John F. Hurst to E. Cowan, asking for the discharge of his young son Daniel, who enlisted against his wishes. 1 p.

ANS. "Satisfied that this statement is correct, this man--Simon H. Elliott--is pardoned." Written on the back of a 2 page statement describing the reasons why Elliott did not report for duty, submitted by his father.
ANS. "Let this boy be discharged." Written on the back of the sworn statement of Thomas Closson, who testified that his son, Caleb H. Closson, enlisted underage and should be returned home. 1 p.

ANS. "Let this boy be discharged." Written on the back of the sworn statement of Michael and Ann Coady, who testified that their son, Michael Coady, enlisted underage and should be returned home. 1 p.
ANS. "Let the man be discharged." Written on the back of a copy of a letter from A.S. Buckner to J.W. Payne, approving Payne for detached duty. 1 p.

ANS. "Let this boy be discharged, on restoring bounty, if any." Written on the back of a sworn statement from John Lyon, testifying that his nephew, James H. McManemin, is underage for enlistment. 1 p.

ANS. "Let this man take the oath of Dec. 8 and be discharged." Written on the back of letter written to H. Winter Davis, testifying to the loyalty of the West family, particular the son. Davis wrote an ANS forwarding the letter to Lincoln. 1 p.
ANS. "Pardon." Written on the back of a letter from Illinois Governor Richard Yates to Lincoln, requesting a pardon for Leander Patteson, who enlisted underage and is unfit for service. 1 p.
ALS, Executive Mansion. "Let Private Thomas Lowery of Co. G 11th New-Jersey Vols, now in hospital at Philadelphia, be discharged. Addressed to the Secretary of War [Edwin M. Stanton]. 1 p.
ANS. "At the request of Hon. Mr. Stevens, the pardon within requested is granted." Written on the back of an April 20, 1864 ALS from Thaddeus Stevens to Lincoln. 2 pp.

ANS. "Let the boy be discharge on refunding any bounty received." Written on the back of the sworn statement of Roxana Metcalf, who requests her son, Marquis L. Metcalf, be discharged and returned home as he is too young for military service. 1 p.
ANS. "Pardon, for unexecuted part of punishment." Written on the back of June 3 ALS from William H. Munroe, pleading for a pardon for deserter Charles B. Clark. 3 pp.

ANS. "Let this boy be discharged on refunding any bounty received." Written on the back of the sworn affidavit of William W. and Mary Ann Cassidy, who request the discharge of their son, as he is underage; attached to a letter from John G. Nicolay. 2 pp.

ANS, Executive Mansion. Recording that Oscar E. Burnham of 106th Co. H, New York Volunteers, is pardoned for any desertion charges provided he returns to his regiment and serves out the rest of his term. 1 p.

ANS. "Let this man be discharged, upon James F. King, being substituted for him, and not charged to the quota." Written on the back of a Sept. 22 autograph signed memo recording Lincoln's promise to discharge Lyman H. Tuttle should a suitable substitute be found. 2 pp.
ALS, Executive Mansion. Addressed to the Adjutant General [Lorenzo Thomas]. "If the drafted man Robert Westlake, will put in a good substitute, let him do so and be discharged." 1 p.
ANS. "Let Thomas W. Johnson, prisoner of war at Fort Delaware, take the oath of Dec. 8 and be discharged." Written on the back of a clipped letter from Andrew Johnson, with Johnson's signature. 1 p.
ANS. "Let the boy be discharged on refunding any bounty received." Written on the back of the sworn statement of Philena Fay, testifying that her son, Loomis C. Fay, enlisted underage. 1 p.

ANS. Pardoning a man for desertion on condition of return to his regiment. Written on a Dec. 29 ALS from James Jameson, requesting the pardon. Containing also the signatures of I[srael] Washburn and W[illiam] P[itt] Fessenden, testifying to the reliability of the writer. 4 pp.

ANS. "If the man puts in a substitute for three years, let him be discharged." Written on the back of a Jan. 10 letter from Lucius J. Hendee, requesting the discharge of Lafayette G. Fuller on grounds of his health. 1 p.
ANS. "Let this man be discharged." Written on the back of a letter from E.C. Ingersoll requesting the discharge of Ephraim Black. 2 pp.
ANS. "Pardon & discharge." Written on the back of a Jan. 8 letter to Lincoln requesting the pardon & discharge of Benjamin Shearer based on youth and health. 1 p.

ANS. "Let him be discharged." Written on the back of a letter from D.W. Young requesting the discharge of J. C. Denison. Approved and signed also by J. F. Farnsworth of the House of Representatives. 1 p.

ANS. "On the representation and at the request of Hon. J.C. Sloan of Wisconsin, Burt Scott, of the 3rd U.S. Cavalry is hereby pardoned for any desertion heretofore committed, and discharged the service." 1 p.
ANS. "Let these men take the oath of Dec. 8, 1863 & be discharged." Written on a letter from A.L. Knapp submitting the names of sixteen prisoners of war for discharge. 2 pp.
DS, on vellum. Appointing William Henry Forwood Assistant Surgeon. Signed also by Secretary of War Simon Cameron. 1 p.
DS, on vellum. Appointing John Godfrey Assistant Quartermaster of Volunteers with the rank of Captain. Signed also by Secretary of War Edwin M. Stanton. 1 p.
DS. "Ferdinand Andrews is hereby appointed to discharge the duties of Second Auditor of the Treasury during the absence of E.B. French, the Auditor." 1 p.
ADS. Printed certificate appointing Manuel S. Salazar as "Agent for the Indians in the territory of New Mexico." Signed also by Secretary of the Interior J.P. Usher. 1 p.
For the affixing of the Seal of the United States.
DS. Ordering the Secretary of State to affix the Seal of the United States to a letter addressed to the President of Ecuador. 1 p.
DS. Ordering the Seal of the United States to be affixed to an envelope addressed to the Sultan of Turkey. 1 p.
DS. Ordering the Seal of the United States to be affixed to the ratification of the postal convention between the U.S. and Costa Rica. 1 p.
Various endorsements and signatures clipped from Lincoln letters and documents. All on small slips of paper.
Clipping of Lincoln's signature from a warrant. 1 p.
"Respectfully submitted to the Secretary of War. A. Lincoln." On a piece of an envelope.
"Submitted to the Sec. of War. A. Lincoln."
"Let the men take the oath of Dec. 8, and be discharged. A. Lincoln."
"Let the men take the oath of Dec. 8, and be discharged. A. Lincoln."
"Let this man be discharged, on taking the oath of Dec. 8, 1863. A. Lincoln."
"Let this man take the oath of Dec. 8, 1864 and be discharged. A. Lincoln."
"Let this man take the oath of Dec. 8, 1863, and be discharged. A. Lincoln."
"Approved on taking oath. A. Lincoln."
"Let this man take the oath of Dec. 8, 1864 & be discharged. A. Lincoln."
"Let this man take the oath of Dec. 8, 1863 & be discharged. A. Lincoln."
"Let this man be discharged, on taking the oath of Dec. 8, 1863. A. Lincoln."
Lincoln's signature endorsing orders for a discharge.
ANS clipping from a letter or document reading: "Submitted to the Commissioner of Public Buildings, with direction that he give immediate attention to the subject." On a small piece of paper.
"Submitted to Gen. Halleck. A. Lincoln." With a few other words written on a clipping from an envelope.
Including a fragment of a speech on Stephen Douglas, Lincoln's political opponent, and an agreement among Lincoln and the other proprietors of a cemetery in Springfield, Illinois.
AMs. Fragment of a speech on Stephen Douglas, mentioning their early acquaintance and the contrast in their careers. [The date is based on a written note by Lincoln, see Vol. II: 382-3 for more]

ADS with many other signatures, Springfield, Illinois. Agreement among the proprietors of lots in Hutchinson's Cemetery appointing John Hutchinson agent and superintendent of said cemetery. 1 p., very damaged. With a later note explaining that the agreement was found among John Hutchinson's papers. [Vol. III: 399] (Document is very damaged.)
Autograph endorsement on the back of a New York check from Spofford & Tileston.

AMs, in pencil. Consisting entirely of columns of numbers said to be tabulations of the number of Union forces at Knoxville, based on a telegraphic report from General Ambrose Burnside. Possible date October 20, 1863. 1 p.
AD. List of names for provost marshal in nine districts in Missouri. 1 p.
Stamped envelope docketed in Lincoln's hand: "David V. Derrickson. 20. Cong. Dist., Penn."

American statesman. LS to Rufus King, U.S. Minister to Britain. Outlining the probable makeup of President Thomas Jefferson's cabinet; giving instructions for King to convince Great Britain of America's "friendly disposition." 3 pp.
American aviator.
ALS to George Anderson, overseer of the Lindbergh estate. Responding to a letter from W.C. Dennis of Bulk's Nurseries concerning the cost of plants for the estate grounds [on the same page]. 1 p.
Newspaper photograph of Lindbergh and Calvin Coolidge, signed by both men.
Printed DS, addressed to Richard Varick. "Instructions for the inlisting [sic] of Men." Signed by Lispenard as President Pro-Tempore of the New York Provincial Congress. 1 p.
American Revolutionary colonel. ALS, Free Town. To Colonel [Ephraim] Bowen. Complaining that he has not received the "portmanteaus" he has requested. 1 p.
American merchant & statesman. LS, New York. To Richard Derby. Settling accounts. 1 p.
American politician and diplomat.
Filed by recipient.
LS, Philadelphia, To the Governor of New York. Congratulating him on the newly-proclaimed peace and advising him to carefully observe the provisions of the treaty. 1 p.
ALS, Paris. To James Monroe. Protesting against the guarantee for the purchase of Louisiana offered to the French commissioners by Monroe [it was refused but later taken up by Napoleon]. 6 pp.

DS, Paris. Signed also by James Monroe. Appointing Fulwar Skipworth commercial agent of the U.S. in Paris, to serve on the board of commissioners engaged in examining claims of U.S. citizens against the French republic. 2 pp.
Governor of New Jersey. Letters filed by recipient.
LS, Princeton. To the Vice President of Pennsylvania. Promising to apprehend some robbers but only after first dealing with British militants in New Jersey. 1 p.
ALS, Trenton. To the President of Pennsylvania. Asking Moore to respect General Washington's orders banning movement through areas near enemy lines in New York and New Jersey. 2 pp.
Original deed [in Spanish] and hand-drawn map for a piece of land in Natchez granted to Elizabeth Derbin, with subsequent transfer to William Basset. 5 pp.
English Governor General. ADS confirming the title to land in New Castle, Delaware to Mathias & Emilius De King. Signed also by secretary Mathias Nicols. 1 p.
Merchant and real estate speculator. DS by Low and his wife, mortgaging a large portion of Manhattan for $25,000 to the Trustees of the First Protestant Episcopal Church School. 7 pp.

Series of documents pertaining to British Loyalists who lost money and property in America as a result of the Revolutionary War. The British government created the Office of American Claims to address the issue and attempt to recoup the losses. A number of the documents relate to British Prime Minister William Pitt (1759-1806).
Abstract of an act passed in Georgia concerning payment for confiscated property. 2 pp.
Copy of a South Carolina act to restore both real and personal estate to certain persons named therein. 11 pp.
Copy of a resolution concerning the treatment and claims of Loyalists in America. 2 pp.

Letter from the Office of American Claims to British Prime Minister William Pitt. Enclosing a statement of losses incurred by Loyalists. Signed by commissioners John Wilmot, John Marsh, and Robert Mackenzie. 2 pp.

Copy of a letter from Neil McLean to William Pitt. Complaining of being wronged by the commissioners for American Loyalists [Office of American Claims]. 20 pp. with 11 pp. of supporting documentation.
Copy of the twelfth report of the Commissioners of American Claims (John Wilmot, Robert Kingston, John Marsh, and Robert Mackenzie). Reporting on losses incurred by Loyalists in America. 30 pp.
Draft of a memorandum concerning Loyalists petitioners seeking to recoup losses. Docketing on verso says the memo was submitted to [William] Pitt. 3 pp.
Claimants were filed by class.
British subjects who were not resident in the American States but lost property there in consequence of their attachment to the British government. 1 p.
Claimants who took oaths to the American States. 1 p.
Loss sustained in consequence of the capture of a vessel under the authority of the Prohibitory Act. 1 p.
French diplomat.

LS, Philadelphia. To the Governor of Havana, notifying him that Robert Morris (U.S. Secretary of the Treasury) is sending a Mr. Brown to negotiate a large letter of exchange and asking his assistance. 2 pp. [Letter has been reported missing as of 16 August 1863.]
LS, in French. To [John F.] Mercer, delegate from Virginia. Saying that he has no further information about the ports of France open to Americans. 2 pp.
Served as professor and President of Princeton University. ALS, Princeton. To Reverend George Bush. Notifying him of his appointment as teacher of languages. 1 p.
Wife of President James Madison.
ALS, Montpelier. To her brother. Asking him to clear up some business with family properties and sending news from other family members including information on Napoleon's return to France. 3 pp.
AMs. Sketch of the biography of her husband, containing at the end a list of his correspondents, partly based on an original by Madison (see James Madison file). 22 pp.
NS. Note to a Mrs. Grennell, declining an invitation to spend the evening together. 1 p.
Fourth president of the United States (1809â€“1817).
Filed by recipient.
Served in Madison's Cabinet as secretary of the Treasury.

ALS, Montpelier. Marked "Private." Questioning the best method to raise loans abroad, discussing General [Andrew] Jackson's treaty with the Creeks, and pondering the probable effect of European events on Anglo-American relations. 2 pp.

ALS, Washington. Marked "Private." Concerning an investigation by the House of Representatives into the British attack on Washington; defending his actions related to the event and urging Campbell to be completely forthright when questioned by the investigative committee. With a very rough draft of Campbell's response. 2 pp.
ALS, Washington. Discussing the strength of the union of states in the face of the war and the effectiveness of local and national efforts to combat adversaries. 2 pp.
ALS, Montpelier. Congratulating Eustis on his election as governor of Massachusetts and discussing the growth of ideas within the Republican party as compared to the Federalists. 3 pp.

ALS, Washington. To his brother-in-law. Waiting expectantly for news of a treaty with France for the cession of Louisiana, planning a visit, and discussing how a drought is affecting food production and prices. 2 pp.
ALS. Saying that Judge [Thomas] Todd will call at Monticello and that he and Mrs. Madison will visit there the following evening. 1 p.

LS, Department of State. To the U.S. Minister at London. Enclosing a protest of Captain Newell of the Sea Flower against the impressment of American seaman by British commanders; stating the position of the U.S. government on the issue. With notes by Rufus King on verso. 1 p.
LS, Washington. Sending copies of documents [not included] concerning four men said to have been impressed into British warships; asking Lenox to procure their discharge. 1 p.
LS, Washington. Forwarding proofs of citizenship [not included] for three men said to have been impressed into British warships. 1 p.
LS, Washington. Enclosing papers [not included] concerning American seaman who may be detained on British warships. With duplicate copy. 1 p.
Madison's wife.
ALS. Enclosing various letters [not included] and many bits of news from family and friends. 2 pp.
ALS. Discussing her health and expenses, enclosing various letters and bits of business, with news of many friends and colleagues. 2 pp.
ALS, Washington. On personal matters including expenses for a doctor and cook, with mention of the arrival of a Mr. Livingston and an ambassador from Tunis. 2 pp.
ALS, Montpelier. Outlining the problems arising from events following Napoleon's return to power and the correlated questions of policy for the U.S. army and diplomatic negotiations. 3 pp.

LS, Washington. Congratulating Napoleon on the birth of his [step] granddaughter, Josephine [daughter of EugÃ¨ne de Beauharnais, a son from his wife's previous marriage]. Signed by Madison as President and Robert Smith as Secretary of State. 1 p.
ALS, Washington. Providing directions for avoiding spoilage in a shipment of cider. 2 pp.
ALS, Montpelier. Enclosing a letter from an applicant [not included] and recommending the re-publication of a newspaper article on hemp and flax. 1 p.

ALS, Montpelier. Affirming their friendship, expressing concern over the legislature in Thomson's "adopted" state of Kentucky, sending news of financial difficulties in Virginia, and mentioning Lafayette, Judge [Thomas] Todd, and [Thomas] Jefferson. 2 pp.

ALS, Washington. To the Governor of New York. Introducing and recommending Mr. Surville, a French engineer and friend of Lafayette, who desires work in the U.S. related to the building of canals and bridges. 1 p.
ALS, Washington. To an applicant for a collectorship in Norfolk, explaining the proper methods of securing the position, with mention of President Thomas Jefferson and Albert Gallatin. 1 p.
Ship's papers for the schooner George. Form printed in French, Spanish, English, and Dutch. Signed by Madison as President and James Monroe as Secretary of State.
Appointing James Carr as a tax collector for Massachusetts. Printed form. Signed by Madison as President and James Monroe as Secretary of State. 1 p.
Ship's papers for the ship Columbia. Printed form on vellum. Signed by Madison as President and James Monroe as Secretary of State. 1 p.

AMs. "Memorandum sent Sep. 1816 to Mr. Delaplaine at his request," consisting of an autobiographical sketch of 4 pages with interlineations, many in a different hand. With a contemporary transcript (2 pp.) and a fuller 14 page draft of his biography (neither in Madison's hand). A similar copy can be found in the hand of his wife, Dolley Payne Madison, in her file (above).
Miscellaneous documents relating to citizens of Maine.
ADS of Reverend John Newmarch. Receipt issue by Newmarch to the town treasurer of Kittery, Maine. On a small slip of paper.
Lincoln County, ME. Inventory of the late Joseph Foster's estate. 2 pp.

Printed form of the oath and subscription required of officers in the militia of Maine. Signed by six men, all from the town of Cape Elizabeth and members of the first corps, second brigade, fifth division. 1 p.
American educator and politician. Letters filed by recipient.
ALS, Yellow Springs, Ohio. Inviting him to lecture at Antioch College. 2 pp.
ALS, Washington. Asking whether there are any vacancies at the House of Representatives that might be filled by the son of A. D. Hodges. 1 p.
ALS, Yellow Springs, Ohio. Promising to notify Plummer if he travels East this winter. 1 p.
ALS, West Newton, Mass. Replying to some questions about schools and taxes. 1 p.
Union general in the American Civil War. LS to General Ambrose Burnside. Ordering him to immediately report to the headquarters of the Army of the Potomac via Fort Munroe. 1 p.

American Revolutionary War soldier. Portion of an LS to Major General [Benjamin] Lincoln. End of a letter reporting on the arrival of enemy ships and his sending Lieutenant Beekman to command Fort Littleton. 1 p.
Letters between various members of the Marshall family including Benjamin, Charles, and Christopher, Jr., all sons of Christopher Marshall, Sr. of Lancaster, Pennsylvania. Letters filed by author.
Fragment of an ALS to his wife, Sally. Discussing family news and some business with pig iron. 1 p. (partial)
ALS, Deep Creek Furnace. To his wife, Sally. Describing how a business deal to secure iron has gone awry. 2 pp.
ALS, Philadelphia. To his father. Reporting on the war, French support of American currency, and the arrival of Lafayette in America. 3 pp.
ALS, Philadelphia. To his wife, Sally. Describing the battle of the Brandywine. 1 p.
ALS, Providence. To his father. Concerning the death of his brother, Benjamin Marshall, and the settling of his estate. 3 pp.
Two part ALS, one half by Christopher and one half by Charles, to their father. Both describing the last illness of their brother Benjamin Marshall, with mention of Aunt Lydia Darragh. 4 pp.
Served as Chief Justice of the United States from 1801-1835. Letters filed by recipient.
Minister Plenipotentiary from the United States to the Court of Madrid.
ALS. Marked "No. 3." Concerning a dispute with the Spanish government over commercial claims and the seizure of some American vessels taken to Spanish ports. 10 pp.

ALS. Marked "No. 4." Asking Humphreys to address the claims of specific individuals who sustained losses at the hands of Spain [due to the seizure of American vessels], while also requesting that a general settlement for the total amount of depredations also be reached. 3 pp.
ALS, Washington. Thanking him for recommending amendments to the Constitution, but stating that he will not support changes to the government that do not have clear advantages. 1 p.
Miscellaneous documents relating to citizens of Maryland.
Appointing seven men to serve as justices of the levy court of Anne Arundel County, Maryland. Signed by Maryland State Chancellor Alexander C. Hanson. 1 p.

Ms journal of an anonymous Maryland lawyer. Giving receipts and disbursements relating to cases involving prominent Pennsylvania, Virginia, and Maryland families. Entries concern the executors of the estate of George Washington, various business transactions, and personal transactions between various families. Names include: Gilpin, Fitzhugh, Mason, Hartshorne, Evans, Barnes, Carroll, etc. Including an alphabetical index of his clients. 128 pp., bound.

This series contains papers relating to various towns in Massachusetts. The majority of items are legal documents in the form of land deeds, writs, and tax forms. The series is arranged alphabetically by name of town and chronologically within each town file. In the cases of documents featuring multiple parties, the following arrangement generally applies: Writs are filed by the town of the defendant. Letters are filed by the town of the writer. Land deeds are filed by the town in which the land was located. Researchers should note that individuals and families may be found in multiple documents both within town files as well as across the entire series. Of particular note in this regard are Justice of the Peace Abel Lawrence and Massachusetts Congressional Representative John Locke. The final folder in the series contains miscellaneous general documents related to the state of Massachusetts.
Transferring land from William French to James Humphreys. 1 p.
Transferring land from Jacob Fox to Abel Prescott. 1 p.
Ordering Samuel Russell to pay Peter Fox or contest in court. Ruling of Justice Abel Lawrence written on back. Printed form. 2 pp.
Transferring land from Ebenezer Jones to Abel Prescott. 1 p.
Ordering George Hewitt to pay Edward Gary or contest in court. Ruling of Justice Abel Lawrence written on back. Printed form. 2 pp.
Court settlement ordering George Hewitt to pay Edward Gary. Issued by Justice Abel Lawrence. Printed form. 1 p.
ALS from Isaac Goodwin to John Locke requesting a continuance in a court case. 1 p.
Two printed forms filled in with measurements and value of land owned by Daniel Raymond. Attached to one is an 1850 death notice for John Raymond. 1 p. each.
Two printed forms filled in with valuations of household furniture kept by Daniel Raymond. One is undated. On two small slips of paper.
ALS from Rowland Freeman of Lewiston, ME to John Locke of Ashby, MA. Concerning some business with wood and till. 1 p.
Printed form filled out by John Locke on behalf of Liberty Wellington acknowledging tax on her chaise and harness. 1 p.
ALS from James Humphreys to John Locke regarding a certificate for a Mr. Robbins. 1 p.
Transferring land from Amos & Ephraim Meriam to Abel Prescott. 1 p.
Transferring land from Elihu Penniman to Abel Prescott. Printed form. 1 p.
Between brothers Thomas & Isaac Woodbury. 1 p.
ALS from Marshall Preston to John Locke. Writes about both American and English politics, specifically mentioning allied powers and British Prime Minister (George) Canning. 3 pp.
Issued to William Dudley, Trustee of Roxbury, for repaying part of a loan. On a small slip of paper.
From William Shirley, Governor of Massachusetts, to Paymaster General of his Majesty's Land Forces demanding money for troops who served in an expedition against Canada under General Waldo. 2 pp.
Printed form signed by Boston Town Clerk Ezekiel Goldthwait announcing the marriage of Thomas Greenleaf and Mehetable Harris. On a small slip of paper.
Tax assessment for William Wane, issued by collector Sampson Salter. Printed form. On a small slip of paper.

DS, Boston. From the Committee of Donations of Boston to the Committee of Correspondence of Glastonbury, CT. Thanking them for their sympathy and generosity in supporting Boston. Signed by Henry Hill. With a copy of the Glastonbury Committee letter of June 23, 1774. 3 pp. total.

A printed pass issued by the Boston Committee of Donations to Nathan Spear and his family of four, who are leaving the town of Boston. Recommending them to the selectmen of the towns of Massachusetts, asking for the "charity and assistance of our benevolent sympathizing brethren." Signed by Edward L. Sanders, Clerk. Half leaf.
The items were once owned by Republican Institution subscriber George Homer.
Printed letter announcing a general meeting. Signed by Secretary Thaddeus Page. 1 p.
Printed letter announcing an upcoming meeting for subscribers. 1 p.
Printed letter calling a meeting, with proposed by-laws. 3 pp.
Certifying George Homer as a subscriber to the Republican Institution. 2 pp.
Printed form filled in with measurement and value of land owned by Nathan Raymond. 1 p.
Binding Robert Andrews to pay Jonathan French, signed 1748. In 1752, French signed the money over to Jonathan Wood (written on back). 2 pp.
From Daniel Bullard to Caleb Strong, Governor of the Commonwealth of Massachusetts, resigning as Coroner of Worcester County and recommending a replacement. 1 p.
A 1747 copy of a 1744 Brookline town ruling vetoing a highway. 1 p.
List of names and amounts taxed Brookline residents for Highway Rate. Sent by town assessors to William Ackers, Surveyor of Highways. 2 pp.
Sent by Jonathan Harris to the Colony of Massachusetts Bay for boarding destitute widow Rebekah Vaughn of Boston. 1 p.
Muster-Master of Suffolk County registering Asaph Bisbee for one year service. Printed form. 1 p.
Ordering William Barrit to pay Zechariah Parker or contest in court. Printed form. 1 p.
Deed between Robert Elmes and Benjamin Stutson for house in Cohasset. Printed form. 1 p.
Ruling by Justice Abel Lawrence in case of Ephraim Ware v. Mary Patterson for nonpayment of physician's fees. 1 p.

Printed letter decrying "venal presses" accompanied by ALS from Shilborn Whitman to George Partridge (former Massachusetts Congressional Representative) asking him to help protect the Commonwealth by battling bad press. 2 pp.
Transferring land from John Lane to Joshua Woodbury. 1 p.
Printed form letter granting John Wheelwright administrative rights over the estate of his late uncle, John Jordan. 1 p.
Printed form filled in with Stephen Nelson Rowley's State, County & Town taxes for 1815. On a small slip of paper.

Three individuals are prominent within the Groton town file: James Brazer, John Loring, and Abel Lawrence. Due to volume, Lawrence's papers have been separated and arranged chronologically in a second folder.
List of money owed Zechariah Wethe for services rendered to Widow Hepsibah Warren. 1 p.
Printed form filled in by James Brazer acknowledging the yearly tax on his chaise. 1 p.
Printed form filled in by James Brazer acknowledging the yearly tax on his phaeton. 1 p.
Printed form filled in with measurements and value of land owned by James Brazer. 1 p.
Printed form filled in with measurements and value of land owned by Jonathan Loring. 1 p.
Printed form filled in by Jonathan Loring on behalf of Ezra Farnsworth acknowledging yearly tax on Farnsworth's chaise. 1 p.
Printed form filled in by Jonathan Loring acknowledging the yearly tax on his chaise. 1 p.
Printed form filled in by Sampson Wood acknowledging the yearly tax on his chaise. 1 p.
ALS from Bradford Russell to John Locke expressing thanks and giving news of Groton including a religious controversy and the suicide of Colonel Sampson Wood (see also: Pepperell file). 1 p.
Two identical newspaper clippings announcing Jonathan Loring's death and bequests.
ALS from Joshua Green to S(amuel) G(ardner) Drake (author of History of Boston,1852) regarding historical research. 1 p.
Book review from The New York Tribune in which James Brazer of Groton is mentioned.
Printed form filled in with valuation of household furniture kept by James Brazer. Probable date circa 1814. 1 p.
Printed form filled in with valuation of household furniture kept by Jonathan Loring. 1 p.
Printed broadside for Benjamin P. Dix's store in Groton, Mass. Crossed out type suggests it was switched from a drug store to a shoe store. 1 p.

Various papers issued by and to Justice of the Peace Abel Lawrence including many writs involving various residents of Groton. Almost all the writs require one party to pay another party or contest in court. Most have notes and final judgments written on the back. All writs are half leaf printed forms with names and specifics filled in by hand.
Issued to Lawrence by Jo. Read detailing fees, payments, and balance due for work related to court cases. 1 p.
Josiah Farwell to pay Timothy Heald. 1 p.
Copy of receipt issued to Josiah Farwell. 1 p.
From Sarah Marteen (or Martin) to Abel Lawrence requesting a promissory note left in his care. 1 p.
Note signed by William Little concerning a receipt issued to Josiah Farwell. 1 p.
Court bill in case of Abel Fox v. William Russell. 1 p.
Isaiah Holden to pay William Wulling. 1 p.
Court settlement ordering William Spaulding (or Spalding) to pay Silas Parkhunt. 1 p.
John Stone to pay William Little. 1 p.
Hepsibah Warren to pay Zechariah Wethe. 1 p.
Oliver Farnsworth to pay William Little (copy 1 of 2). 1 p.
Oliver Farnsworth to pay William Little (copy 2 of 2). 1 p.
Solomon Farnsworth to pay William Little. 1 p.
Court settlement ordering Shattuck Blood to pay Israel Hobart. 1 p.
David Keemp (or Kemp) to pay Amos Holdin. 1 p.
Abel Parker to pay Jabez Keep. 1 p.
Ruling in case of Farnsworth v. Trowbridge. 1 p.
Phineas Butler to pay John Gragg. Note reads that Lawrence gave judgment on January 15, 1770. 1 p.
Statement of money owed Cotton Proctor by Isaac Nutting for fabric purchased. Note reads that Lawrence gave judgment on the account January 29, 1770. 1 p.
Isaac Nutting to pay Cotton Proctor. 1 p.
Addressed to six men requiring them to appear in case of Francis Mitchell v. Joseph Page. Signed on back by each of the men. 2 pp.
Account of various promissory notes issued by Lawrence. 1 p.
Bill from Thad. Mason to Captain Abel Lawrence. 1 p.
Settling accounts between Abel Lawrence and Thomas Little. 1 p.
Statement of money owed Lawrence by Peter Wright. 1 p.
Receipt from Nathaniel Appleton "Continental Loan Officer, in the State of Massachusetts" given to Oliver Smith of Hadley. Printed form. 1 p.
Copy of entry written by Edw. Barnard, pastor of First Church in Haverhill, recording church's vote to dismiss and recommend Jonathan & Elizabeth Sawyer to a new church in Atkinson. 1 p.
Binding Robt. Garnett to pay Peter Tour. 1 p.
Copy of entry from Hingham town records describing the land owned by the late John Thaxter. Attested by Town Clerk Benjamin Cushing. 1 p.
ALS from John Stone to Mr. Fleet, requesting he publish a rebuttal to a false and scurrilous piece written by Ephraim Littlefield. 2 pp.
Printed form letter filled out by Thomas Berry, Judge of the Probate of Wills, granting Sarah Fuller administrative rights over the estate of her late husband, William Fuller. 1 p.
Unfinished letter regarding a Mr. Norris and a new edition of tunes. Writer and recipient not specified in author's hand, but penciled note reads "Joseph Dana, Ipswich." 2 pp.
Order of Exercises at the Ipswich Washingtonian Celebration. Includes lyrics to an original temperance hymn. Printed by S.N. Dickinson, Boston. 1 p.
Sent by Assessors of Leicester to Harrison Gray, Province Treasurer, giving account of taxes levied. 1 p.
Clipping of death notice of Thomas & Samuel Denny, two of the Leicester town assessors (see above item).
Copy of letter sent to Selectmen of the towns of Leicester and Sheffield regarding which town should count Aaron Root, Jr., a recently returned Continental soldier, in its quota. 1 p.

Issued by the Commonwealth of Massachusetts commissioning William Henshaw as a Justice of the Peace for Worcester County. Printed form. Signed by John Avery, Jr., Secretary, and John Hancock, Governor. On back is handwritten acknowledgement that Henshaw appeared before Lieutenant Governor S(amuel) Adams. 1 p.
ALS from Thomas Jackson to Samuel A. Allen, Public Store Keeper, requesting the bearer of the letter be entrusted with a box addressed to Jackson. 1 p.

File contains writs and judgments issued by Justice of the Peace Abel Lawrence involving various residents of Littleton, notably the Russell and Fox families. Each writ requires one party to pay another party as a result of a court settlement. Recipients acknowledged payment on back. All writs are half leaf printed forms with names and specifics filled in by hand.
Signed by Nathanial Russell acknowledging money received from James Stevens via Justice Abel Lawrence. 1 p.
Solomon Farnsworth to pay Benjamin Hutchins. Note reads that Lawrence gave judgment on March 11, 1765. 1 p.
William Russell to pay Nathan Proctor. 1 p.
William Russell to pay Sarah Fox. 1 p.
William Russell to pay Sarah Fox. 1 p.
William Russell to pay Sarah Fox. 1 p.
William Russell to pay Sarah Fox. 1 p.
William Russell to pay Sarah Fox. 1 p.
William Russell to pay Samuel Preston. 1 p.
Isaac Russell to pay William Russell. 1 p.
Ephraim Corey to pay William Russell. 1 p.
William Russell to pay Timothy Fox. 1 p.
William Russell to pay Timothy Fox. 1 p.
Isaac Russell to pay Oliver Prescott. 1 p.
Samuel Russell to pay Peter Fox. Note reads that Lawrence gave judgment on June 27, 1768. 1 p.
Oliver Hartwell to pay James Reed. 1 p.
Ordering Thad. Mason to pay Pearson Eaton or contest in court. Issued by Abel Lawrence. Printed form. 1 p.
ALS from Otis Rockwood, Pastor of First Congregational Church of Christ in Lynn, Mass., recommending George Martin to a new congregation. 1 p.
Receipt for George Martin's payment of his daughter's tuition. Signed Jacob Batchelder. 1 p.
ALS from J.C. Stickney, on behalf of the Key Stone Club of Lynn, inviting the Boston branch of the club to a Democratic Demonstration. 1 p.
Reverend in Lynn, MA. ALS from P. Cooke to Reverend Dr. Felt about subscribers to a Review and an upcoming meeting. 1 p.
Handwritten poem entitled "But." Penciled on back is note that was written by Warren Newhall and read at the Alliance Club. 2 pp.

Official communication between the towns of Marblehead and Newbury Port planning a meeting to protest the enactment of "oppressive acts" by Parliament. Signed Benjamin Boden, Town Clerk of Marblehead and John Gerry, Clerk of Newbury Port. 2 pp.
ALS signed by ministers William Balch, Abner Bayley, and Samuel Williams approving and recommending Stephen Peabody as an occasional preacher. 1 p.
Deed of Joseph Billing of Milton, relinquishing rights to his father's estate. 1 p.
Receipt from Nathaniel Appleton, Commissioner of Loans for State of Massachusetts, given to Abel Alleyne. Printed form. 1 p.
ALS from William Garritt to Benjamin Austin (Commissioner of Loans for Boston) requesting Austin forward an affidavit to Washington. 1 p.
Issued by Judith Bradbury to the Province of Massachusetts Bay for boarding William Tumey in the weeks before his death. 1 p.
ALS from Dan Killam to Doctor W. Stearns. Letter originally sent with twelve pounds spirit of vitriol. 1 p.

From Daniel Hathorne to William Harns. 1 p.
Issued by Enos Briggs to Elias H(asket) Derby (prominent New England merchant) for settling account balance. Later note on back gives brief history of Briggs. 1 p.

Part of a deed signed by Charles & Mehetable Cleveland and Justice Amos Choate. 1 p. (torn).

Announcement transmitted by the Boston Committee of Correspondence asking for aid and support for the inhabitants of Boston who find themselves "in the front rank of the conflict" [with the British government]. Signed by William Cooper, Town Clerk. 1 p. addressed to the Selectmen of Milton.

Issued by the Committee of Correspondence for Boston. Outlining various grievances against Great Britain and a plan to affect her "trade and interest" so deeply as to "induce her to withdraw her oppressive hand." Asking every province to join them. Signed William Cooper, Town Clerk. 2 pp. addressed to the town clerk of Milton.

Circular letter issued by the Committee of Correspondence for Boston. Concerning a covenant not to purchase goods from Great Britain or engage in business with anyone who does. Signed William Cooper, Town Clerk. 1 p. addressed to the Selectmen of Milton.
Circular letter issued by the Committee of Correspondence of Worcester concerning an agreement not to purchase imported goods. Signed William Young, Chairman. 1 p.
"In Provincial Congress, Watertown." Two resolves of April 23 and May 9 respectively, requiring towns to furnish their soldiers with a blanket and firearms. 1 p.

Asking the towns of Massachusetts to send salt pork, beans, peas, vinegar, and blankets to the magazine at Watertown for the subsistence and comfort of the soldiers. Send by David Cheever per order of the Committee of Supplies. 1 p. addressed to the Selectmen of Reading.

"In Provincial Congress, Watertown." Two resolves, one demanding 13,000 coats for Massachusetts soldiers, including a list of every town and the number of coats they are required to provide. The second recommending a ban on killing sheep or lambs as wool is anticipated to be in high demand. 1 p.
Giving further directions regarding coats for the soldiers (see above), with a postscript asking for summer clothing as well. 1 p. addressed to the Selectmen of Reading.
Resolves issued by the Massachusetts House of Representatives requiring each town to impose a draft in order to meet its specified quota of men for the Continental Army. 2 pp.
Resolves issued by the Massachusetts House of Representatives requiring towns to aid in providing much needed shoes, stockings, and shirts for soldiers. 1 p.
Issued by the Massachusetts Senate. Explaining the need for public monies and appointing commissioners in each county to assess and collect taxes. 2 pp.

A court summons directed to the coroners of Suffolk County, MA, ordering the appearance of Nathaniel Brewer to answer charges of unlawfully selling land. Signed by clerk John Ballentine and coroner Jonathan Sewall. 2 pp.

In the early 1730s, a group of Boston merchants attempted to regulate the circulation of money in Massachusetts by giving loans based on individual credit. This indenture for a bond issued to John Walley is an example of one of their loans. Printed form, signed by the ten merchants (Edward Hutchinson, John Osborne, Jacob Wendell, etc.) and witnessed by two others. 1 p.
Statement of money owed William Gamage by the Province of the Massachusetts Bay for coopering powder barrels. 1 p.
DS. Copy of resolutions of the House of Representatives of Massachusetts outlining the creation of a regiment for the defense of Boston. 3 pp.
DS. Copy of resolutions of the House of Representatives of Massachusetts with regard to the raising of militia under orders of General Washington. 3 pp.
DS. Copy of an order directing Continental Army recruits from Massachusetts to be forwarded to Rhode Island at the request of General George Washington. 1 p.

Printed note issued by the State of Massachusetts promising to pay 75 pounds to the bearer. Stamped "Advance Pay to Officers, first Moiety." Signed Treasurer H. Gardner and two committee members. 1 p.
DS. Copy of resolutions of the House of Representatives of Massachusetts regarding the movement of firearms to Springfield. 2 pp.
DS. Copy of a resolution from the House of Representatives of the State of Massachusetts Bay providing clothing and other supplies for new recruits to the Continental Army. 1 p.
Certifying John Mayhew as a member of the Middlesex Society of Husbandmen and Manufacturers (Massachusetts). 1 p.

American astronomer and naval officer. ALS, Fredericksburg, VA. To Messrs. Hilliard, Gray & Co, booksellers in Boston. Outlining a book he has written on mathematics and navigation, asking whether they might publish it. 3 pp. with a contemporary clipping giving a brief biography of Maury.
Union general during the American Civil War. Letters filed by recipient.
ALS, Washington. Recommending Major John Oakes be promoted to Inspector General with the rank of Colonel. 1 p.
ALS, Cincinnati. Marked "Personal." Requesting specific officers to be placed under his command and a supply of arms to be sent to Ohio so the troops will be ready to take the field. 2 pp.
Copy of a telegram announcing victory at Forts Clark and Hatteras; asking that the news be shared with the command. 1 p.
American politician and professor at Princeton University. ALS, Princeton. To Peniton Maxwell. Refusing to comply with an unspecified request. 1 p.
