American statesman. ALS, Pittsburgh. To W[illiam] P[itt] Fessenden. Giving his opinion of the high price of gold and suggesting governmental action to stabilize currency. 4 pp.

ALS, Fishkill. To [New York] Governor [George] Clinton. Discussing his command of last winter and the impact of shortages of food and clothing on the morale of the troops. Asking permission for some goods to be delivered to his wife. 7 pp.
American statesman, U.S. secretary of war from 1796-1800. Letters filed by recipient.
ALS (draft), Middlebrook. Agreeing to put aside a disagreement, praising the work and character of George Washington, and discussing his desire to retire to a private life. 4 pp.
ALS (draft). Discussing peace negotiations, the stance of various European powers, and his political service. 3 pp.
Letters directed to the accountant of the War Department.
LS. Requesting a statement of expenditures. 1 p.
LS. Giving his opinion that it is reasonable for the public to pay for the table and forage of commanding generals provided they have the proper receipts and documentation. 3 pp.
American Revolutionary officer.
ALS, Augusta. To [Benjamin] Lincoln. Reporting on local engagements, the arrival of two Indian delegates, enemy movements near Savannah, and the results of meetings of the Council. 1 p.
DS. Weekly return of the first brigade commanded by McIntosh. 1 p.
Served as twenty-fifth President of the United States (1897-1901).
Filed by recipient.
TLS, Canton, Ohio. Saying that he has not heard directly from a Mr. Medill. 1 p.
LS, Washington, D.C. Promising to forward information about a pension claim. 1 p.
ALS, Canton, Ohio. Thanking Casselman for a remittance of $100. 1 p.
ALS, Canton, Ohio. To the President. Recommending Walter Chance, formerly a law student in his office, for a commission as 2nd lieutenant in the army. 2 pp.
LS, Washington, D.C. Accepting an invitation to attend a banquet of the Ohio Society in New York. 1 p.
LS, Washington, D.C. Declining an invitation to attend a banquet of the Ohio Society in New York. 1 p.
TLS, Columbus, Ohio. Thanking Plunkett for a letter and saying he may be able to arrange a visit in May. 1 p.
LS, Canton, Ohio. Recommending Wyman communicate with the Charmain of the State Committee to learn when McKinley will make a campaign stop in his area. 2 pp.
TLS, Columbus, Ohio. Thanking Wyman for congratulations on the election. 1 p.
ADS. A legal petition drawn up by McKinley as attorney for plaintiff, N. Seckler. 1 p.
DS. Appointing Vaugh E. Wyman notary public. Signed by McKinley as Governor of Ohio. Printed certificate. 2 pp.
DS. Appointing William Henry Forwood as Assistant Surgeon General with rank of Colonel. Printed certificate signed by McKinley as President and Russell A. Alger as Secretary of War. 1 p.
Signed photograph of McKinley.

American army commander. Two ALsS on one page, one by Meade and one by Medical Director John P. Milnau, both recommending Miss Jane B. Moore and her mother, who proved themselves by helping wounded soldiers at Antietam. 1 p.
American politician. ALS, Marietta. To George Simpson, Cashier of the Bank of the United States. Ordering him to pay Dudley Woodbridge his judge's salary of $200. 1 p.
American soldier and politician. DS. Commission appointing "Justices of the Levy" for Anne Arundel County Maryland. Signed by Mercer (as Governor of Maryland) and Alexander C. Hanson. 1 p.

James Monroe (1758-1831) was an American politician who served in various high-ranking government positions including governor of Virginia, secretary of war, secretary of state, and fifth president of the United States (1817-1825). He is known for his influence on U.S. foreign policy, most notably through the Monroe Doctrine (1823), which opposed the interference of any European powers in the affairs of newly independent nations of the Western hemisphere. His letters in this collection reflect his involvement in international diplomacy as he wrote to and about various U.S. foreign ministers and affairs of state. Also included are a handful of letters dealing with his personal life and estate, which highlight financial difficulties and the sale of property in Europe and America. Miscellaneous documents at the end include a couple of speeches. [Some of the information provided in this finding aid was verified using: Preston, Daniel. A Comprehensive Catalogue of the Correspondence and Papers of James Monroe (Westport, CT: Greenwood Press, 2001). ]
Filed by recipient.
ALS, Paris. To the American chargÃ© dâ€™affaires at the Hague. Introducing a Mr. Wilcocks of Philadelphia. 1 p.
ALS, London. To the American Minister at Paris. Introducing the Margravine of Anspach [Elizabeth Berkeley Craven], "distinguished for her attention & kindness to Americans." 2 pp.

LS, Department of State. To the U.S. Minister to France. 2 pages in undeciphered code, the rest instructing the Minister to complain to the French government about the seizure and burning of several American vessels. 4 pp. total.

ALS, Albemarle. To the Vice President of the United States. Introducing Dr. [Charles] Everett; discussing his [Monroe's] decision to retire and devote time to his family, with assurances that he is still invested in the welfare of the country. 1 p.

did.unittitle: Collector at the Port of Philadelphia

scopecontent.p: Circular LS, Department of State. Asking the collector to survey local insurance companies for information on the seizure of American vessels by European governments, providing a form to be followed in reply. 2 pp.

ALS, Richmond. Concerning a financial arrangement involving William Nelson, the possibility of Coxe buying shares in the James River Company, and a letter to be forwarded by Colonel [Edward] Carrington. 2 pp.
ALS. Promising to make a payment. 1 p.

LS, Department of State. Marked "Triplicate." Sending credentials for Crawford so he can be appear legitimate before "the new sovereign of France" [Louis XVIII], and asking him to forward dispatches to the U.S. ministers engaged in negotiations with Great Britain. 1 p.

ALS. Requesting an opinion from Dallas and Benjamin Crowninshield on a letter received from George Erving [concerning Luis de Onis], with a postscript about forcing Spain to yield to just demands. 1 p.

LS, Department of State. Giving detailed instructions for Everett to deliver dispatches to American ministers abroad, with mention that he may be considered for the office of chargÃ© dâ€™affaires in Holland once [William] Eustis steps down. 2 pp.
ALS, Albemarle. Explaining his failure to visit Everett's home, mentioning a proposed visit by [Albert] Gallatin, and addressing some mutual business. 2 pp.

ALS, Washington. Concerning his frustrations with his brother, Joseph, who plans to move his family to the Mississippi Territory. Asking Everett to advance $100 to his brother, declaring that it is the last help he will ever give him. 3 pp.
ALS, Washington. To the U.S. Consul at Cadiz. Introducing Thomas S. Mercer, son of Colonel John Francis Mercer of Maryland. 1 p.
ALS, in third person. Sending a copy of a song and a speech [not included], hoping they will entertain her as she travels through "rugged country." 1 p.
ALS (draft), London. Lengthy letter about the difficulties of signing the treaty for the purchase of Louisiana and the possible effect of an outbreak of war between France and England. 11 pp.
LS, Richmond. Urging the employment of a young Mr. Camp of Culpepper, whose intentions and character are verified by a number of Virginia sponsors, including [Thomas] Jefferson. 1 p.
ALS, Oak Hill. Saying he and his wife are both sick, with a postscript suggesting that he and Madison should not bother to address "the question suggested from Baltimore." 1 p .

AL (draft), Richmond. Explaining the depleted state of his finances and a plan to sell his London property to pay off debts, mentioning his recent appointment as Secretary of State, and asking Mason to send some poplars for his plantation. 2 pp.
ALS. Asking him to aid a Mr. Brown, recommended by Commodore Porter, who requires a vessel and some other articles. 1 p.

ALS, Washington. Marked "Confidential." Including a lengthy discussion of Mercer's son, who is serving as [Winfield] Scott's secretary while Scott is in Europe, with reference to Monroe's own service in the Department of War and his objections to the Federalist party. 4 pp.
LS, Department of State. Asking Mitchell to facilitate a shipment of wine and other goods for the Russian Minister, Mr. Daschkoff. 1 p.
ALS, Druid Hill. Declining to attend a celebration in Baltimore of the (July) revolution in France due to ill health, with praise for Lafayette. 2 pp.

LS with autograph subscription, London. Marked "Duplicate." Reporting on his concluding a contract with the house of Sir Francis Baring & Co. for the sale of Maryland's stock in the Bank of England. 2 pp.

LS, Paris. To the U.S. Secretary of State. Marked "No. 30." Explaining how he is handling complaints by the French government about America's treaty with England, mentioning the resignation of Pichegru, and expressing his belief that a plan to issue paper mandats in place of French assignats will undoubtedly fail. 3 pp.
ALS, Paris. Asking Pinckney to return a letter written by Thomas Paine, as it may contain material derogatory to the Jay Treaty. 2 pp.
ALS, Oak Hill. Urging publication of the committee report regarding his claim for compensation for diplomatic service; wishing Poinsett success in his mission to Mexico. 2 pp.
ALS, Aranjuez [Spain]. Urging the diplomat to resign his post to [William George] Erving, consul at London, in the event that ill health makes it impossible to carry on business. 3 pp.

ALS, Paris. To the Consul for the United States at Paris. Arranging for the purchase of books for the U.S. Department of War to help train officers in fortification and engineering, with mention that they should be paid for with a combination of assignats and specie. 1 p.
ANS. Asking Skipworth to get him a passport from Cambaceres, which must be signed by Napoleon, in order that Monroe may go to England. 1 p.
ALS, Aranjuez [Spain]. Awaiting the return of Captain Dalton from Paris with maps and papers; happy to hear his daughter is well. 1 p.
ALS, Washington. To the President of the Maryland Agricultural Society. Refusing to attend an exhibition of 2 pp.

ALS, Oak Hill. Expressing concerns over the upcoming sale of his land in Albemarle and therefore asking Swann, a lawyer, to attend the sale and ensure the interests of Monroe and the bank are met. 2 pp.

ALS, Oak Hill. Planning for the sale of his land in Albemarle to satisfy his debt to the Bank of the United States; suggesting Charlottesville in July as an acceptable place and time for the sale. 1 p.

ALS, Richmond. Lengthy letter giving his views on Jefferson's administration and the quarrels within the Republican party, his reception on his return from abroad as contrasted with Jefferson's treatment of him, political conditions, etc. 11 pp.
ALS, Oak Hill, Virginia. On Smith's acceptance of an appointment to the Supreme Court. 1 p.
ALS, Philadelphia. Agreeing to obtain passage and a passport for a vessel. 1 p.
LS, Paris. First paragraph written in code (with deciphering above). Reporting on his negotiations with the French Directory and conditions in France and various European countries. 3 pp.

ALS, Richmond. Concerning the biased attitude of a Washington paper against the Republican party, the repeal [of the Judiciary Act], national finances, the European political situation, and other bits of political news. 2 pp.
ALS, Oak Hill. Concerning the duties of Com. [Charles] Morris, who is to combine political duties with his naval post so he can effectively combat piracy and slave trade. 1 p.

ALS, Washington. Marked "Confidential." Concerning [Telaforo] Orea, a Venezuelan diplomat; saying Orea conducted himself well despite the fact that the U.S. refused to recognize the Venezuelan government. 2 pp.
ALS. Asking his correspondent to read some enclosed papers [not included] concerning the Cherokees and Georgia representatives. 2 pp.
ALS, Oak Hill. Writing in confidence on the delicate international situation provoked by Com. [David] Porter's activities with the Mexican Navy. 3 pp.
Arranged chronologically.

Ms with ANS, Paris. Speech to the French National Convention in which Monroe accepts his role as U.S. Minister to France and encourages friendship and unity between the two countries. Signed as Minister Plenipotentiary. 3 pp.

DS. Printed instructions "to the public and private armed vessels of the United States" ordering them to aid any U.S. vessels traveling from British ports and carrying British cargo, since the British Orders in Council have "allegedly" been repealed. Marked "No. 218." Signed by Monroe as Secretary of State. 1 p.
DS, on vellum, signed also by B[enjamin] W[illiam] Crowninshield. Appointing William G. Woolsey as midshipman in the U.S. Navy. 1 p.
DS, on vellum. Also with signature of John Quincy Adams. For the Carrier of New London, master John Deshon. 1 p.
AMs excerpt from Monroe's message to Congress given on December 7, 1824, on national finances and public credit. 1 p.
Colonial governor of New York and New Jersey (1728-1731). DS. Proclaiming a one day prorogation of the New York assembly. 2 pp.
American clergyman. ADS, Camp Smith's Clove. Written testimony of a verbal disagreement between General [William] Smallwood and a Mr. Hurt, over the right to pass through certain fields. 2 pp.
Colonial governor of New York (1765-1769). ALS, London. [To his brother-in-law?]. Concerning the appointment of a Mr. Jones to the engineer corps and a debt Moore is owed. 3 pp.
American Revolutionary soldier. ADS. Discharge for John Collet, who found "a good and able bodied man" to take his place in his regiment. 1 p.
American financier. ALS, New York. To [Alexander?] Holly. Answering a letter concerning where he purchased gilt brass bedsteads and giving family news. 2 pp.
American statesman. Letters filed by recipient.
ALS, Paris. Concerning a cargo of tobacco and the wheat crop in America. 3 pp.

ALS, Philadelphia. Saying that he has written General [George] Washington that the army should be divided and that he wishes Washington would come to Philadelphia to quiet concerns and thereby improve the public welfare. 1 p.
American statesman. ALS, "Camp 18 miles from Four Holes." To Nathanael Greene. Congratulating Greene on a successful maneuver against the enemy and sending news from various parts of the war. 2 pp.
American politician and financier, signer of the Declaration of Independence. Morris privately funded portions of the Revolutionary War, and was influential in the establishment of a national bank.
Filed by recipient.
Secretary of the Marine Committee.
ALS, Manheim. Confirming the receipt of papers, offering to send money, and sending love to his son, "Bob". 1 p.
ALS, Manheim. Concerning embarrassing actions by his [step]brother [Thomas, commercial agent at Nantes], plans to meet up with his son, and various financial dealings. 3 pp.
ALS, Manheim. Denouncing his [step]brother's behavior and planning to balance various accounts. 1 p. with an additional half page note in a clerk's hand concerning an error in Brown's account.

ALS, Manheim. Thanking him for papers, promising to forward a letter from the Governor of New Orleans, and asking Brown to help him secure some pistol powder. 1 p. with an additional half page note in a clerk's hand asking for ink powder as well.
ALS, Manheim. Asking about the availability of blistered steel and promising to send money to a Mr. Helligass. 1 p.
ALS, Manheim. Concerning various accounts, storing wine and salt, measles infection in his family, and enclosing letters to be forwarded [not included]. 2 pp.
ALS, Manheim. Concerning the price and shipment of various goods including salt, wine, tobacco, and hemp. 2 pp.
ALS, Manheim. Forwarding a letter from Samuel Chew and some papers from the Secret Committee; arranging for wine to be sent to various persons. 1 p.
ALS, Manheim. Mentioning the unfortunate loss of a Virginia frigate, a shipment of beef, and the purchase of multiple bills to be paid to various people. 2 pp.
ALS, Manheim. Forwarding letters for the Marine and Commercial Committees, giving directions for the shipment of rice and indigo, and mentioning Captain Pickles aboard the Schooner Lewis. 2 pp.

ALS, Manheim. Asking Brown to handle some financial business, wondering why Mr. Ross has not provided directions for goods he ordered, and requesting that his letters be sent by a different route so he might receive them sooner. 2 pp.

ALS, Manheim. Giving direction for financial transactions between the Secret Committee and Messrs. Babcock and Griffin, sending news that Captain Brown of the Henrietta was forced to throw his dispatches overboard to keep them from the enemy, and giving news of Mr. Ross' dealings in Europe and the West Indies. 2 pp.
ALS, Manheim. Arranging for various financial transactions and requesting a shipment of black pepper. 1 p.
ALS, Manheim. Arranging for various financial transactions. 1 p.

LS, Office of Finance. By order of the Board of War, authorizing the sale of command stores at Rhode Island, the proceeds from which will go towards discharging drafts and outfitting frigates Alliance and Deane. 1 p.

LS, Office of Finance. Enclosing a resolution [not included] regarding a settlement with the Board of War of Massachusetts, with mention of arbitration between a Portuguese vessel and a privateer. 1 p.
LS, Office of Finance. Arranging for the payment of freight imported from Spain by Josiah Batchelor. 2 pp.
LS, Office of Finance. Asking for more information about surplus stores in Boston and other eastern ports. 1 p.
LS, Office of Finance. Asking him to pay some bills for Colonel [Charles] Armand, Marquis De La Rouerie, Commander of a Legionary Corps in the service of the United States. 1 p.
LS, Office of Finance. Authorizing the sale of any surplus stores left over after outfitting vessels in Boston, with the exception of copper, which should be kept and stored. 1 p.

LS, Office of Finance. Asking Brown to quickly resolve some business with a Mr. F, to pay the wife of Major General [Benjamin] Lincoln, and send copper via Captain S. Nicholson's ships if convenient. 1 p.

LS, Office of Finance. Directing Brown to deliver articles to Major Hodgson, anticipating the sale of goods to the public, hoping difficulties with the Navy Board can be smoothed over, arranging for copper to be delivered to the army, and mentioning a bill for Monsr. Bouldasky. 2 pp.
LS, Office of Finance. Arranging to pay Isaac Smith, owner of the schooner Hawke, and handle some bills drawn on Holland. 2 pp.
LS, Office of Finance. Discussing various business concerning the marines, with mention that Captain James Nicholson has requested command of the Deane. 1 p.
LS, Office of Finance. Asking Brown to forward a copy of the proceedings of the court martial at Boston in the case of three men from the frigate Alliance, who have been sentenced to death. 1 p.
LS, Office of Finance. Enclosing announcements for contracts to be printed in various newspapers [enclosures not included]. 1 p.
LS, Office of Finance. Concerning the brigantine Navarre, with a warning to Mr. Langdon not to issue any more notes at a discount. 1 p.
ALS, Philadelphia. Asking Brown not to sell some bills and sympathizing with Brown over his dispute with Messrs. Warren & Vernon. 1 p.
LS, Office of Finance. Concerning business with Messrs. J. L. & L. Le Couteulx and shipments to and from Havana. 3 pp.
ALS, Philadelphia. Discussing a new crop of troubles just when he cleared himself of the last, mentioning Constable's brother's sale of land. 1 p.

ALS, Philadelphia. To James and William Constable. Asking them to handle entry of goods on board his ship Superb, some of which are to be delivered to Gouverneur Morris, with mention of some drafts in favor of [Albert] Gallatin. 3 pp.
LS, Philadelphia. Reminding them that discounts from the bank are extremely rare and they are expected to make their payments on time. 1 p.

ALS, Philadelphia. Chastizing them for poor communication and asking that they give him an explicit statement of his account in the future, mentioning ships Virginia, Empress of China, and Comte d'Atrois, as well as his agent, Furman. 5 pp.
ALS, Philadelphia. Mentioning various accounts by name and lamenting that money is so scarce. 2 pp.
ALS, Philadelphia. On financial commitments with a postscript saying "all the adventurers in tobacco are terrible disappointed." 1 p.
LS, Philadelphia. Introducing John Brown, who is to negotiate $200,000 worth of bills at Havana, mentioning that the U.S. and Cuba share a "common enemy." 2 pp.
ALS, Office of Finance. To the Governor of Delaware. Arranging for the payment of supplies. 1 p.
ALS, Philadelphia. About getting a loan from Dutch bankers for Greene and the necessity of paying the public debt, mentioning Rhode Island in particular. 3 pp.

ALS, Philadelphia. Asking whether he might forward a previous letter from Law to the President, discussing some unspecified complaints and charges, with mention of the "business of the Federal City." 2 pp.

ALS, signed also by John Nixon. To both Mathews and William C. Houston. Saying Nixon has been appointed to settles charges of salvage for the ship Henry; giving the most equitable manner of the settling the business. 1 p.

ALS, Richmond. To his wife, "Molly." Promising to do all in his power to mitigate recent financial losses, mentioning visits to the Byrd and Griffin families, and planning to send for their sons to come home from Europe in March. 4 pp.
Comptroller General of Pennsylvania.
ALS. Asking Nicholson to discount a note for $6000 and commenting on Nicholson's refusal to allow interest in another transaction. 1 p.
ALS. Asking Nicholson to read an enclosure [not included] and stop by Morris' office before the evening to discuss it. 1 p.
LS, Philadelphia. Thanking Pemberton for acting as one of the referees in a cross action between John Holker and himself. 2 pp.
ALS, Philadelphia. Asking him to forward a letter and referring to the difficulty of raising money for army payments. 1 p.

DS. Printed certificate issued to John Nicholson for one share of stock in the Asylum Company, organized to buy and sell land in Pennsylvania [an early example of the use of the corporate plan for speculation on a large scale]. 4 pp.
First chief justice of New Jersey after American independence. Grandson of New Jersey Governor Lewis Morris (1671-1746) and son of Robert Hunter Morris (1713-1764).
Letters to and from Morris. Nearly all the letters to Morris contain his docketing and notes on the back. Filed by correspondent.

ALS from Morris to Lord Stirling. Giving a detailed account of the British raid under Major Ferguson on the Shrewsbury River and Tinton Manor, the defense by Colonel Ford, and Morris' personal observations during the raid. 3 pp.
ALS to Morris, Mine Brook. Refuting accusations that he took possession of a negro belonging to a Mr. Cooley of New York. 1 p.
ALS to Morris, Haddonfield. Concerning many different court cases. 3 pp.
ALS to Morris. Asking Morris to help in the case of Lieutenant Bradford, who is being punished for assaulting William McDonald. 3 pp.
Governor of New York (1777-1795)

ALS (draft) from Morris. Complaining that Israel Hedden, a resident of New Jersey, had upwards of 400 pounds of property seized in New York allegedly under the "regulating law." Questioning the legality of the seizure and asking Clinton to remedy the situation. 1 p.

AL (draft) possibly to Clinton. Complaining about the arrangement of the army and Congressional decisions as to how to provision the soldiers. On the back are some draft resolutions of "the joint committee." 2 pp.
ALS to Morris, New York. Concerning payment of interest on a note. 1 p.
ALS to Morris. Writing Morris on the recommendation of a Mr. Pettit, asking for help in his case against a Mr. Reed, late agent for the West Jersey Society. 1 p.

ALS (draft) from Morris. About protecting local property from the enemy, raising money for Congress, and the failure of men to enlist unless their own persons or property are in jeopardy. 2 pp. written on a scrap piece of paper bearing other notations.
ALS to Morris, Hillsborough. Asking Morris to help him procure a pass to New York. 1 p.
ALS to Morris. Asking Morris to call on him on his way to Trenton. 1 p.
ALS to Morris, Trenton. Apologizing that his son's illness will keep him from attending court. 2 pp.
LS to Morris, New York. Asking Morris to balance accounts by sending a remittance. 2 pp.
Congressional delegate from New Jersey.
ALS (draft) from Morris, Trenton. Notifying Fell he has been nominated and elected to be a delegate for New Jersey. 1 p.
ALs (drafts) from Morris. Three draft ALs to Fell, Mr. Morris, and Mr. [John] Jay, all introducing the newest delegate from New Jersey, [William Churchill] Houston. 1 p.
ALS (draft) from Morris. Concerning Furman's dispute with a Mr. Buck over who deserves the reward money for apprehending "the two Smiths." 2 pp.
ALS (draft) from Morris. Asking Mr. Hedden to reconsider the cases of Captains Johnson & Nutman. 1 p.

ALS (draft) from Morris. Trying to convince Colonel Holmes that the "practice of retaliation" against alleged criminals in his neighborhood is inappropriate and unlawful, especially citing the case of William Lawrence. 3 pp.
ALS to Morris, Hackettstown. Informing Morris that a Mr. Rapelje traveling to New York is believed to be conspiring with the enemy and should therefore be apprehended. 1 p.

ALS from Morris, Monmouth. Writing Jay before his departure to Europe to serve as ambassador to Spain, asking for direction on some mutual business to which Morris will attend during Jay's absence. 2 pp.
Governor of New Jersey (1776-1790)
ALS (draft) from Morris. Recommending Mrs. Rutgers and Rebecca Johnson for passes to go to New York. 1 p.

ALsS (drafts) from Morris. Two draft letters, one concerning various political and regional issues affected by the war, and the other on behalf of a group of men petitioning for the care of a poor widow. 2 pp.
LS to Morris, New York. Asking Morris to carefully convey a letter to a debtor. 1 p.
ALS (draft) from Morris. Enquiring about his future political career, asking him to attend the Supreme Court at Trenton to see how it operates, and mentioning other bits of news. 2 pp.
ALS to (Robert) Morris, Rocky Hill. Asking to be appointed Lieutenant Colonel in the New Jersey state regiment. 2 pp.
ALS to Morris. Requesting a trial date to settle his grievance against John Hall. 1 p.
ALS to Morris. Asking Morris to parole Cornelius Van Vorst & son to prevent the enemy from using them. 1 p.
ALS to Morris, Philadelphia. From the Governor of Pennsylvania. Recommending the bearer, a Mr. Marshal. 1 p.
ALS to Morris. Asking to immediately be furnished with a list of "disaffected persons" from Bergen County (NJ) who have ties to the enemy as a militia is standing by to apprehend them. 1 p.
ALS to Morris, Princeton. Offering to serve as clerk for the assembly. 2 pp.

ALS (draft) from Morris. Questioning Justice Symms for granting habeas corpus to some soldiers, warning him that he should not entangle himself with military affairs. 1 p. with unrelated notations on the back concerning a real estate law.
ALS to Morris, Middletown. Asking Morris to help a Mrs. Stevenson, whose horses and cattle were seized by Major Walton and a party of armed men. 1 p.
ALS from Morris, Hackensack. Concerning some legal business, politics in New York and New Jersey, and relations with the English. 3 pp.
ALS (draft) from Morris. Asking White to please compensate a poor widow whose grass and hay his troops used. 1 p.
ALS to Morris, Hackensack. Asking Morris to conduct some business with his father. 1 p.

Portions of two ALs. One written to "an old acquaintance" containing friendly advice and comments on politics and Congress. The other concerning legal business with mention of Justice Symms. Possible recipients include William Paterson and/or Gouverneur Morris, based on notations on the leaf. 2 pp.
Draft ALS to unknown recipient touching on various matters including the problem of depreciating paper money, taxation and provisioning of troops, and government appointments. 2 pp.

Two draft ALs. One to an unspecified general, congratulating him on a recent appointment. The other to an unnamed recipient concerning Major and Mrs. Prevost, who are affiliated with the British but sympathetic to American causes. 1 p. each.
Scrap sheet containing drafts of one AL, possibly more, discussing the condition of New Jersey battalions. 2 pp.

Handwritten copies of two essays appearing in The Whisperer, a paper published by William Moore. Labeled "No. 3" and "No. 6" respectively. Complaining about the King and legislation encroaching upon the rights of Englishmen. 7 pp. each.
Copy of a circular letter and resolves of the Continental Congress vesting General [George] Washington with power to raise more troops. Appears to be docketed in Morris' hand. 4 pp.

Handwritten copy of an article "From the Pennsylvania Packet." Consisting of an anonymous letter to Mrs. Asgill [mother of Charles Asgill, a British soldier who was sentenced to die for another man's crimes but was pardoned by the Americans at the last minute]. Complaining that the same mercy that was shown to her son was not shown to American Colonel Haynes, who was executed at the hands of the British, despite the desperate petition of the women of Charlestown, a copy of which is included. 6 pp.
Printed form granting permission for Morris to visit New York City. Issued and signed by Samuel Birch, Brigadier-General and Commandant of New York. 1 p.
Receipt issued to Silvanus Baldwin from John Croes, certifying that Polly Morris' tuition was paid. Quarter leaf.
AD. Summary of a court case involving John Duyckinck, who took an oath of allegiance to the King. With names of the jury and questions for them to address. 2 pp.
Summary of the testimony in the court case of James Montgomery v. Thomas Herlin over the seizure of goods. 3 pp.
Governor of Indiana (1861-1867) and U.S. senator. Letters filed by recipient.
LS, Indianapolis. To Colfax and the other Indiana delegates in Congress. Asking whether Indiana and other states might procure arms from the national armories. 3 pp.
ALS, Washington. To the President. Recommending Schuyler Colfax to be the next Secretary of the Interior. 1 p.

American Revolutionary General from South Carolina. ALS to General [Benjamin] Lincoln. Relating his orders to troops, saying that he can use negroes as carpenters, and referring Lincoln to Colonel Horry for information on the enemy. 1 p.
American Revolutionary War General. ALS, Cumberland Courthouse. To a general. Concerning new methods for recruiting and retaining soldiers. 1 p.

Publisher of Scientific American. ALS, New York. To the Directors of the Orphans Home. Asking them to take in the son of the destitute Mrs. Rourke, promising to make a yearly donation as long as the boy remains in their care. 2 pp.

British politician, also known a "Viscount Stormont." ALS, Paris. To [William] Eden (Lord Auckland). Discussing the war and upcoming decisions by the American Congress, as well as the treaty of alliance between France and America. 4 pp.

Virginia delegate, signer of the Declaration of Independence. ALS, York County. Certifying that Richard C. Graves acted as Commissary of Provisions in 1781 and enthusiastically and effectively provided supplies for "an almost starving army." 1 p.
Miscellaneous documents relating to citizens of New Hampshire.
ADS by minister J. Emerson attesting to the marriage of John Davis and Margaret Wright in New Castle, NH. On a small slip of paper.
Portsmouth, New Hampshire. Printed form outlining the conditions of the apprenticeship of Samuel Miller to Eliphalet Ladd to learn the art, trade, or mystery of a mariner. 1 p.
Issued by Abraham Bradley, Jr. of the General Post Office of Washington City (DC) to Thomas M. Edwards, postmaster of Keene, New Hampshire. All on small slips of paper.
To pay Isaac Hill.
To pay Jonathan Pierce [leaf is torn].
To pay Jonathan Pierce.
To pay Jonathan Pierce.
To pay William Shepherd.
On large piece of vellum, deed transferring land from Abraham & Johanna Freer to John Dies. 1 p.
Manuscript legal brief in the case of Jeremiah Hogeboom and other early settlers of Claverack, NY against "those who call themselves the Churchwardens of Claverack." 2 pp.
Document conveying land in New York from John Stockbridge to Hezekiah Howell. 2 pp.
American Revolutionary officer. ADS. A general return of the troops quartered in Philadelphia, signed as town major. 1 p.
First colonial governor of New York. DS. Deed to Jan Cloet for land in Albany. Signed also by Matthias Nicolls, Secretary. 1 p.
Colonel of the First Rhode Island Regiment during the American Revolutionary War. ADS. Return of the deficiency of men from various towns based on quotas established for the Campaign of 1782. 1 p.
American physician, served as Director of Southern Hospitals during the American Revolution and was later a member of the Rhode Island Assembly. Letters filed by recipient.

ALS, Newport. Praising the choice of [John] Jay and [Thomas] Pinckney as diplomats to Great Britain, stressing his belief that the U.S. must do all in its power to negotiate and remain at peace with "all the world," but offering his services as a doctor should war break out and a military hospital be established. 2 pp.

ALS, Newport. Thanking him for books and newspapers. Commenting that the French "are a divided people" and would do best to establish a limited monarchy "as near the American constitution as may be." 2 pp.

ALS, Newport. Expressing concerns over domestic and foreign opposition to the American government. Anticipating the creation of a general hospital to care for sick and injured soldiers, and asking Greene to recommend him to the President. 2 pp.
ALS, Newport. Commending the President's recent speech, suggesting Rhode Island as an optimal spot for Marine headquarters, sending family news, and requesting three books. 2 pp.
This file consists of letters written by and to William J.J. Scott, a pioneer who left Iowa to settle in Oregon.
ALS, Fort Des Moines to William. From his father, Levi Scott. Giving directions to his son concerning financial business involving a deed and a bond. 2 pp.

ALS, Fort Hall from William Scott. To William Butin of Burlington, Iowa. Giving a rich account of his travels west with a caravan of wagons departed from Des Moines County, Iowa. Describing traveling conditions, Indian sightings, soap & saleratus factories, natural springs, and killing buffalo. 3 pp.

ALS, Umpquaw Valley (Oregon) from William Scott. To William Butin of Burlington, Iowa. Comparing life in Oregon to life in Iowa and declaring his intention to stay in the former. Describing the pleasant weather, easy farming, and healthy people. Urging his family and friends to come to Oregon, giving directions for how to outfit their wagons and stock for the trip west. 3 pp.

American Treasury commissioner. Circular LS, signed also by Arthur Lee. To William Ellery, Commissioner of the Loan Office for Rhode Island. Requesting information on Rhode Island's policy for valuing copper coins. 1 p.
American Revolutionary statesman. ADS, Barnstable, Massachusetts. Giving Shear Jashub Bourn power of attorney for James and Joseph Otis, signed and sealed by both. 1 p.
American statesman, signer of the Declaration of Independence. ALS, Annapolis. To Captain De Barras. Asking him to return some borrowed arms to supply the militia. 1 p.
American diplomat. Letters filed by recipient.
(Godfrey Rathbone Benson)
TLS with AN, London. Requesting him to address the American Luncheon Club on the character of Abraham Lincoln. 1 p.
TLS, London. Introducing Edward T. Devine, an American social worker who desires a meeting with Lord Charnwood. 1 p.
ALS, London. Accepting an invitation to be on a committee to honor the memory of Mr. James. 1 p.
English-American political philosopher and author. Letters filed by recipient.
ALS, New Rochelle, NY. To the printer of the American Mercury. About the printing of several articles and the constitution of Connecticut, suggesting that a portion of his letter be printed. 3 pp.

ALS, Philadelphia. Concerning sundry personal business including the delivery of letters and a pair of boots, mentioning in a post script that he recently wrote the Marquis [de Lafayette]. 2 pp with small piece of address sheet.
ALS. Sending a piece on commerce for possible publication in [John] Dunlap's paper [the Pennsylvania Packet]. 1 p.

ALS, New York. To his parents. Renewing communication with his parents after ten years of silence, arranging to send them money, and telling of his property and affairs in America. Enclosed is a small newspaper clipping reporting that Congress wishes to honor Paine for his "ingenius and timely publications upon the nature of liberty and civil government." 3 pp. and clipping.
American Revolutionary officer. Letters filed by recipient.

ALS. Concerning Gray's post at Norwalk (Connecticut); instructing him to restrict travel and intelligence in and out of New York and Long Island unless it is approved by [George Washington] or another superior officer. 2 pp.
ALS, Peekskill. Expressing strong patriotic sentiments and support for the Revolution; containing accounts of various troop numbers with mention of General Howe and the capture of Philadelphia. 3 pp.
British officer in the American Revolution.

LS, Camp at Stony Point. Giving a lengthy report of the movements of British troops in the vicinity of New York City, describing the capture and fortification of Stony Point under Sir Henry Clinton, and reporting the death of Captain Fenwick. 10 pp.

LS, New York. Marked "Duplicate." Describing the unexpected capture and plundering of Stony Point by the Americans, and reporting his new post as acting Commandant of the Garrison of the City of New York. 6 pp.

Paulding was a New York militiaman who helped capture British Major John Andre, co-conspirator with Benedict Arnold. ADS. "I took Andre the 23 of September 1780 and I seen him hung October 2, 1780 for my children." On a slip of paper; very faded.

American Revolutionary officer and marshal from Rhode Island. ALS, Providence. To Benjamin Bourne. Requesting payment of jurors and officers of the federal courts in Rhode Island, remarking on the Jacobins' criticisms of [John] Jay, mentioning personal business, and complaining about marauding Algerines. 3 pp.
Lieutenant Governor of Pennsylvania. DS, on vellum. Land grant to Jacob Hendrick. 1 p.
Son of William Penn, served as proprietor of Pennsylvania. DS. Land grant for 150 acres in Newcastle County. 1 p.
Founder of Pennsylvania.
DS. Receipt for the sale of 500 acres of land in Pennsylvania. 1 p.
DS, on vellum. Indenture for the sale of 2500 acres of land in Pennsylvania to Hugh Lamb. 1 p.
DS. Receipt for the sale of 5000 acres of land in Pennsylvania to James Harrison. 1 p.
ALS. To James Logan. Asking him to aid a gentlewoman from England who has had marital difficulties and is in need of money. 2 pp.
DS. Writ ordering Thomas Landell to pay Daniel Furbush money owed for the sale of a horse or contest the debt in court. Printed form. 1 p.
Renowned U.S. Army general.
Filed by recipient.
TLS. Commending Abbott for a recent article on West Point and asking whether he might like to revisit the school and speak with some professors. 3 pp.
TLS, France. Marked "Personal." Responding to a letter concerning possible leave for two soldiers serving in Europe. 1 p.
TLS, Washington. Enclosing a Memorial Day message saluting "the Allied dead." 2 pp.
TLS, Tucson, Arizona. Discussing his writing process and giving a timeline for his composition of My Experiences in the World War. 1 p.
TLS. In reference to the possibility of his making an address at the unveiling of a war memorial tablet in Kendallville, Indiana. 1 p.

ALS, Fort Bliss, Texas. Thanking an old family friend for her sympathy at the death of his wife and children. 3 pp. with original envelope. Included is a newspaper clipping describing the fire in which they died.
ALS. Referring to a business venture in the Philippines in which he, Wilson, and Col. Hersey are interested, discussing a lumber concession, and advising an early trip to Manila. 4 pp.
TMsS, France. Statement of encouragement to the men of the American Expeditionary Forces, saying that their training and labor has not been in vain and the American people stand behind them. 1 p.
Photograph of Pershing as a general sitting outside a tent.
Autograph signature on small card.
Autograph signature on small card, mounted with clipped heading of "American Expeditionary Forces/ Office of Commander-in-Chief" letterhead.

American politician and military officer. ALS, Philadelphia. To Colonel Ephraim Bowen. Dealing with a scarcity of money and methods of financing the war, mentioning a bill drawn by General [Nathanael] Greene for $35,000. 2 pp.
American statesman. Letters filed by recipient.
Filed by recipient.

Copy of a letter sent to the U.S. Minister to France. Discussing the character of Mr. Parish, U.S. Consul at Hamburg, who has been accused of issuing false passports; promising to replace him with an American citizen as soon as a proper replacement can be found. 3 pp.
ALS, Newburgh. Giving directions for tents to be delivered to Major Platt's brigade. 1 p.
ALS, one line requesting Fisher immediately forward a letter to Governor [George] Clinton. 1 p.
ALS, War Office. Orchestrating the delivery of fresh gun powder as the previous supply was poor in quality. 1 p.

LS, Department of State. Relating the presentation of French flags to the President and Congress, reminding Monroe that the [Jay] treaty with Great Britain does not infringe or violate any agreements with France, and mentioning a peace treaty made between General Wayne and the Indian tribes northwest of the Ohio River. 3 pp.

LS (copy), Department of State. Referring to the change of consul at Hamburg, the disguising of armed vessel Les Juneaux as Le Cassius, and complaining about Monroe's conduct relative to the late treaty with Great Britain. 4 pp.
DS, Philadelphia. Passport for the armed schooner Skjoldebrands, Captain William Penrose, to travel to Algiers. In Turkish and English. 1 p.
Served as American Commissioner of Patents and charge d'affaires in Peru. ALS, Lima. To J.H. Cansten. Lamenting the state of bankruptcy and civil unrest in Peru. 3 pp.
Served as fourteenth President of the United States from 1853 to 1857.
Filed by recipient.
ALS, Andover, Mass. Concerning some personal business including the purchase of insurance and the sale and repairs of a shop Pierce owns. 3 pp.
ALS, Washington. To the U.S. Secretary of State. Enclosing his revision of the Secretary's notes on foreign affairs and asking whether it is necessary to mention Nicaragua. 3 pp.
ALS, Concord, NH. Regretting that his health prevents his acting on Seymour's suggesting, with mention of mutual friends Mr. and Mrs. Corning. 2 pp.
ALS, Washington. Introducing his friend Dr. Davis of the Marine Hospital at Chelsea, Mass., who wishes to converse with the Treasury Department official. 2 pp.
DS. Ordering the Secretary of State to affix the Seal of the United States to "a full power for Mr. Buchanan to treat with Bavaria." 1 p.
American statesman. ALS, Fort Moultrie. To General Benjamin Lincoln. A lengthy complaint of the commissary system and its failure to deliver goods. 3 pp.
Served as secretary of state and prime minister of Great Britain.

LS, Whitehall. To unspecified "Gentlemen." Writing in the King's name, ordering that an investigation be made of illicit trade in America, particularly in the region of the Mobile and Mississippi Rivers. 2 pp.
LS, Whitehall. To the Deputy Governor of Maryland [Horatio Sharpe]. Marked "Duplicate." Commanding the raising of troops and supplies for the coming campaign against the French and Indians. 5 pp.
LS, Whitehall. To the Deputy Governor of Maryland [Horatio Sharpe]. Announcing the forthcoming marriage of (George III and) Princess Charlotte of Mecklenburg Strelitz. 1 p.
American politician. ALS, New York. To an unspecified general. Discussing the upcoming presidential election mentioning [Benjamin] Harrison and [James G.] Blaine. 4 pp.
Served as eleventh President of the United States from 1845-1849.
Filed by recipient.

ALS, Columbia, Tennessee. Speaking of the Democratic party in Tennessee, the coming election of 1844 and his belief that the Democrats will be victorious, and recommending Cave Johnson as a qualified candidate for Speaker of the House. 3 pp.

ALS, Washington City. Marked "Private." Reiterating that he will not interfere with the appointment of subordinate officers in the customs, saying that he seeks to keep the entire Democratic party united, and asking about the Treasurer of the Mint. 2 pp.
ALS, Nashville. Marked "Private." Advising of his travel plans and stressing the importance of their meeting. 2 pp.
ALS, Columbia. Marked "Private." Saying that he will continue to serve in the ranks of the party if he does not get the nomination and that he is forming local Democratic associations. 2 pp.
ALS, Washington. To the Secretary of War. Asking Marcy to meet with Cadet Prince, who was recently discharged from West Point and is requesting a trial by Court Martial. 1 p.

ALS, Bedford Springs. Marked "Private." Referring to some business with [John] McKeon of New York; enclosing a newspaper clipping about fighting in Ireland and saying that he cannot take any action because of U.S. neutrality; with mention of other business and [James] Buchanan. 2 pp. plus clipping.

ALS, Washington City. Saying that he has been happy to honor Tazewell's request and arrange for the moving of Lieutenant Bradford from a "distant military station" to Norfolk, mentioning Mrs. Polk's fondness for Tazewell. 2 pp.
ALS to the Secretary of the Treasury. Asking for advice on the timing of an appointment, mentioning Mr. Bogardus of New York. 1 p.
DS. Ordering the Secretary of State to affix the Seal of the United States to a Cabinet letter addressed to the Emperor of Austria. 1 p.

French marine officer. AMs, in French. "Journal de ma Campagne commandant le Vaisseam l'llustre..." September 1788 to July 1790. Journal kept by the commander of the Ship l'Illustre, from Sept. 21, 1788 to July 19, 1790. Part I: from Toulon to Martinique and sojourn in the West Indies. Part II: Visit to the United States (1789) Chesapeake Bay, Williamsburg, Boston, Washington's visit there, audience with Washington. Part III: Return to the West Indies, beginnings of French Revolution there. Died on board his ship, July 23, 1790. 250 pp., bound.
American Revolutionary officer. LS, "Camp near Cross Roads." To an unnamed correspondent. Complaining about a lack of soldiers and cavalry, stating his belief that the enemy is about to depart. 1 p.
Connecticut lottery ticket sold "for the benefit of the College of New-Jersey." Printed. Endorsed "Mdm. Belcher" on back. On a small slip of paper.

Receipt issued to John Bayard for loaning five pounds to the trustees of the College of New Jersey [Princeton] "to be applied to the repairs of the house in which D. Smith resides." Signed Richard Stockton. On a small slip of paper mounted on cardstock.

Printed circular letter from officers of the American Whig Society of the College of New-Jersey [now Princeton], appealing to former members for donations of books and money after a fire consumed their library and all its furniture. Signed by J. Middleton. 1 p.

Manuscript circular letter from John Morin Scott and R. B. Magruder of the American Whig Society [at Princeton]. To Charles Fenton Mercer. Asking him to contribute funds for the continued rebuilding of a hall for the Society. 2 pp.
A statement from Joseph Clark, reporting his routes and expenses as he travelled to different towns soliciting subscriptions for the College of New Jersey. 2 pp.

Printed broadside "To the Public" from "The Students of Princeton College..." Responding to a recent series of disagreements with the trustees of the college which resulted in an "unfortunate rupture in the Institution" and the suspension of three students. With a contemporary signature of Samuel L. Howell in the margin. 1 p.
Letter inviting Charles F. Mercer to deliver the Annual Discourse before the American Whig and Cliosophic Societies. Signed by Richard Stockton, James Carnahan, and Samuel J. Bayard. 1 p.

Printed pamphlet entitled An Account of the College of New-Jersey. Printed by James Parker. Signed on the first and last pages by P[eter] W[aldron] Yates (1747-1826, delegate to Continental Congress). 47 pp.
Draft Ms. Proposal to rid England of its excess population by having idle sons of gentry and poor children engage in the fishing trade and settle in New England. 4 pp.

DS. Petition from Proctor to the governor and council, asking to be allowed out of jail on bail, having been sent there based on complaints of an "afflicted person." [Multiple members of the Proctor family were accused of witchcraft.] 1 p.
American Revolutionary general. Letters filed by recipient.
LS, Camp Horse Neck. Explaining the facts about a prisoner named Butler who had been held in New York and left with the help of a dragoon and two horses. 1 p.

LS, Peekskill. Ordering the colonel, on instructions from Governor [George] Clinton, to march half his regiment to Peekskill and to keep the other half in readiness to march because of the expected enemy intention to take posts in the Highlands. 1 p.
LS, Princeton. Telling Rodney to exercise judgment about leaving Trenton and ordering him to forward artillery if supplied with ammunition. 1 p.
Politician and lawyer who served as Mayor of New York City from 1810-1811 and 1815-1818.
To Jedediah Morse.
ALS, New York. About a lawsuit against a Mr. Reid over the printing of a book by Winterbotham, communicating Reid's offer to settle for $500 plus taxes. 2 pp.

ALS, New York. Updating Morse on the status of his lawsuit against Mr. Reid; praising the work of the New England states; speaking harshly of Jacobins and saying the French faction in America ought to be "exterminated." 3 pp.
ALS, New York. Concerning how and when Morse will receive the rest of the money from his settlement with Mr. Reid. 2 pp.
DS. Signed as witness for transfer of land from George Freligh to Gabriel H. Ludlow, George Ludlow, and Egbert Benson. 5 pp.
American statesman who served as Governor of Virginia, Attorney General, and Secretary of State. Letters filed by recipient.

LS, Philadelphia. Announcing that he has succeeded [Thomas] Jefferson as Secretary of State, acknowledging receipt of Humphreys letters and information of the Algerian treaty, and sending papers and journals updating on the work of Congress [not included]. 2 pp.

ALS, Philadelphia. Enclosing a statement outlining their entire correspondence [not included]; discussing international affairs, yellow fever, the whiskey insurrection, and $800,000 to be offered to the Dey of Algiers as ransom. 5 pp.

LS, Germantown. Marked "a true copy." In response to European powers at war, discussing how far U.S. jurisdiction and protection extends beyond its coast. Issuing a temporary order that one sea league be the margin around the coast wherein hostilities are forbidden, giving the procedure to be followed whenever a capture is made within this limit. With an additional enclosure giving instructions to governors of states on the coast. 4 pp. total.

English colonial official. Ms document with autograph signed endorsement on back. Articles Against the Government of Boston, an account of offenses committed by the government of Massachusetts against the crown, drawn up for presentation to the Lords of Trade and Plantation. 3 pp.
American statesman. Letters filed by recipient.
ALS. Concerning an official statement sent to Monroe. 1 p.
ALS, Monticello. Lamenting the fatal illness of [Mary] Eppes [daughter of Thomas Jefferson]; remarking on how the President is dealing with her expected death. 3 pp.

Secretary of the Massachusetts Bay colony. ANS on a petition signed by 21 merchants and shipmasters of Massachusetts and New Hampshire asking for the repeal of a law prohibiting the export of raccoon skins. 1 p.
American Revolutionary officer.
Filed by correspondent.

LS (draft), Bath. Sending a letter for his wife & daughter, saying that he is feeling well though a week of rain may have injured the [healing powers of] the waters [he was visiting natural springs in Virginia]. 1 p.
A letter to James by one of his brothers, saying the country is "all in confusion" due to the war, anticipating his own death. 4 pp.
ALS (signature partly torn away), Colchester. Expressing joy that they will be meeting in Maryland, suggesting various activities and sending regards from his mother & sisters. 3 pp.

ALS (draft), Bath, Berkley County, Virginia. Writing to his daughter, describing the other guests at the natural spring, encouraging she and her mother to use their bath every morning to preserve health. 2 pp.
His wife.

ALS, Somerset County, New Jersey, "on the march from Pluckemin to MorrisTown." Assuring her of his health, saying he has fought in battles at Trenton and Princeton, reporting on the military success of his brothers. 2 pp.
ALS, Morristown, New Jersey. Reporting his arrival at Morristown and expressing optimistic expectations of routing the enemy. 1 p.
ALS, Morristown, East Jersey. Saying he misses his family but is honored to serve his country; stressing the importance of the victories at Princeton and Trenton; praising General Washington. 3 pp.
ALS, Camp at Swedes Ford on Schuylkill. Assuring her of his health, describing the army's position and hope for victory, sending updates about various family members and acquaintances. 2 pp.
ALS, Bath in Berkley County, Virginia. Describing his journey, arrival, and lodgings at the warm springs, where many have traveled in the hopes of improving their health. 4 pp.
ALS (draft), Bath in Berkley County, Virginia. Discussing the weather and conditions at the spring, mentioning Dr. Rush, congratulating her on their eighteenth wedding anniversary. 4 pp.

Appointing James Reed [sic] Major of the first battalion of militia in the county of Philadelphia. On vellum, signed by Thomas Wharton and Timothy Matlack (Pennsylvania President and Secretary respectively). 1 p. Included is a small vellum pouch in which the commission was kept and likely hung from a string or belt.
AM. Describing a journey from Philadelphia to New York City to upstate New York, commenting on the modes of travel, the housing styles, the pace of life in different towns, etc. 4 pp.
American lawyer and statesman, served as third President [governor] of Pennsylvania from 1778 to 1781.
Filed by recipient.

ALS, London. To an unnamed general. Reporting from England how unfavorably the gentry and upper classes speak of the United States and American officers; discussing the possibility of a Dutch loan. 4 pp.
ALS, Philadelphia. Asking for an accurate return of the officers of the Pennsylvania line as clothing for them is to be issued. 1 p.

LS, Philadelphia. To John Shee and Jacob Morris, auditors of accounts. Giving the opinion of council concerning the compensation and reimbursement of specific individuals in the service of the state. Signed by Reed as President of Pennsylvania. 2 pp.

ALS, Camp at Cambridge. To the Chairman of the Committee of Portsmouth. Saying that General [Washington] has directed [Stephen] Moylan to handle the transportation of flour from Portsmouth and referring to a probable attack there by the British fleet. 2 pp.

ALS, Camp at Cambridge. Sending word from General Washington that Major French and accompanying prisoners should not be brought to Cambridge; directing Reed to keep the men at Hartford or some other place appointed by Governor [Jonathan] Trumbull. 1 p.

Proclamation issued by Reed as President of Pennsylvania's Supreme Executive Council, naming 33 Tories as traitors, calling on them to give themselves up and stand trial for treason. Directing faithful Pennsylvanians to take notice and apprehend the traitors. Signed by Pennsylvania Secretary Timothy Matlack. 3 pp.

AMsS. Stating his understanding that regiments and companies derive their posts according to the rank of the company and not the rank of the commanding officer, saying this rule was established in the American army when he was adjutant general. 2 pp.
Remsen was a New York banker and cashier of the Manhattan Company, which was involved in a scheme to supply New York City with clean water. Draft letters, filed by recipient.

Two draft ALsS, New York. The first, dated May 28, thanks Dulany for sending a copy of the regulations of the waterworks in London, wishes him better health, laments the fighting between Great Britain and France, and provides a statement of shares. The second, dated November 3, reiterates the major points of the first letter as it seems to have been lost in transit. 4 pp.
Two draft ALsS, New York. Both dealing with the purchase of various stocks, specifically mentioning stock in the Manhattan Bank. 33 pp.
A printed bond from the state of Massachusetts, engraved by Paul Revere. 1 p.
Mayor of New York City from 1735-1739.
DS. Ordering a special election to fill the position of constable in Montgomerie Ward, as the original constable has abandoned the city due to a smallpox epidemic. 1 p.
ALS, New York. To Jacob Wendell. Mentioning an inventory, a mortgage, and family affairs. 1 p.

This file consists of a group of broadsides issued by the State of Rhode Island and Providence Plantations from 1776-1812. Nearly all are docketed on the back for the Town Clerk or Treasurer of Exeter.

Issued by the Colony of Rhode Island. An Act repealing an Act intituled [sic] "An Act for the more effectual securing to His majesty the Allegiance of His subjects in this His Colony and Dominion of Rhode-Island and Providence Plantations" and altering the Form of Commissions, of all Writs and Processes in the Courts, and of the Oaths prescribed by Law. Signed by Henry Ward, Secretary of the General Assembly.
A resolution reducing the toll paid to millers for grinding corn, as corn is scarce. Printed by John Carter.
An Act for the better forming, regulating and conducting the military Force of this State. Printed by John Carter.
An act concerning the auditing of non-commissioned enlistments.
A resolution ordering town clerks to transmit accounts of all bounties and gratuities given to officers and soldiers. Printed by John Carter.
An Act for raising Six Hundred and Thirty able-bodied effective men. Printed by John Carter.
An Act for proportioning, upon the several Towns within this State, the monthly Supplies to be raised for the Support of the Army. Printed by John Carter.

An Act for granting and apportioning a Tax of Sixteen Thousand Pounds, in Silver or Gold; Six Thousand Pounds thereof to be appropriated towards paying the Balances due to the Regiments of Colonel Greene, Colonel Angell and Colonel Sherburne; and Ten Thousand to be appropriated to the raising of this State's Quota of the Continental Army. Printed by Bennett Wheeler.

Two acts and two resolutions printed on one sheet of paper: An Act Proportioning to the several Towns in this State, and for collecting Fresh Beef for Supplying the Army of the United States and An Act in Addition and Amendment of an Act passed at the last Session of this Assembly, for filling up and compleating [sic] this State's Quota of the Continental Army. The two resolutions concern taxes and payment for soldiers respectively.
An act requiring each town to provide cornmeal for the subsistence of the state troops.
An act concerning the quota of beef each town is required to give to supply the army. Printed by Bennett Wheeler.
An act concerning the failure of certain towns to provide their quota of men for the Continental Army.

p.emph: An Act for incorporating and bringing into the Field Five Hundred able-bodied effective Men of the Militia, to serve within this State for One Month, from the Time of their Rendezvous, and no longer Term, and not to be marched out of the same.

scopecontent.p: Amending previous acts for relieving the state militia. Printed by Bennett Wheeler.
An Act for proportioning upon the several Towns within this State Supplies of Beef, for the Support of the Army, for the Months of August and September next. Printed by Bennett Wheeler.
An act requiring each town to provide corn or rye for the subsistence of the state troops.

p.emph: An Act to disqualify Persons convicted of carrying on an illicit Trade with the Enemy from electing or being elected to any Office within this State.
An Act for granting and apportioning a Tax of Twenty Thousand Pounds, in Silver or Gold, upon the Inhabitants of this State.

scopecontent.p: Addition to a previous act concerning the issuing of interest on loan-office certificates. Signed Henry Ward, Secretary. Printed by John Carter, Providence.

p.emph: An Act for granting and apportioning a Tax of Twenty Thousand Pounds, in Silver or Gold, upon the Inhabitants of this State.
An Act for granting and apportioning a Tax of Twenty Thousand Pounds, Lawful Money, upon the Inhabitants of this State.

scopecontent.p: An Act for granting and apportioning a Tax of Twenty Thousand Pounds, Lawful Money, upon the Inhabitants of this State. Printed by Bennett Wheeler, Providence.
An Act to Stimulate and give Efficacy to the Paper Bills, emitted by this State in May last. Printed by Bennett Wheeler, Providence.
An Act for granting and apportioning a Tax of Thirty Thousand Pounds, lawful Money, upon the Inhabitants of this State. Printed by Bennett Wheeler.
An Act for granting and apportioning a Tax of Thirty Thousand Pounds, lawful Money, upon the Inhabitants of this State. Printed by Bennett Wheeler, Providence.
An Act for granting and apportioning a Tax of Six Thousand Pounds, Lawful Money, upon the Inhabitants of this State. Printed J. Carter, Providence.
An act for granting and apportioning a Tax of Twenty Thousand Dollars upon the Inhabitants of this State. Printed by H. & O. Farnsworth.
An Act for granting and apportioning a Tax of Twenty Thousand Dollars. Signed Samuel Eddy, Secretary.
An Act for granting and apportioning a Tax of Ten Thousand Dollars. Signed Samuel Eddy, Secretary.

LS, Williamsburg. To the General Assembly of the State of Virginia. Replying to an address from the Assembly congratulating Louis XVI on the birth of a son, with hopes for continued affection between France and the U.S. 2 pp.
American financier. ALS, New York. To Professor H.B. Nason. Thanking him for a book and hoping to visit soon. 1 p.
American geologist, founder of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. Letters filed by recipient.
ALS (draft), University of Virginia. To the Foreign Secretary of the Geological Society of London. Thanking the Society for electing him a Foreign Member. 1 p.
ALS, Boston. Thanking him and his wife for their kindness during his visit to Cambridge, Mass. 1 p.
ALS (draft), University of Virginia. Thanking the societies of the college for inviting him to visit; regretfully declining. 1 p.
ALS, University of Virginia. To his brothers. Reporting his arrival at the University of Virginia, asking for letters from them. 2 pp.
ALS, University of Virginia. Saying the he would like to accept the invitation to speak to the Jefferson Society but must reschedule for a different date. 1 p.
Wife of Franklin Delano Roosevelt. TLS. To E. D. Bloom. Sending an autograph card of her husband, the Governor of New York, and saying he has a program of the Memorial Services. 1 p.
Served as Governor of New York from 1929-1932 and thirty-second President of the United States from 1933-1945.
Filed by recipient.
TLS. Thanking him for sending a letter of Theodore Roosevelt. 1 p.

ALS, New York. Reporting on a conference in Auburn, the success of his campaign for governor in the western upstate region of New York, and bits of business for the committee. Written on Marvin, Hooker & Roosevelt letterhead. 2 pp.
TLS, Executive Chamber, Albany. Thanking a veteran for his approval and support. 1 p. with original envelope.
TLS, Executive Mansion, Albany. Thanking Hall for his support, saying they must first focus on winning the election and then discuss appointments. 1 p.
TLS, Navy Department. Concerning the details of Helmuth's case involving reimbursement for time spent on furlough. Sent by Roosevelt as Assistant Secretary of the Navy. 1 p.

TLS, Executive Chamber, Albany. Saying that he cannot go to White Sulphur during the meeting of the Virginia State Bar Association because of his duties as Governor of New York but that he is interested in the fine work being done there. 1 p.

TLS, Executive Mansion, Albany. Thanking Vernon for sending a newspaper clipping; saying that states must individually consider how to handle the control and distribution of liquor following the repeal of the 18th Amendment. 1 p. with original envelope.

TL, Washington. Letter from Roosevelt's private secretary, M.A. LeHand, thanking a Mr. Stevens for his letter and sending a photograph of the President. [The photograph is filed below under Miscellaneous.] 1 p.
DS. Printed copy of Roosevelt's inaugural address, given March 4, 1933. Signed on the last page.
Signed photograph of Roosevelt sitting at a desk.
Signatures of Roosevelt and Herbert Hoover underneath pen and ink caricature portraits of their heads. 1 p.

Theodore Roosevelt served as twenty-sixth President of the United States from 1901 to 1909. This series mainly consists of correspondence written by Roosevelt dating from the 1880s until just before his death in 1919. His letters reflect many of the positions he held before being elected President including Civil Service Commissioner under Presidents Harrison and Cleveland and President of the board of New York Police Commissioners. They also frequently touch on his penchant for writing as he corresponded with numerous editors and publishers for works covering everything from politics to hunting. Many of the letters are marked "Personal" and contain Roosevelt's private opinions on official subjects. He responds to criticisms of all kinds, and offers many of his own criticisms, particularly with regards to President Woodrow Wilson's handling of World War I and the treatment of German-Americans. In an 1899 letter to Bartlett S. Johnston, Roosevelt insists he will never be considered for President. The series is arranged alphabetically by correspondent. Miscellaneous documents are housed in a folder at the end.
Filed by correspondent.
Editor of The Outlook.

TLS, Washington. Marked "Personal." Saying that the Hague Tribunal should act in a certain case, but that having a first-class navy and army are more important. Mentioning the color line in an autograph postscript. 1 p.
TLS, Washington. Marked "Personal." Discussing in detail various bills before Congress concerning trusts and franchise taxes. 4 pp.

TLS, Washington. Marked "Personal." Responding to allegations of "White House extravagance," addressing whether the government paid for a new stable, a tennis court, the use of a yacht, the expansion of the White House, etc. Defending his actions and the use of his own money, calling the allegations "fatuous folly." 6 pp.

TLS with autograph additions, Oyster Bay, NY. Marked "Personal." Answering inquiries about the cruise of a navy fleet to the Pacific Coast: the length, number of men, the response should war unexpectedly break out, etc. 3 pp. with original envelope. Also included are transcriptions of two letters from Abbott to Roosevelt (3 additional pages)

TLS, Washington. Marked "Personal." Alleging false information and "outrageous bad faith" exhibited in an editorial in The Springfield Republican, which was written in response to a review in Abbott's publication [ The Outlook] concerning the Russo-Japanese Treaty. 2 pp. with original envelope and a newspaper clipping of the offending editorial.

TLS with autograph addition, Washington. Mocking the allegations that Standard Oil controls The Outlook. 2 pp. with original envelope. Also included is a copy of a letter from Abbott to Roosevelt on the same subject. 2 pp.

TLS, Lake Naivasha (Africa). Referring to fake stories about his hunting exploits in Africa, explaining that he has only hunted for food and for animals to be preserved and given to the National Museum; with mention of [Edward W.] Bok. 2 pp.

ALS, Naivasha (Africa). Discussing [Charles] Eliot's list of best books and lambasting [Leo] Tolstoy for hypocrisy and perverted views on marriage; with multiple references to the Russian government. 4 pp.
ALS, New York. Saying he hopes Abbott will be away all summer; asking him to give any help possible to the executive committee. 1 p.

TLS, Porto Alegre, Brazil. Concerning an article he sent to Abbott on "the Negro in Brazil." Expressing surprise and pleasure at the advanced situation of the Brazilians, with the caveat that they are behind the U.S. in matters of sexual morality. 3 pp.
TLS, New York. Saying he cannot write an article proposed by Abbott. 1 p. With a copy of Abbott's letter to Roosevelt requesting the article. 1 p.
ALS, Sagamore Hill (NY). Forwarding an article, asking for a proof, and commenting on his bad handwriting. Written on a small card.

TLS, New York. Saying that he will not write about the Kaiser and relating a ludicrous story about the Kaiser, the Crown Prince, and himself. 1 p. with a copy of a letter from Abbott to Roosevelt on the same subject. 1 p.

TLS, Washington. To the editor of The Outlook. Marked "Personal." Responding to an article that was critical of [Henry Cabot] Lodge; defending Lodge and comparing and contrasting him to [Charles] Sumner and [Daniel] Webster. 2 pp. with original envelope.

TLS with autograph additions, Oyster Bay, NY. Responding to a review in The Springfield Republican of a Russian writer's [Prof. Kovalesky] article on the Russo-Japanese Treaty. Describing the true details of his negotiations with both nations and the fact that he only met with them at the request of Japan. A postscript mentions that he is more devoted to seeing [C.E.] Hughes nominated Governor of New York than he was to see [William H.] Taft nominated for President. 2 pp.
ALS, Oyster Bay, NY. Thanking Allison for information about the Daniel Boone tree which he plans to use in a forthcoming book [ The Winning of the West]. 4 pp.
ALS, New York. Making an appointment for Allison to bring his little daughter to visit. 1 p.
ALS, Medora, Dakota. On the number of yearlings that can be placed on the range, discussing the price of other cattle. 2 pp. with original envelope.
TLS, Oyster Bay, NY. Hoping to see Bigelow and recalling time together at Santiago. 1 p.
TLS, Washington. Marked "Personal." To the Attorney General. Telling him to "repair damages" and rest in Baltimore. 1 p.

TLS, Washington. Marked "Personal." Thanking him for a letter and editorials; saying that the message that he (Roosevelt) wrote was in the spirit of the independent churches who made up Cromwell's army. 1 p.
TLS, Oyster Bay, NY. Saying it is impossible for him to commit to write an article for The Congregationalist; hoping he will not be considered churlish for his refusal. 1 p.

TLS, Washington. To the Governor of Colorado. Announcing the creation of a National Conservation Commission following a suggestion made at a conference of governors. 1 p. With a copy of Roosevelt's order creating the commission. 6 pp.
ALS, Washington. One line: "It is a pleasure to write a line to a gentleman who has been engaged with myself in the endeavour to better the condition of our national civil service." 1 p.
TLS, New York. Saying that Panama reserved the right to secede and had ample justification for a revolution. 1 p.
TLS, War Department, Washington. To the Speaker of the House of Representatives. Forwarding a draft of a bill to raise a volunteer army in time of emergency. 2 pp.
TLS, Buffalo, NY. Thanking him for his letter and saying there is absolute certainty of the President's [William McKinley] recovery. 1 p.
Member of the Lotus Club.
TLS, Washington. Marked "Personal." Thanking Chambers for a book, telling him to visit when he comes to Washington. 1 p.
TLS, New York. "No, Van Wyck did not ask the Rough Riders to parade, nor did he review the regiment. Do let me see you anytime you find convenient." 1 p.
TLS, New York. Thanking Chambers for a book, wishing they had more time to visit. 1 p.
TLS, New York. Thanking him for sending a newspaper clipping. 1 p.
TLS, New York. Hastily thanking him for a letter. 1 p.
TLS, New York. Sending his thanks for a favor. 1 p.
TLS, Oyster Bay, NY. Thanking him for a letter and advice; introducing Senator [Chauncey M.] Depew. 1 p.
TLS, Oyster Bay, NY. Thanking him for a letter. 1 p.
ALS, Washington. Responding to suggestions by his editor and providing new content for his book [The Wilderness Hunter], specifically describing the reasons why a bear might walk on two legs. 4 pp.
ALS, Washington. Marked "Personal." Offering congratulations for Cleveland's seventieth birthday. 2 pp.
TLS, Oyster Bay, NY. Marked "Personal; Not for Publication." Discussing the Philippines and American expansionism, with parallels to other colonial empires. 5 pp.
Mrs. Cushman K. Davis.
LS, Albany, NY. Sending sympathy and speaking of his admiration for her husband. 1 p.
TLS, Oyster Bay, NY. Marked "Personal." Saying that he has written to Mr. Longerman asking for the proposal about the naval station. 1 p.

TLS, Navy Department, Washington. Inviting the senator to a dinner given by the editor of the Sun at which [Henry C.] Lodge and [Garret A.] Hobart will be present; mentioning an allusion to Davis in his book, American Ideals. 2 pp.
TLS, New York. Saying that double the number of Americans have been killed in Mexico and by submarine warfare within the past three and a half years than were killed during the Spanish War. 1 p.
TLS, Washington. To the Secretary of the Customs Board. "I have to request that you forward at once the reports of examinations held on April 1, 1890." 1 p.
TLS, New York. Expressing surprise that a Mr. Cassi, who served valiantly in Roosevelt's regiment, has fallen into trouble with General Cesnola. 1 p.
Secretary of the National Civic Federation.

TLS with autograph corrections, New York. Marked "Private." Harshly stating that Easley must not wholehandedly condemn all Americans of German origin but must judge them by their loyalties, but stating that if any are found to be disloyal to America they should be shot or hanged, specifically mentioning Virieck and two Columbia students. Criticizing President [Woodrow] Wilson. 2 pp.

TLS, New York. Saying that he agrees with Easley about Nagel. Harshly criticizing the government for failing to properly prosecute traitors, with numerous vitriolic statements about President [Woodrow] Wilson. 2 pp.

TLS with autograph corrections, New York. Marked "Private." Continuing his bitter complaints about [Woodrow] Wilson's handling of the war, saying that Wilson is considering his own personal advancement above all else. 2 pp.

TLS, New York. Clarifying misconstrued statements, saying that he has always maintained that the bulk of Americans of German dissent are loyal to America, but that those who are not must be found out and harshly prosecuted. 1 p.

TL, signed by Roosevelt's secretary. Saying that Easley should enlist the help of Harry Lauder and have some wounded veterans speak out against a growing anti-English sentiment in America. Commending Easley on his handling of the "Polish matter." 1 p.
ALS, Oyster Bay, NY. Asking for assistance in researching early New York, for a volume to be published as part of [E.A.] Freeman's "Historic Towns" series. 2 pp.
TLS, Albany, NY. Declining her suggestion to dramatize his book on Cromwell. 1 p.
ALS, Oyster Bay, NY. Saying he is delighted to receive feedback on an article he wrote. Commenting on reference works. 1 p.

TLS, New York. Commending Goldfogle on his nomination by the Republicans, saying that his platform of "100% Americanism" stands in stark opposition to the German Socialism of his opponent, Mr. London. 2 pp.
ALS, Washington. Referring to one of his speeches which Hale has praised, the recent election, and his faith in America. 2 pp.
TLS, Oyster Bay, NY. Saying he hopes to dine with Hale in Yonkers, expressing admiration for Hale's work. 1 p.
TLS, New York. Saying that books had been sent to the New York Historical Association and that his knowledge of Dutch is limited to one folk song. 1 p.
TLS, New York. Thanking Harrison for sending the text of a Senator's remarks, saying the senator answered a question properly. 1 p.
TLS, New York. Thanking Hart for a book and saying he is strongly advocating the introduction of the Swiss system into the U.S. 1 p.
TLS, Washington. Marked "Personal." Telling Harvier to call on Parsons or [T.L.] Woodruff as the President can do little "in a campaign like this." 1 p. with original envelope.
TLS, Washington. Asking Harvey to call after the election with three gentlemen, mentioning Chaplain Casey. 1 p. with original envelope.
TLS, Washington. Thanking him for his telegram and his contribution to [W.H. Taft's] victory in the election. 1 p. with original envelope.
TLS, Oyster Bay, NY. "Oh, Lord, how I wish I were a sword, or part of the head, and not just one of the writers!" 1 p.
TLS, Oyster Bay, NY. Refusing to write for the Brooklyn Eagle, as he has refused countless other newspapers and magazines and must remain consistent. 1 p.
TLS, Albany, NY. Saying that the party machine would never put him up for President and that his Spanish War record led to his being made Governor. 1 p.
TLS, New York. Denying the rumor that he is about to join the Scottish Rite, Northern Jurisdiction. 1 p. with original envelope.
TLS, Albany, NY. Commending Lala on the impartiality displayed in his book. 1 p.
ALS, Oyster Bay, NY. Thanking her for a book, discussing his writing on Robert E. Lee, and offering to send her the next volume of the American Statesmen Series on Gouverneur Morris. 4 pp.
ALS, Washington. Promising to send a book, commenting on the valor of General [Robert E.] Lee, asking after Colonel Preston. 4 pp.
ALS, Washington. Saying that Lord has not passed his examination for the Patent Office Board. 3 pp.
TLS, New York. Saying it is a "physical impossibility" for him to accept Martin's invitation. 1 p. with original envelope.
TLS, Navy Department, Washington. Promising to write to Niblack who is doing admirably abroad. 1 p.
TLS, Oyster Bay, NY. Concerning the complicated and delicate matter of the disposition of lands owned by the Catholic Church in the Philippines. 2 pp.
TLS, Washington. Welcoming McDonough home from the Philippines and wishing to see the judge before he makes any public address. 1 p.
TLS, New York. Declining an engagement. 1 p.
TLS, Police Department, New York. Regretfully declining an invitation as Sundays are the only time he can spend with his family. 1 p.
Secretary of the Navy.

TLS, Washington. "The enclosed memorandum of Admiral Dewey on the general staff seems to me altogether admirable." 1 p. letter with 5 pp. memorandum "Concerning the proposed formation of a general staff for the Navy," signed by George Dewey.

TLS, Oyster Bay, NY. Marked "Personal." Forwarding a letter from the Dean of the University of Chicago [not included], asking if Moody will agree to make the opening address at the campaign in Chicago. 1 p.
