TLS, Grand Island, Nebraska. Marked "Personal." Asking Moody to join him for travels through California and Washington State, both for friendship and for the purpose of inspecting navy yards. 1 p.

TLS, Omaha, Nebraska. Marked "Personal." Again asking Moody to join him for travels through California, Oregon, and Washington; promising four days holiday in Yosemite and a rendezvous with Seth Bullock and "a select circle of cowboy friends." 1 p.

TLS, Oyster Bay, NY. "I should like to know what truth there is as regards this story." 1 p. with small newspaper clipping claiming that upwards of 100 American sailors deserted Admiral Cotton in Germany.
TLS. Forwarding a letter from Wainwright praising Lieutenant-Commander Sims; asking for suggestions for how to reward Sims for his service. 1 p. with original 4 pp. letter from Wainwright.

TLS, Washington. Marked "Personal. "I think the enclosed by Bat Masterson will appeal to you." 1 p. with newspaper clipping of a piece by Masterson giving his positive opinion of the President and negative opinion of Congress.
TLS, Washington. Marked "Personal." Responding to suggestions from Sims, wondering how specialized the weaponry on Naval ships can be before it does more harm than good. 1 p.
ALS, Washington. Saying that the Civil Service cannot initiate promotions but can only respond to requests from appointing officers. 2 pp.
TLS, New York. Saying he will likely not be able to make a lunch with Oliver as all his time is taken up by his scientific friends. 1 p.

TLS, Washington. Discussing points raised by Phillips about dealings with the Indians, specifically mentioning the Indian commissioners of 1822, the report of 1868 touching on the issue of torture, and a case from Bonneville. 2 pp. Included is a one page 1893 autograph memo on the subject (with an explanatory note), an 1894 TLS from Captain John G. Bourke to Phillips (2 pp.), and an 1893 TMs about torture as practiced by the Indians and whites (1 p.).
TLS. To the Quartermaster of the First Regt. U.S. Vol. Cav. "Please give bearer halters, a curry-comb, brush, bucket &c. for my two horses." Half page cut out and glued to another piece of paper.
TLS, Washington. Marked "Personal." Responding to false reports circulated by an Episcopal clergyman and a school teacher that Roosevelt has a drinking problem. 2 pp.
TLS, Washington. "Before you leave can you come down here and spend a night? When are you going to be in New York?" 1 p.
TLS, New York. Refusing to answer petty and anonymous rumors about his and his sons' service in the military; referring Relf to his book, The Foes of Our Own Household. 2 pp.
TLS, Oyster Bay, NY. Marked "Personal." Thanking Reynolds for an aquamarine from New Hampshire, with remarks on the nature of peace and justice. 2 pp. with original envelope.
ALS, Washington. Asking for the date of the February meeting of the Liberal Club at which he is to speak. 1 p.
TLS, New York. Thanking him for writing. 1 p.
Editor of Atlantic Monthly.

ALS, Washington. Saying that the "Century" people have asked him to write a civil service article but he thinks it may be better placed in the Atlantic Monthly expressing concern over its reception by Congress; saying he now strongly believes in the merit system. 3 pp.
ALS, Washington. Forwarding a copy of his article [not included], asking for a proof. 2 pp.
ALS, Washington. Sending his article on civil service reform, asking whether the Atlantic Monthly would be interested in publishing it. 2 pp.
ALS, Washington. Saying he is amenable to postponing the publication of his article, but not past September 1. 2 pp.

ALS, Washington. Thanking Scudder for his note, saying he understands that his article is "combative" and that a magazine may not be the best place to "hit his defamers square between the eyes." 2 pp.

ALS, Washington. Saying he cannot write an article by November 12 but could finish one by December 1. Complaining that he just received an angry letter from Mr. Merwin, who saw a personal letter Roosevelt sent to Scudder. 2 pp.

ALS, Washington. He is having a copy of his book Wilderness Hunter sent to Scudder, asking him to look it over. Saying he hopes he has done for the life of the hunter what [John] Burroughs has done for home woods and fields. 3 pp.

TLS, Washington. Asking if he may write an article on [Charles Henry] Pearson's National Life and Character: A Forecast; harshly criticizing the Atlantic Monthly for publishing writers with "a colonial habit of thought" and discussing English versus American literature. 3 p..
TLS, Washington. Sending a proof and asking whether J.H. Porter, a "leading anthropologist," may write a review of Roosevelt's book The Wilderness Hunter for the Atlantic Monthly. 2 pp.
TLS, Washington. Giving more information on J.H. Porter [see above], listing his merits but also mentioning a problem with alcoholism. 2 pp.

TLS, Washington. Saying he accepted a position with extreme reluctance and worries he will not be able to do much with it; inquiring whether a review has been written for [Max] Nordau's book on degeneration. 1 p.
ALS, New York. Announcing himself as candidate for Speaker [of the New York Assembly] and asking for Shoemaker's support. 2 pp.
Secretary of the Progressive Republican League of Nebraska.

TLS, New York. Marked "Personal." Asking Shotwell and his friends to abandon a movement to nominate Roosevelt for a third term as president, as it would "deeply embarrass" him. 1 p. with a 1912 newspaper clipping about the letter.

TLS, New York. Marked "Private and Confidential." Saying that he is not ready to announce whether he is again running for president, but that he believes the people at large want him to do so and he does not wish to be nominated by politicians or friends. 2 pp.
ALS, New York. Wishing Sprague success at a meeting, and saying every American of fighting age should "get into the fighting" and the rest should support them until victory has been achieved. 1 p.
President of the Republican League of Clubs.
TLS, Washington. Commending the Republican League of Clubs for their good citizenship and service to the nation. 1 p. with original envelope.
TLS, Oyster Bay, NY. Saying he envies a trip taken by Stewart and his wife; sending regards to guides who have an "anti-race-suicide" standpoint. 1 p.

TLS, New York. Saying he cannot currently commit to any associations or movements with regards to Canada or China; asking Steward to meet with some men and discuss the Agricultural and Industrial School matter. 1 p.
ALS, The White Nile. Concerning a homecoming reception for him upon his return from Africa, insisting that any such celebration be non-partisan and not attended by the President. 4 pp.

TLS, aboard the Ibis on the Nile. Marked Confidential. Chastising Stewart for faults in transcribing a cablegram, discussing a reception he would like to hold to meet people from all different political viewpoints and parts of America, warning Stewart to watch his words as they could be easily misconstrued by the press. 3 pp.

TLS, Porto Maurizio. Expressing relief that Stewart did not say the "idiotic things" attributed to him by the press; saying he likes the idea of a popular, national and non-partisan reception; saying he is concerned over the political situation but will not discuss it by letter. 1 p.
TLS, New York. Saying he believes in Stewart's work but must guard his connections; asking how he can help Blake. 1 p.

TLS, Spokane, Washington. Marked "Private." Saying he showed Stewart's letter on the progressive faction to Senator [Miles] Poindexter; arguing that New Yorkers need education in progressiveness while leaders in Washington (State) need to learn moderation. 1 p.
TLS, New York. Saying he wants to cancel a planned speech in Canada as it may damage his campaign. 1 p.

TLS, Oyster Bay, NY. Saying he largely agrees with the sentiment of Stewart's paper, but disagrees with some points regarding Central and South America; mentioning "hyphenated Americans" and the need to be a good neighbor to Canada. 1 p.

TLS with autograph note, New York. Marked "Private; not for publication or circulation." Responding to an address made by Stewart; arguing that he (Roosevelt) was the only candidate who occupied a particular position of preparedness and Americanism. 1 p.
TLS, Washington. Thanking Thurman for forwarding a letter by Madison. 1 p.
TLS, New York. Thanking Thurman for sending a document signed by his great-great-grandfather, the first revolutionary governor of Georgia. 1 p.
TLS, Police Department, New York. Advocating the appointment of Thomas A. Church as Minister to Haiti. 1 p.
TLS, Washington. Thanking her for sending an article of interest to both Roosevelt and his wife. 1 p.
ALS, New York. Acknowledging Ward's letter, explaining that he did not receive it sooner since he just came back from the West, where he will return in a few days. 2 pp.
ALS, Sagamore Hill (NY). Declining an invitation to speak in Elizabeth and saying that no man who defends the Kaiser of Germany is a good American. 3 pp.

TLS with lengthy autograph postscript, Washington. Agreeing to lunch with Welsh in Philadelphia and defending various appointees to government service, while attacking a Mr. Dougherty for complaints. 2 pp.
TLS, Washington. Thanking the artist for a sketch he sent as a Christmas present. 1 p. with original envelope.

TLS, Washington. Congratulating Wheelan on his success in San Francisco [in the wake of the earthquake and fire], saying he would like to help with the appointment of "young Lewis" but already has so many similar requests that the chances are small. 2 pp.

TLS, New York. Responding to questions and allegations about his stance towards the Catholic Church, saying that he believes men should be judged by their individual worth and behavior towards others, with the freedom to practice whatever religion they choose. 5 pp. with original envelope.
TLS, New York. Thanking Whitlock for a telegram he intends to publish, saying The Evening Post is "rotten at heart." 1 p.
TLS, Oyster Bay, NY. Thanking Whitlock for his cable, saying he is proud of all his sons, particularly Quentin [who died two weeks earlier while fighting in World War I]. 1 p.
TLS, New York. Declining an invitation to speak for the Friends School of Baltimore, Maryland. 1 p.
TLS, Albany, NY. Refusing to give an off-hand opinion on a subject "of so much weight." 1 p.
TLS, New York. Declining an invitation to speak before the Patriotic Education Committee of Painesville, Ohio. 1 p. with original envelope.
A member of the City Vigilance League.
TLS, Police Department, New York. "I will have that matter looked into at once. Many thanks for the information." 1 p.
TLS, Police Department, New York. Saying they are having a desperate fight with the liquor dealers and cannot "watch the boys" at present. 1 p.
TLS, Police Department, New York. "Many thanks for your note. I have directed that these men be thanked." 1 p.

TLS, Police Department, New York. Saying the present law makes it difficult to reach saloons that exercise great care; inquiring whether a newspaper clipping reporting falsities was clipped from the World. 1 p.
TLS, Police Department, New York. Giving the name and address of William Weidersheine, who worked on excise duty. 1 p.
TLS, Police Department, New York. "All right! I will have Ivory hauled over the coals. I will direct the Chief to make a report on the points you mention." 1 p.

ALS. Saying that he will support [James G.] Blaine and would never desert the boys who stood by him the previous winter. [The top of the first page has been ripped away, hiding the recipient and exact date of the letter.] 2 pp.
ALS, New York. On the possible conduct of the New York State Legislature with regards to the Earl exemption bill for sailors and soldiers. 3 pp.

TLS with autograph postscript, Washington. Making inquiry about a possible infringement of Civil Service by the postmaster at Cincinnati, a Mr. Zumstein. [The name of the addressee has been rubbed out.] 2 pp.
ALS, Washington. Refusing to grant a request. 1 p.
Printed catalogue entitled The Summer Birds of the Adirondacks in Franklin County, N. Y., based on observations by Roosevelt and H.D. Minot. 4 pp.
TMsS with autograph corrections and additions, entitled "Hunting in the Cattle Country." 25 pp.
DS, on vellum. Appointing William H. Forwood as Surgeon General. Signed also by Secretary of War Elihu Root. 1 p.
Photograph of Roosevelt inscribed with signature and date: "With regards of Theodore Roosevelt/ November 4th, 1904." C.M. Bell Photographic Co.
TMs with autograph changes. Speech made at the unveiling in Washington of the statue of Frederick the Great, gift of the German nation. 7 pp.
Two engraved portraits, signed and dated. One of Roosevelt, March 14, 1905; the other of his Vice President, Charles W. Fairbanks, February 1, 1909.
DS with many other signatures. Approval on a series of documents offering a reward and appropriation for the arrest and conviction of the murderer of Ben C. Collins, a Chickasaw. 3 pp.
DS with many other signatures. Approval of an act appropriating money to pay for a session of the members and officers of the legislature of the Chickasaw Nation. 3 pp.
TDS. Ordering the creation of a Committee on Grades and Salaries in the Executive Departments. 1 p.
TMs with autograph changes. Speech delivered at Canton, Ohio; a eulogy of William McKinley. 8 pp.
AMsS. "Freedom stands with her back to the wall," a draft of an article about the necessity of full American cooperation with her allies. 2 pp.

Eldest son of President Theodore Roosevelt, served as Governor of Puerto Rico from 1929-1932. TLS, Porto Rico [sic]. To J. McIntosh Eckard. Forwarding a copy of his annual report and commenting on the people of Puerto Rico. 1 p.
American Civil War officer. LS, Helena, Arkansas. To W[illlis] A[rnold] Gorman. Requesting that his brigade be equalized by transferring a regiment. 1 p. with docketing by Gorman on the back.
American physician and political leader. Filed by recipient.
ALS, Philadelphia. Speaking of a reunion of the "Sons of Nassau-Hall" [Princeton alumni], commending college Presidents [Samuel] Davies and [Samuel] Finley. 1 p.

ALS, Philadelphia. Discussing American liberty and extolling Dr. [Benjamin] Franklin, discussing the publication of a speech he delivered to the American Philosophical Society, commenting on commerce and its relation to liberty. 2 pp.

ALS, Philadelphia. Enclosing a copy of the constitution of the "Negro Society" of Philadelphia [not included], discussing how slavery is being denounced throughout the world, suggesting the American Revolution has much to do with the change in attitude. 2 pp.

Popular English composer and singer. Lithograph from the front page of the sheet music for "The Total S'iety: A Comic Song." Depicting a group of men offering a pledge. Handwritten labels have been added over the heads of some of the men. Published by Henry Prentiss and B.W. Thayer's Lithography, Boston. The accompanying music is not present. 1 p.

Signer of the Declaration of Independence, served as Governor of South Carolina from 1798-1800. DS, Charlestown. Writ ordering the arrest of a debtor, signed by Rutledge as attorney for the plaintiff. Countersigned by William H. Drayton. Printed form. 1 p.
Spanish Missionary in California. ADS, baptismal records of California Native Americans. 2 pp.
DS. Copy of orders issued by General Washington relating to the trial and acquittal of Josias C. Hall. Sent to Brigadier General [William] Smallwood. 2 pp.
Journalist and newspaper editor who served as Union Army general during the American Civil War. Letters filed by recipient.
ALS, Editorial Rooms of the Detroit Post. Discussing difficulties at the Detroit Post, expressing interest in leaving the paper for St. Louis or New York, commenting on New York newspapers. 2 pp.
ALS, "Camp near Casletts Station." Reporting the exoneration of Colonel Krzgyanowski and recommending him for nomination as Brigadier General. 1 p.
ALS, Bethlehem, PA. Describing his army career and discussing several battles in detail including Chancellorsville, Bull Run and Gettysburg. 6 pp.
American Revolutionary officer and statesman, served as Senator from New York. Letters filed by recipient.

ALS, Albany. Expressing anxiety that the enemy will divide the American army since they have the advantage of boats; mentioning General Washington's refusal of fifty batteaus and General Carlton's retreat. 1 p.

ALS, Albany. Saying that he has written Wolcott & Edwards, that he is expecting General [John] Stark to arrive in Albany in the coming weeks, planning to visit Duane, and inquiring about bushels of wheat. 1 p.

ALS, Saratoga. Expressing his frustration at having procured troops and supplies for an expedition against Niagara which General Washington has unexpectedly reduced to a smaller campaign against the Indians; mentioning his resignation; inquiring about Generals Lee and St. Clair. 4 pp.

ALS, Albany. On his fear that the Indians will join the British, the difficulties in the Legislature, New York's financial embarrassment, the mutiny of the troops, and the fear that more troops will abandon the frontier for want of meat. 3 pp.
ALS, New York. On various matters of state and political business. 3 pp.
His daughter, Mrs. Alexander Hamilton.
ALS, Albany. Sending butter, potatoes and onions; encouraging she and her family to stay put until a severe frost has ended a health scare. 1 p.

ALS, Albany. Referring to public speculation as to why her husband recently visited Philadelphia; discussing Washington's acceptance of command of the army; sending news of the family's good health. 3 pp.
ALS, Albany. Giving news of family health, hoping to visit her at her country estate, sending love to her husband and children. 1 p.
ALS, Albany. Discussing family news and looking forward to a visit. 1 p.
LS, Saratoga. Recommending that the militia of Tryon County be held in readiness to march; wishing for communication from General [Horatio] Gates. 1 p.
ALS, Albany. On various business matters, enclosing stock and empowering Low to transfer or sell it. 1 p.
ALS, Tyonderoga [sic]. Instructing Captain Mott to treat well the British captives in his care. 2 pp.
ALS, Tyonderoga [sic]. Stating his intention to send 150 men and additional workmen to Fort George the following spring, suggesting Van Rensselaer send a quantity of goods there. 1 p.
ALS, Philadelphia. Joking about retirement from Congress and social life in Philadelphia. 1 p.

British officer in the American Revolutionary War. Ms. Orderly book of Captain Scott's company of the British Legion under the command of Lord [William Schaw] Cathcart, dated October-November 1778. Bound, with a case. Approximately 60 pp.
American military officer.
ALS, Yellow Springs. To J. Vance. Asking Vance to visit; discussing whether he will be given a trial or dismissed from his post. 2 pp.

ADS entitled "Relative to a Modification of the U.S. Military Academy." Outlining different possibilities for modifying the naval academy to better meet the needs of the nation; written in the hopes of quenching a movement to shut down the academy entirely. 5 pp.
First American Episcopal bishop. DS. Deed transferring land in Rhode Island from Samuel & Elizabeth Seabury and James & Ester Helme to Christopher Phillips. 2 pp.
New York politician and U.S. secretary of state. ALS, Washington. To Simon Cameron [Secretary of War]. Recommending that Isaac S. Miller be retained in his present position. 1 p.
Served as Royal Governor of Maryland from 1753 to 1768.
Filed by recipient.
ALS, Annapolis. About the commissioning of [Samuel] Rideout. 1 p.
ALS, London. Explaining how his brother's death forced him to return to England to claim a share of his estate, speaking of his love for Maryland and its people. 3 pp.
ALS, London. Discussing colonial matters in Maryland, speaking of the death of Daniel Dulaney and a position for a Captain Eden. 4 pp.
DS, on vellum. A deed of land to Ninian Veatch. 1 p.
DS. A deed of land to Benjamin Tracey. 1 p.
DS, on vellum. A deed of land to Peter Urquhart. 1 p.
British statesman and diplomat. LS, Beake Street. To his brother, Horatio Sharpe. Recommending the bearer, Mr. Edward Cooke, who intends to enter the tobacco trade in Maryland. 2 pp.
Civil War General. Letters filed by recipient.
ALS, Harper's Ferry. Ordering Augur to send troops to Harper's Ferry from Washington. 1 p.
ALS. Informing Averell of troop movements. 1 p.

American statesman. ALS, Philadelphia. To [Jonathan] Trumbull, Governor of Connecticut. Saying that all states from New Hampshire to Virginia inclusive have appointed commissioners to attend a convention on the regulation of prices, except Massachusetts. 1 p.
Union general in the American Civil War. Many of his letters deals specifically with military strategies and operations during the war.
Filed by correspondent.

ALS, New York. Recalling the early days at Fort Moultrie in 1844, his old captain "Bob Anderson," mentioning an enclosed photograph and his practice of sending out signed engravings, of which he is forwarding four [not included]. 4 pp.

ALS, Camp on Big Black. "To any officer of the U.S. Army to whom this may come, more especially to Maj Generals Banks, Ord, Stone, Franklin & Washburne." Recommending a captured Confederate prisoner, Lt. B.C. Cushman, to their attention as Cushman had been a star pupil at the Louisiana Military Academy. Recommending he be allowed to move about the city during his confinement. 2 pp.
ALS. Asking for a sergeant and ten men to be sent to Fort Bennett to relieve the present guard, a temporary measure. 1 p. Ten names are penciled on the back.
ALS. Discussing a lot of land in San Francisco and explaining his truce with General [John B.] Hood which allowed for the evacuation of Atlanta. 2 pp. [Date based on information in letter.]

ALS, Saint Louis. Saying that he has written Ulysses S. Grant and provided an introduction for Casserly; giving recommendations for how to interview Grant, who is "really social & likes to see people." 2 pp.
ALS, Saint Louis. Insisting he will never agree to run for President, explaining how and why [U.S.] Grant might concede to run for office. 4 pp.
ALS, Saint Louis. Discussing how he and his family are planning to move to Washington so he can succeed [U.S.] Grant in the command of the Army. 3 pp.
ALS, Washington. Relating to several military appointments and Sherman's travels. 4 pp.

ALS, New York. Acknowledging a gift of a book from [Andrew] Carnegie, mentioning Champlin's travel book, his own article in the North American Review, and referring to handing over a letter to [James G.] Blaine from Carnegie. 4 pp.

ALS, Lancaster, OH. Having learned that the Army may be increased, applying for a commission above the rank of captain. Explaining that recent events have destroyed the plans he had when he resigned in 1853. Suggesting California as the best field for his services, as he helped settle the state. 1 p.
ALS, St Louis. Granting an autograph and giving directions for securing [P.H.] Sheridan's autograph, with reminiscences of early California. 3 pp. with original envelope.

ALS, St. Louis. Refusing to allow his name to be nominated as a candidate for civil office [most likely the Presidency], saying the country is full men for the office, among them Devens' own cousin, General Andrews of Massachusetts. 2 pp.

ALS, Goldsboro, NC. Announcing the taking of Richmond and Petersburg, considering Raleigh and Greensboro for his campaign, with mention of C. Schurz's report from Washington. 2 pp. with autograph card of Phillip H. Sheridan.

ALS, Washington. Acknowledging receipt of two silk badges of the old brigade, saying that [U.S.] Grant is attending the funeral of his father, and giving news of his family, particularly the travels of daughter Minnie. 4 pp.

ALS, "Right Wing of Grant's Army." Reporting his own movements and the necessity of organizing men and supplies for the contemplated move on Vicksburg on the 18th, mentioning many Union officers. 2 pp.

ALS, Memphis. On agreement in plans between Halleck, Grant, Steele, and himself, his movement towards Vicksburg, the plan to confuse the enemy with the help of Porter, with mention of Union and Confederate generals, etc. 4 pp.
ALS, Saint Louis. Explaining his unwillingness to approach [Andrew Johnson] or [E.M. Stanton] to secure an appointment for Hoyt's cousin. 3 pp.

ALS, New York. Discussing the reduction in rank of officers following the Civil War, his practice in keeping his correspondence, and the inability to ascertain his official acts. 4 pp. with original envelope.

ALS, New York. Referring to his article in the North American Review, his unwillingness to promise to write or speak, a series of his letters dating from 1836 in the possession of John Sherman, and enclosing two photographs by Sarony [not included]. 3 pp.
ALS, Benton Barracks (Missouri). Asking for paper supplies for muster rolls as he plans to muster all the regiments and detachments simultaneously. 1 p.

ALS, Memphis. Giving his opinion concerning negroes escaping the Confederacy on boats sailing under a flag of truce. Saying, under the law, such people should be returned to their masters, as those boats are technically not part of the Union military lines under which negroes are protected. 2 pp.

ALS, Lancaster, OH. Saying that the size of the regular army is expected to be increased and explaining how officers will be assigned, enclosing a certificate for Captain Murray but saying it will be little help without further recommendations; with friendly news. 4 pp.
ALS, Paris. Thanking her for the opportunity of viewing the portrait of her and her children being painted by M. Cabanel, praising the artist's composition and execution. 2 pp.
ALS, Camp before Vicksburg. Asking for Grant's authority to allow [Charles Rivers] Ellett of the Queen of the West to receive the De Soto rather than turn it over to the navy. 1 p.
ALS, Scottsboro. Ordering [James C.] Veatch to cut off [Nathan Beford] Forrest; with his movements and plans, mentioning other Union officers. 2 pp.
ALS, Washington. Asking if he might peruse letters of Halleck, Grant and C. F. Smith to prepare for a meeting he will attend in April on the anniversary of the Battle of Shiloh. 3 pp.

ALS, St. Louis. Forwarding a copy of an April 1864 letter sent from Alexander Stephens to H. V. Johnson on the topic of Jefferson Davis' usurpation of power, which Sherman wishes to be published. 4 pp. Included is the 9 pp. copy of the letter, in Sherman's hand.
ALS, Kingston, GA. To his wife, saying that they start the next day, that the box of clothing and her letters have arrived, and that she is to write no more until she hears from him. 1 p.
ALS, Camp on Big Black. Asking for aid for Mrs. Kenney and her daughter, who are without household goods, supplies, and cotton; saying that he will approve of any action. 1 p.
Sherman's letters to Thomas were written from the Headquarters of the Department of the Cumberland in Louisville, Kentucky, unless otherwise noted.
ALS. Asking Thomas to move his men in the direction of the Cumberland despite difficult conditions--"if your men simply move the effect will be good." 1 p.
ALS. Expressing his frustration that he is powerless to furnish arms to the many troops currently without them. 1 p.
ALS. Updating on the movements of various troops; hoping the state board will successfully raise more regiments. 3 pp.
ALS. Saying the Secretary of War is coming to visit, complaining that the government has not come through with the men they promised, but hoping they will be adequately supplied soon. 2 pp.
ALS. Declaring Thomas is indeed surrounded by difficulties; offering various alternatives. 2 pp.
ALS. Saying the state military board authorized him to send ammunition to Thomas, mentioning unsafe roads, asking Thomas to keep him informed. 1 p.

ALS. Warning Thomas not to push too far since his line is weak and an interruption of the railroad would cut him off. Saying many men are without arms and uniforms and all he can currently offer are promises from the state board that they will be supplied. 1 p.

ALS. Giving directions for Thomas to watch forces passing toward Kentucky; updating on other regiments; mentioning how winter will affect the roads and how an engagement with General [Robert E.] Lee would occupy all Thomas' time. 2 pp.

ALS. He is aware of the problems with the Kentucky regiments; a telegraph line to Nicholasville has been completed and should be manned by a trusty person; reserve troops are waiting in Ohio; it seems no larger forces can travel through the Gap this season, etc. 1 p.
ALS. Telling Thomas to await further orders as he believes the enemy will decrease rather than increase in his area; suggesting the route they might take and telling Thomas to set up a watchman. 1 p.

ALS. Discussing money for the army, where the troops will winter, how detrimental an attack on bridges and railroads could be; giving directions for Thomas to keep [William Booth] Taliaferro's forces in check, etc. 3 pp.

ALS. Updating on the status of a Turnpike Company, Kentucky Volunteers, and regiments in Ohio; stressing the importance of well-drilled regiments; urging Thomas to do the best he can until more troops can be brought together. 1 p.

ALS. Responding to Thomas' letter reporting that the enemy has reappeared at Monticello; saying that they must watch not only armies in the field but also disunionists throughout the state who could easily band together and destroy trains and railroads; mentioning there is no clothing, arms or wagons for the Kentucky volunteers; presenting evidence that the enemy is gathering a large force in his area, etc. 3 pp.

ALS. Giving Thomas updates received in a telegraph from McCook that Confederate troops along Green River have drawn back to join with others and form a force 20,000 strong, telling Thomas to withdraw as it would be madness to contend with a force of that size. 1 p.

ALS. Reporting that Confederate General [Albert] Sidney Johnston appears to be moving troops from Bowling Green to Lexington, Louisville, and Cincinnati; giving directions for Thomas; updating on the movement of others; providing a telegraphic code phrase for future use. 3 pp.
ALS. Instructing Thomas to intercept the march of Confederate forces near the Kentucky River Bridge. 1 p.
ALS. Responding to a report from Thomas which suggested the enemy has abandoned efforts to penetrate Kentucky by the three passes; instructing Thomas to move his command to Crab Orchard. 1 p.
ALS, near Adairsville. Giving orders for Thomas to pursue the enemy [J. E. Johnston], saying he will be with Thomas in the morning, mentioning many Union officers. 2 pp.
ALS. Informing Thomas that ammunition is on its way by express; asking him to communicate frequently; hoping he can keep enemy forces in check. 1 p.
ALS, San Francisco. Giving the status of mutual business, the receipt of cash and its disposition, and the balance due his correspondent. 3 pp.

Autograph memorandum. Though against his usual practice, endorsing the wish of General [Jasper A.] Maltby that his brother be paroled. Noting that such situations are "one of the curious complications of this cruel war." On a half sheet of paper.
Autograph memorandum. Stating that it would be unwise for the government to yield its legal right to use all enlisted men as privates, reducing some in rank, if necessary. 1 p.

ADS, Washington. Giving notice about a reunion of the societies representing the armies of the Tennessee, Cumberland, Ohio, and Georgia, which will meet 15-16 Dec. 1868 at Chicago, with plans for the reunion. 2 pp.
Photograph of Sherman, signed on front and inscribed on verso to Mrs. General Custer [Elizabeth Bacon Custer, Mrs. George A.] 7 x 9 inches.
American naval officer. ALS, Newport, RI. To G. W. Blodgett. Saying the hope of the future rests on sympathy and good understanding between the English-speaking peoples. 1 p.

Brigadier General for Loyalist forces during the American Revolutionary War. Copy of letter to his brother, Lieutenant Colonel William Skinner. Discussing revolution, the role of Congress, and fate of Loyalists, etc. With a warning not to send letters of a political nature unless the courier is completely trustworthy. The copy is attested true by Charles Thomson, Secretary of Congress. 2 pp.

American Revolutionary officer, served as Governor of Maryland from 1785 to 1788. The documents in this file are in multiple handwritings and many are unsigned, making exact attribution difficult; they are filed under Smallwood based on provenance.
Incomplete letter concerning the distribution of the prize from captured brig Symetry. 2 pp.
Letter to General Washington. Discussing debates over military policies and improprieties conducted by field officers. 3 pp.
Incomplete letter to unknown recipient. Discussing Congress, a movement against General Washington, and the recommendation and promotion of some Maryland officers. 4 pp.
Calling on any person in possession of public stores or with knowledge of concealed stores to immediately report to a commanding officer. 1 p.
Concerning who will receive payment from the sale of captured sloop George. 1 p.

Letter to [Thomas] Johnson. Discussing the problem of adequately clothing the troops, informing the governor of Maryland that his men can likely be furnished with coats and waistcoats but stockings and shoes are in short supply. 2 pp.
Two statements regarding falsehoods and improprieties conducted by Edward Norwood which involved Smallwood. 6 pp. total
Served as President of The College of New Jersey (now Princeton University) from 1795 to 1812. Letters filed by recipient.
ALS, Princeton. On the difficulties of convincing graduates of the college to become teachers or tutors, as most are either independently wealthy or planning to enter the ministry. 2 pp.

ALS, Princeton. Answering queries about the possible enrollment of a young man from St. Domingo at the college, saying he can learn all requested subjects except for landscape drawing, and quoting how much it will cost for tuition, room & board. 2 pp.

American Revolutionary Statesman. ALS, Carlisle. To General [George] Washington. Updating on business he is handling for Washington and congratulating him on his impending accession to the presidency. 1 p.

Thomas, Albert, and Josiah Smith were shipbuilders operating out of Plymouth, Mass. ALS from Thomas in Liverpool to Albert in Massachusetts. Concerning various matters of their shipping business including plans to leave Liverpool and sail to American with cargo of window glass and crockery. 1 p.
Founder of Stanford University. LS, San Francisco. To Professor George Davidson. Agreeing to contribute to the purchase of an insect collection. 1 p.

Union general in the American Civil War. LS to Senator S[olomon] Foot. Describing army conditions and widespread mistrust of General Candy, saying there is much greater confidence in General Smith; asking the Senator to give his attention and influence to the matter. 5 pp.
American politician who served as U.S. secretary of war during most of the American Civil War. Letters filed by recipient.
ALS, Washington. Introducing Reverend Dr. Jenkin to the President. 1 p.
ALS, Washington. Apologizing for the unauthorized use of Welles' name by someone in the War Department, promising to investigate the matter. 1 p.

Served with the Continental Army during the American Revolutionary War. ALS, in French, New York. [To William North.] Describing conversations with [George] Washington, mentioning [Henry] Knox's intrigue against [Alexander] Hamilton, discussing various social events with mention of Edward Livingston and John Adams. 2 pp.

American statesman, served as first U.S. secretary of the Navy. ALS, War Office. To Joseph Reed, President of Pennsylvania. Asking Reed to provide a small guard of militia to transfer prisoners of war from Easton to Reading for the purpose of reducing unnecessary and expensive posts. 1 p.
British soldier during the American Revolutionary War.

ALS, Laurel Hill Lines. To "My Dear Lord." Describing the current state of the war in America, the unexpected arrival of Sir George Rodney, the plans of the French, victories by Cornwallis, harsh weather and illness among the soldiers, etc. 8 pp.

ALS, Camp near Camden. To "My Dear Charles." Describing life in the army, the lack of tents and the difficulty of finding food in the sparsely inhabited country, the commands of Lords Rawdon and Cornwallis, etc. 4 pp.
Dutch official in New York. DS, in Dutch, on vellum. Granting a tract of land in the New Netherlands to Johannis Theodorus Polhemus. 1 p.
American soldier and statesman. LS, Newport. To John Glover. Reporting on the numbers of his forces and stating three possible measures to be followed in response to D'Estaing's retreat. 2 pp.
General in the Continental Army during the American Revolutionary War.
LS, Halifax. Recipient unknown. Concerning negotiations for the exchange of prisoners, with mention of the abuse of public stores. 2 pp.
ALS. To General Nathanael Greene. Reporting on weapons for the army and Baron von Steuben's plans. 1 p .

William Howard Taft served in multiple high-ranking U.S government offices, most notably as President from 1909 to 1913 and Chief Justice from 1921 to 1930. His devotion to law and the courts is evident in this collection of his letters. Most notable is a series of letters written to friend and colleague W. Hallett Phillips containing an insightful mixture of personal and professional news and opinions.
Filed by recipient.
ALS. Apologizing that he cannot dine with her and the Griggs on Sunday as he will be receiving a degree at the University of Pennsylvania [date based on contents]. 1 p.
TLS, New Haven, CT. Saying that he does not have time to prepare for a speech to which he tentatively agreed and that the subject would not be fit for a suggested book. 1 p.
ALS, Washington. One line: "I am glad to send you what you wish and hope that it may continue to be of interest to you." 1 p.

TLS, Washington. Responding to Elliott's request for a substitute judge in the district court of Minnesota, saying that the new Attorney General, [William D.] Mitchell, will exercise his judgment regarding the matter. 1 p.
TLS, Washington. Thanking him for forming a Taft and Sherman Club in his city.

TLS, New Haven, CT. Declining an invitation to speak at the opening of the Public Library in Kendallville, Indiana, as he is booked with numerous engagements in addition to his regular duties at Yale. 1 p.
TLS, New Haven, CT. Agreeing to autograph some books for J. B. McGee. 1 p.

ALS, Washington. Thanking Nelson for standing by Taft during a painful situation [likely referring to the dissension in the Republican party caused by Theodore Roosevelt's founding of the Progressive "Bull Moose" Party.] 1 p.
ALS, New Haven, CT. Cheerfully agreeing to provide his autograph for Perkins' distinguished collection. 1 p.
TLS, Washington. Notifying him that dinner at Mr. Storer's has been postponed until 8pm. 1 p.
ALS, Office of the Solicitor General. Expressing hope that they will remain friends despite Taft's leaving Washington. 2 pp.
ALS (initials), Cincinnati. Asking Phillips to give his opinion on the legal case of Pickett's heirs, which has been complicated by the death of the counsel for the appellant. 1 p.
ALS, Cincinnati. Complaining about Secretary of the Treasury [Charles] Foster, discussing a couple of legal cases, and complaining that Cincinnati has far more soot than Washington. 2 pp.
ALS, Nashville. Apologizing for a long delay in writing to Hallett, saying as soon as he returns to Cincinnati he will write with an account of his recent travels. 1 p.

ALS, Nashville. Discussing his new position as a criminal judge and his excitement at working under Judge Jackson; describing his family's new home; asking about Washington and the Supreme Court; hoping Phillips will visit; with a postscript about the results of his order that counsel stand up when examining witnesses. 4 pp.
ALS (initials), Cincinnati. Asking Phillips to consider spending his summer vacation with the Tafts at the Lorne House near Quebec. 2 pp.

ALS (initials), Lorne House, Point a Pic. Describing his delight with the buildings, food, and outdoor activities at the Lorne House, asking Phillips to drop everything and join his party; with mention of judges Harlan and Shiras. 6 pp.
ALS (initials), Cincinnati. Regretting that Phillips was unable to join the Tafts on their summer vacation. 2 pp.
TLS, Cincinnati. Discussing various judges and courts. 2 pp.

TLS, Cincinnati. Asking whether he can help Judge Harlan's son obtain a district judgeship; saying he recently saw a mutual friend; responding to recent decisions by the Supreme Court; asking about events in the capital. 2 pp.

TLS, Cincinnati. Expressing disappointment at the results of a recent round of judicial appointments; discussing Judge Harlan's impending trip to Paris; lamenting Folger's resignation; saying he enjoys the circuit court but dislikes the low salary. 2 pp.

TLS, Cincinnati. Approving of the promotion of Judge Jackson though regretting that they will no longer be working together, mentioning the Behring Sea arbitrator, and asking how things are in Washington. 2 pp.
TLS, Cincinnati. Regretting that he can't make a trip, joking about Harlan's tobacco chewing, and stating his jealousy at the "delightful little society" of lawyers and judges now in Washington. 1 p.
TLS, Cincinnati. Asking Phillips to immediately raise support for a bill that would provide for the purchase of law books for circuit courts. 2 pp.

TLS, Cincinnati. Saying he and many others are petitioning President Cleveland to appoint Phillips a judge in the appeals court; recommending Edward B. Whitney, a former classmate and the new Assistant Attorney General; hoping Lloyd Bowers will be made Solicitor General. 2 pp.

TLS, Cincinnati. Expressing annoyance that some of Phillips' friends in Washington are hindering his chances of being appointed judge; hoping that Maury will be retained in his current post; mentioning General Bristow, Edward Whitney, and Storer; commenting on his recent notoriety after issuing a restraining order against the chiefs of the brotherhoods of locomotive engineers and firemen. 2 pp.

TLS, Cincinnati. Thanking Phillips for agreeing with his recent decision in a case, saying that he does not care about the disapproval of "socialists and ignorant heads of labor unions," but does want approval from the bar and bench. 1 p.
ALS, Cincinnati. Thanking Phillips for an amusing letter about senators, commenting on the legality of boycotts, and questioning President [Grover] Cleveland's judicial appointments. 2 pp.

TLS, Cincinnati. Responding to Phillips' entertaining letter and humorous description of Harlan; mentioning a publication that was suppressed; describing his odd but good friend [Edward] Whitney; commending Judge Jackson, and saying that Cleveland is smart to retain Roosevelt. 3 pp.

TLS, Cincinnati. Expressing amusement at [Edward] Whitney's desire to reform the Department of Justice, discussing the international tribunal, asking Phillips to visit the Taft's rustic cottage in Murray Bay, and alleging that Speer was guilty of unjudicial conduct in the Georgis Central case and will likely be impeached and cause a judicial scandal. 4 pp.

TLS, Cincinnati. Giving directions for Phillips to write and visit Point-au-Pic in Quebec, Canada, mentioning his fifteen year class reunion at Yale, and commenting on the "tone of the arbitrator's letters." 2 pp.
ALS (initials), Point au Pic. Regretting that Phillips could not visit their summer cabin and approving the result of an arbitration involving the U.S. and Canada. 1 p.

TLS, Cincinnati. Briefly commenting on many matters including Judge Brown's accident, a movement against the confirmation of Hornblower, mugwumps, the Italian ambassadorship, [Edward] Whitney, and more. 2 pp.
TLS, Cincinnati. Commenting on mutual friends, international arbitration and diplomacy, his work, Folger's position in the navy, Judge Jackson's illnesses, and various issues of the court. 4 pp.
ALS, Cincinnati. Asking for more information about Brown Hill. 1 p.

TLS, Cincinnati. Agreeing that he should do his best to keep up his Washington acquaintances; expressing sorrow that Harlan is getting so old and weak; discussing Hornblower's defeat and Cleveland's handling of the "Hawaiian mess;" mentioning Teddy Roosevelt; analyzing the fight for the District Attorneyship. 4 pp.

TLS, Cincinnati. Annoyed that some judges are under investigation, approving of the appointment of White, suggesting the Democrats will be easily defeated in the next Congressional election, speaking of his work to get funds to buy law books, with mention of various acquaintances. 4 pp.

TLS (initials) with autograph addition, Cincinnati. Addressing the issue of jurisdiction in the Detroit Street Railroad case and discussing mutual friend Bellamy Storer, with mention of various other acquaintances. 2 pp.

TLS, with autograph addition. Friendly banter, questioning why so many American workmen are going on strike, commenting on judicial appointments, and laughing at a humorous but accurate portrayal of Teddy Roosevelt in the New York Sun. 3 pp.

TLS, Cincinnati. Saying he believes Phillips should be the reporter of the Supreme Court; commending the work of Harlan Cleveland; discussing Maxwell's disagreement with the Attorney-General; analyzing the Republican party and support for the gold standard; saying that he may have to leave the bench and go into private practice in order to make enough money for his family; discussing Jackson's illness, etc. 9 pp.

TLS, Cincinnati. Telling of the recent visit of Bellamy [Storer] and Teddy [Roosevelt], saying Judge Jackson's health is remarkably improved, commenting on the opinions of justices Harlan and Gray, and discussing his own opinion that federal judges should wear robes on the circuit. 4 pp.

TLS with autograph postscript, Cincinnati. Asking Phillips to provide some letters of introduction for a friend traveling to Central America, and requesting that he visit J. M. Dickinson, Assistant Attorney-General in the Department of Justice. 2 pp.
TLS, Cincinnati. Thanking him for a favor, commenting on the income tax cases, and remarking on the need to keep marauders and thieves out of the public lands of Yellowstone. 1 p.

TLS, Cincinnati. Commending [Theodore] Roosevelt's acceptance of the position of President of the Board of Police Commissioners of New York; questioning whether Bellamy Storer could handle the Civil Service Commission; commenting on the controversy between Admiral Meade and the Cleveland administration; reporting on friends; wondering what the court will decide regarding the income tax, etc. 5 pp.
TLS, Cincinnati. Discussing Harlan Cleveland's "great error" in expressing his indignation at a decision of the court. 2 pp.
TLS, Cincinnati. Recommending [Judson] Harmon, the newly appointed Attorney General; discussing various issues related to the court. 2 pp.
TLS, Cincinnati. Looking forward to meeting in Washington in the coming weeks, saying McKinley will likely be nominated and Storer will probably be given a commission in France. 2 pp.

TLS, Cincinnati. Discussing whether Harlan will visit Ohio, glad that a bill for another circuit judge has passed the Senate and hopeful that Cleveland and not McKinley will be in charge of the appointment, complaining that Hammond does little work. 3 pp.

ALS (initials). Commending Teddy Roosevelt's success in enforcing the law in New York, regretting his agreeing to give the annual address of the American Bar Association, describing how J. M. Dickinson saved the life of James F. Joy after he fell off a yacht, and discussing various friends in the judicial system, with mention of the death of Jackson. 4 pp. written on legal brief stationery.
TLS, New Haven, CT. Glad to hear she is enjoying music, alluding to her health problems. 1 p.
TLS, Pointe-au-Pic, Canada. Forwarding a signed photograph [included]. 1 p. The photo and letter were presented by Scheuer, an autograph dealer, to Andre De Coppet.
TLS. Marked "Personal." Thanking his friends in Nebraska for their work at the Republican Convention and support of the administration. 1 p. with original envelope.

ALS, Augusta, GA. Stressing that the "regular" Republicans must unite on sound principles in order to avoid the re-election of [Theodore] Roosevelt and/or judicial recall. 1 p. with original envelope.

TLS, New Haven, CT. Marked "Personal & Confidential." On his pleasure at the outcome of the election, namely the collapse of the Progressive Party and the weakening of the Democratic Party; denying the suggestion that he is the much-needed man who can unite the Republican party. 1 p. with original envelope.
TLS, Washington. To the editor of The Independent. Explaining the situation behind a nasty article about Taft written by De Rackin of The Review of Trade. 2 pp.
Of the Pittsfield Eagle.
TLS, New Haven, CT. Noting that the press of Pittsfield is covering small and unimportant events. 1 p. with original envelope.
TLS, New Haven, CT. Thanking him for kind words about Taft's address to the Pittsfield YMCA. 1 p.
TMsS. A tribute to Abraham Lincoln, commending his morals and actions and lamenting his tragic end. 1 p.
AMsS, Washington. Tribute to Theodore Roosevelt reading: "The most commanding, the most original, the most interesting and the most brilliant personality in American public life since Lincoln." 1 p.
Colonial Governor of Connecticut. DS, printed form. Appointing peace officers for the colony of Connecticut. 1 p.
French diplomat. LS, Paris. To John Armstrong. Concerning the return of the American ship Emily, captured by the French. 1 p.

Colonial Governor of Maryland. LS, Annapolis. To James Hamilton, Governor of Pennsylvania. Concerning jurisdiction in the murder of Dudley Digges, which took place on the border of Maryland and Pennsylvania. 3 pp.

American statesman and agriculturist. ALS, Philadelphia. To William Woodford. Describing the honorable conduct of the American troops in contrast to the brutality of the British [at the battles of Lexington and Concord]; relating a story about British General [Thomas] Gage; describing how Americans are "getting into a warlike posture." 3 pp.
American military leader who served as twelfth President of the United States from March 1849 until his death in July 1850.
Filed by recipient.
ALS, Baton Rouge. Acknowledging a request for an autograph, saying that though he is a military man he advocates peace, and commenting on his attitude toward Mexico. 1 p.

LS, Fort Brooke. To the Governor of Georgia. About two murders committed near the Okefanoke [sic] Swamp, measures taken to prevent further crimes, difficulties between regular and militia troops which may arise, help for inhabitants near the swamp, etc. 4 pp.

ALS, Louisville. Sending his returns, complaining about the failure of clothing & supplies to reach the recruiting station at Natchez, and telling of an intemperate soldier he sent back to Louisiana. 2 pp.
ALS, Louisville. Reporting the death of Captain R. Walsh at Natchez, asking for a replacement officer to be sent to the Recruiting Service there. 1 p.
ALS, Louisville. Giving his estimates of moneys needed for bounties, premiums, etc. for the recruiting services in Louisville, Cincinnati, Natchez, and New Orleans. 1 p.

ALS, Tampa. Passing on reports of plunder and murder committed by the Indians, describing his heretofore unsuccessful efforts to get them to stay within the limits of the reservation, calling them "lawless banditti" and saying they must be met with force and exterminated. 3 pp.

ALS, Louisville. Reporting that his health is much improved and he would like to report for duty, requesting assignment in Louisiana as he does not feel well enough to deal with the unfortunate warfare in Florida. 1 p.

ALS, Fort Smith, Arkansas. Marked "Private." Forwarding a recommendation for an army appointment, but stating his own belief that increasing the size of the army is a poor choice due to the state of the country's finances. 1 p.
ALS. Accepting an invitation to dine with officers of the mess of the 4th Infantry. 1 p.
ALS, Baton Rouge. Sending his autograph to the Rough & Ready Club of Cambridge. 1 p.
ALS, Louisville. Acknowledging the arrival of his captain's commission. 1 p.
ALS, Louisville. Reporting on his activities in the recruiting service and the care of stores. 2 pp.

ALS, New York. To the Secretary of War. Recommending P. F. Smith be appointed commander of forces to be raised to serve in Florida, also recommending the promotion of Captains Miller and Hoffman. 2 pp.
ALS, Baton Rouge. Sending his autograph to the granddaughter of his old friend Isaac Shelby. 1 p.
ALS, Baton Rouge. Kindly agreeing to provide an autograph. 1 p.
ALS, "On the Rio Grande." Updating on family matters, directions from Washington relating to negotiations with Mexico, the falling price of cotton, and his own movements about the country. 4 pp.
ALS, Monterey. Accepting honorary membership in the Adelphia Alpha Society of Transylvania University. 1 p.
DS. Ordering the Secretary of State to authorize Benjamin E. Green to conclude a convention with Haiti "upon the subject of claims of citizens of the United States." 1 p.

DS. Confirming the appointment of Robert F. Letcher as envoy to treat with the Mexican government about a road, railroad, or canal across the isthmus of Tehuantepec. Signed also by Secretary of State John M. Clayton. 2 pp.
Served as British Consul General to the United States. This file consists of copies of letters sent by and to British officials. Filed by correspondent.
ALS, New York. Sorry to hear the Marquis has been ill, enclosing a copy of the 23 September letter he sent to the Duke of Leeds (see below). 1 p.
ALS, New York. Forwarding the most recent acts & resolves of the U.S. Congress [not included]. 1 p.

ALS, New York. Reporting that [George] Washington and [John] Adams have been inaugurated, discussing U.S. Congressional proceedings about treaties of commerce with European nations, saying he has spent all his money fulfilling his duties and can no longer afford to entertain any congressmen at his home. 3 pp.

Copy of a letter sent by the Duke of Leeds to Temple, Whitehall. Commanding Temple, by order of the King, to provide information on twelve points concerning the policies and people of the United States. 5 pp.
LS from Temple to the Duke of Leeds, New York. Responding to Leeds' letter of 30 June (above), answering the twelve points of inquiry. 4 pp.

ALS, New York. Forwarding the most recent acts & resolves of the U.S. Congress [not included]; reporting that the American people are exhibiting a remarkable change in behavior since [George] Washington became President: they are much less extravagant, prefer water over alcohol, and are extremely industrious, producing items from carriages to cheese at very low prices compared to Europe. 2 pp.

Union general during the American Civil War. Telegraph sent from Thomas to General Edward Hatch. Announcing [W. T.] Sherman's advance into Georgia and warning him to be on his guard against unexpected action of the enemy. 1 p.
Secretary of the Continental Congress. LS to The Governor of Rhode Island. Sending copies of the journal of Congress [not included]. 1 p.

DS. Testifying knowledge of the premature birth and subsequent illness of the child of Peter and Bethia Thorp. Signed also by three other women: Mary Gill, Rachel Whiting, and Hannah Bullard. Note on the bottom reads: "Sd. Thorpe dismissed with admonition to behave himself better for the future." 1 p.

Governor of Ohio. LS, Columbus. To General Ambrose E. Burnside. Introducing Major J. George Harris, whose young son joined the Confederacy and is now a Union prisoner; asking Burnside to provide any help he can while remaining consistent with his duties. 1 p.

Thirty-third President of the United States. TLS, Washington. To Ernest Angell, President of the Council for Democracy. Thanking Angell for directing him to an article in Life and for his interest in stopping the "vermin press." 1 p.
American statesman, son of Jonathan Trumbull, Sr. (first Governor of Connecticut). Letters filed by recipient.
ALS, Albany. Quoting accounts of the action in the Battle of Saratoga. 4 pp.
ALS, Albany. To his father. Describing the enemy's retreat, saying he sent a fuller account of recent action to his brothers. 1 p.
ALS, Dobbs Ferry. Reporting that the French and American armies have joined harmoniously at Dobbs Ferry, sending news of the campaign in the South, mentioning Nathanael Greene, Lafayette, etc. 3 pp.
ALS, Dobbs Ferry. Reporting an engagement with five or six enemy ships that appeared on the Hudson. 3 pp.

ALS, Dobbs Ferry. Explaining irregularities in returns before the adjutancy of [William] Scammel; giving news of General [Nathanael] Greene and the Marquis de Lafayette; reporting no news from India; discussing the uncertainty of their own prospects. 3 pp.

Minister, compiler of church music. ALS, Newbury. To Ebenezer Stevens. [In the spring of 1724, Native Americans captured three of Stevens' children and took them to Canada. The community rallied and raised ransom money and Stevens was able to redeem the captives.] Informing Stevens that his parish has a contribution towards the ransom money he paid to rescue his children. 1 p.

American Revolutionary officer and Ohio pioneer. ALS, West Point. To Reverend Enos Hitchcock. Reporting frequent desertions from the enemy and the capture of an American picket; describing conditions at West Point where vegetables are scarce but the men are at least well clothed. 2 pp.
Served as tenth President of the United States from 1841 to 1845.
Filed by recipient.
ALS, Sherwood Forest. Replying to an inquiry about the heirs of John Hardyman. 1 p.
ALS, Washington. Thanking them for sending their "Manual of gold and silver coins of all nations struck within the last century." 1 p.
ALS, Sherwood Forest. Complaining about the "unreasonable designs" of a Mr. Chaney, wondering about the possibility of a lawsuit rather than proceeding with his requests. 2 pp.
ALS. Asking for information about the New York Commission--when it ended and under what orders the commissioners were paid. 1 p.
ALS, Sherwood Forest. Questioning Johns' decision to call a conference to announce his acceptance of the presidency at the College of William & Mary. 2 pp.

ALS, President's Mansion. Rescheduling a dinner engagement at which Mr. and Mrs. [James K.] Polk are also to be present because the original date is the anniversary of the Princeton accident in which Mrs. Tyler's father died. 1 p.
DS. Ordering the Secretary of State to affix the Seal of the United States to the duplicate of an execution granted to Lawrence A. Edmonston. 1 p.

did.unittitle: United States. Army of the Potomac

scopecontent.p: Various official documents from the Army of the Potomac. The majority are affiliated with the IV Corps under the direction of General Erasmus Darwin Keyes.

Circulars issued by General George B. McClellan concerning everything from supplies to muster rolls to care of the sick. These copies are signed by Assistant Adjutant General S[eth] Williams and were sent to Major General [Erasmus Darwin] Keyes. 25 items.
Official military correspondence. Filed by recipient, with a miscellaneous folder at the end.
Official letters written to Keyes from various army officers concerning army positioning, enemy reconnaissance, supplies, returns, etc.
Unknown sender. Transmitting General McClellan's order for cavalry to go back towards Turkey Bridge. On two small slips of paper.
From Thomas A. Osburn. In reference to the position of his brigade, with a pencil sketch. 1 p. plus sketch.
From Seth Williams. Refusing Keyes' request for the services of Nicholas Bowen, a topographical engineer. 1 p. with docketing.
From Seth Williams. Giving instructions in case of an attack by the enemy. 2 pp. with docketing.
Printed form letter from the U.S. Coast Survey Office, sending maps [not included]. 1 p.
Forwarding a report from a reconnaissance man in Colonel Griggs' cavalry. 1 p. with 1 p. report.
From Seth Williams. Directing that the signal officer on duty with the 4th corps be in communication with gun boats. 1 p. with docketing.
From Seth Williams. Directing that the pieces of Keyes' command be discharged a day later than planned. 1 p. with docketing.
From F. J. D'Avignon. Explaining his reasons for excusing sick men. 1 p.
From William F. Barry. Regarding new guns, caissons, and carriages to replace damaged ones, and a new battery for Captain McKnight. 2 pp. with docketing.
From William F. Barry. Reporting on new batteries for Captains McKnight and Brady. 1 p.
From R.B. Marcy. Giving orders for a brigade to march on the road towards Malvern Hill and find a defensible point. 1 p. with docketing.
From Seth Williams. Ordering blank lists of corps staff, divisions, brigades, regiments, and batteries to be filled out and sent back. 1 p. with docketing.
From Seth Williams. Asking whether Keyes has the prescribed number of rounds of ammunition for artillery and small arms. 1 p. with docketing.
From R.B. Marcy. Relating to the order of an upcoming march. 1 p. with docketing.
From R.B. Marcy. Requesting that two regiments be temporarily placed at Yorktown and two others at Gloucester Point. 1 p. with docketing.
From R.B. Marcy. Telegram ordering a working party for the defense of Yorktown as soon as tools can be obtained. 1 p. with docketing.
From R.B. Marcy. Stating that Yorktown has the necessary supplies for the troops, directing Keyes to confer with Lt. Col. Alexander about working parties. 1 p. with docketing.
From R.B. Marcy. Rescinding an order to send a brigade to Williamsburg. 1 p. with docketing.
From George B. McClellan. Ordering a battery to be placed in the works at Gloucester. 1 p. with docketing.
From Seth Williams. Orders in relation to the 5th and 11th Pennsylvania cavalries. 1 p. with docketing.
From Seth Williams. Directing Colonel Campbell to remain in his current position. 1 p. with docketing.
From Seth Williams. Assigning General Peck as superintendent of the works about Yorktown and Gloucester Point. 1 p. with docketing.
From John J. Peck. Requesting that five officers be detailed to take charge of the working party for the defense of Yorktown and Gloucester Point. 1 p. with docketing.
From John J. Peck. Estimating it will take 12 to 15 days to complete the work ordered by the board of engineers and General McClellan. 1 p. with docketing.
From Theodore McGowan. Concerning a trivial issue involving Captain Fullwood. 1 p.
From David Campbell. Reporting all quiet along his picket line; waiting for the results of a reconnoitering party near New Kent and Providence Forge. 1 p. with docketing.
From D.T. Van Buren. Asking for men to serve as members of a court martial for the trial of Lt. Col. Confort. 1 p. with docketing.
From Henry M. Hoyt. Passing on reports of flagrant outrages and pillaging by soldiers. 1 p. with docketing.
From David Campbell. Concerning recent reconnaissance and the capture of five prisoners. 1 p. with docketing.
From George Clark. Requesting contraband to assist in embarking cavalry. 1 p. with docketing.
From D.T. Van Buren. Asking for the monthly return for September. 1 p. with docketing.
From J.J. DeForest. Requesting that Joshua Norton, Jr. be allowed to sell whatever sutler stores he has on hand. 1 p. with docketing.
From Foxhall H. Parker. Acknowledging a planned attack on Gloucester Point, asking for use of the May Queen. 1 p. with docketing.
From George Clark. Requesting the Lt. Sewall be ordered to turn over a horse. 1 p. with docketing.
Letters written to Assistant Adjutant General Suydam, largely dealing with administrative issues.
From John J. Peck. In reference to orderlies for his headquarters. 1 p. with docketing.
From B.W. Dawson. Submitting a list of officers of his brigade now absent without authority. 2 pp. with docketing.
From Robert M. West. Asking for information concerning light batteries in the 4th corps. 1 p. with docketing.
From T.F. Lehman. Nominating men for the recruiting service as they are not fit for active field duty. 1 p. with docketing.
From Robert M. West. Regarding Battery A of the 1st Pennsylvania artillery. 1 p. with docketing.
From J. G. Farnsworth. Reporting on entrenching tools. 1 p. with docketing.
From William H. Morris. Asking whether old guards are permitted to fire their pieces after marching off. 1 p. with a draft response on the back.
From Robert M. West. Reporting 1st Lieutenant Eugene W. Sherburne as discharged from the service. 1 p. with docketing.
From Thomas H. Neill. Reporting that the military board is suspended due to the absence of Colonel Frank Wheaton. 1 p.
From William H. Morris. Sending four men from the third Brigade. 1 p.
From William H. Morris. Sending five men for the reserve artillery. 1 p.
From William H. Morris. Sending a sixth man for the reserve artillery. 1 p.
From J. G. Farnsworth. Saying he needs more teamsters and a cook. 1 p.
From J. J. Abercrombie. Nominating men for promotion. 1 p. with docketing.
From Robert M. West. Recommending changes in the position of the corps artillery. 1 p. with docketing.
From J. J. Abercrombie. Sending a list of men killed and wounded in the battle of Fair Oaks [list not included]. 1 p.
From John J. Peck. Asking for more time for a review of his division. 1 p. with docketing.
From J. Jordan. Inquiring about a resignation he submitted. 1 p.
From James Brad. Asking for twenty additional men to help fill his battery. 1 p. with docketing.
From Robert M. West. Requesting a new driver for his hospital team as the old one deserted. 1 p. with docketing.
From a brigadier general [name illegible]. Submitting names of volunteers for the reserve batteries. 2 pp.
From Robert M. West. Stating the number of men required for the reserve artillery. 1 p. with docketing.
From Waller (?). Asking for a guide who knows the way to Haxall's. 1 p.
From Robert M. West. Reporting a survey made at the front. 1 p. with docketing.
From S. G. B [unintelligible]. Sending names of men for the reserve batteries. 1 p.
From R.V. King. Sending names of men for the reserve batteries. 1 p.
From Nicholas W. Day. Nominating officers from Peck's division for the ambulance corps. 1 p. with docketing.
From Robert M. West. Asking for investigation into a man known only as "L.H.G.," who allegedly abused soldiers. 2 pp. with docketing.
From Robert M. West. Requesting that replacement surgeons be provided to the batteries. 2 pp. with docketing.
From J. G. Farnsworth. Requesting an inspection of two ambulances that appear to be unfit for service. 1 p. with docketing.
From Robert M. West. Transmitting papers relating to Private John Wiley, requesting he be restored to duty without trial. 1 p. with 5 attachments.
From Floyd Clarkson. Forwarding charges against Robert Crozier. 2 pp. with docketing.
From J. J. Abercrombie. Forwarding a nominal list of officers of the regular army serving with his command. 1 p. with docketing.
From Nicholas W. Day. Forwarding the names of officers from General Couch's division for the ambulance corps. 1 p. with docketing.
From Robert M. West. Reporting that a portion of the meat ration for his command is unfit for consumption. 1 p. with docketing.
From Robert M. West. Requesting that in the event of a march to Fortress Monroe, the artillery be allowed to move in the advance. 1 p. with docketing.
From Charles E. Pease. Requesting aid for the sick left at Yorktown and a guard for the public stores. 1 p. with docketing.
From Dan Lodor. Concerning passes to visit Fort Monroe. 1 p. with docketing.
From Wilson Barstow. Requesting lists of divisions, brigades, and regiments of the 4th corps to assist in forwarding stragglers. 1 p. with docketing.
From T. G. Orwig. Submitting a report of the condition of his battery at the time of muster. 2 pp. with docketing.
From Lt. Howard. A telegram regarding an unnamed general. 1 p. with docketing.
From George Clark. Requesting a man be detailed as soon as possible. 1 p. with docketing.
From Henry M. Hoyt. Requesting to be relieved as provost marshal of the 4th corps. 1 p. with docketing.
From J. P. Wilson. Telegram reporting that three men who took Mr. Sweeney's horse were acting under orders. 1 p. with docketing.
From Henry M. Hoyt. Stating the instructions he gave to his sergeant regarding the mail boat. 1 p. with docketing.
From J. P. Wilson. Asking if he can use recruits to fill the spots of 50 men who have reported absent or sick and have not been discharged or deserted. 1 p. with docketing.
From Cadwallader. Reporting that the trial nurses have all proved themselves to be fit for the job and should be regularly detailed. 1 p. with docketing.
From Andrew Fagan. Reporting that James Bambrick, a deserter, is requesting to be restored to duty. 2 pp. with docketing plus another small slip of paper.

From Floyd Clarkson. Reporting that General Dix cannot give him a leave of absence and he therefore must ask for a resignation as there is no place for him and other officers to sleep at Fort Monroe. 1 p. with docketing.
From Floyd Clarkson. Tendering his resignation. 2 pp.
From Joshua Norton, Jr. Requesting the position of post sutler at Yorktown. Sending recommendations signed by commissioned officers. 1 p. with four enclosed recommendation letters.
From G.B. Dandy. Suggesting two men who were serving with the quartermaster department on extra duty be ordered to rejoin their companies. 1 p. with docketing.
From Henry M. Hoyt. Relating to the sale of goods from vessels. 1 p. with docketing.
From A. Faith. Reporting that he has taken command of the 5th Pennsylvania Cavalry. 1 p. with docketing.
From John Carter Brown. Asking for action against Ferdinand Levy, who has resigned but refuses to hand over the muster roll of his company. 2 pp. with docketing.
From David Bower. Reporting the condition of the Williamsburg sawmill and the repairs needed to get it in working order. With an estimate of the cost of materials and work. 2 pp. with docketing.
From W.G. McCandless. Forwarding discharges and reminding Suydam that there are others to which he should attend. 1 p. with docketing.
From J.J. DeForest. Reporting that artillery practice earlier in the day came close to hurting some soldiers chopping wood. 1 p. with docketing.
From D.T. Van Buren. Relating to his monthly report. 1 p. with docketing.
From William Lewis. Requesting that a number of unserviceable horses be replaced. 1 p with docketing.
Forwarded by J.G. Farnsworth. Describing a horse and reporting its value. 1 p. with docketing.
From John Nicholson. Asking that two of his men serving with the provost guard be returned. 1 p. with docketing.
From H. M. Plaisted. Requesting that five of his men detached to Fitch's battery be returned to their regiment. 1 p. with docketing.
From William Lewis. Requesting that new recruits be collected and transported to his regiment. 1 p. with docketing.
From M.G. Cushing. Forwarding an application for a furlough for Louis Wunch. 1 p. with docketing.
Letters addressed to the Assistant Adjutant General reporting news and requesting certain military actions. 5 items.
From J.S. Belknap. Recommending some promotions. 1 p. with docketing.
From John J. Peck. Requesting that a regular battery be assigned to his command. 1 p. with docketing.
From A.T. Watson. Reporting the death of captain George T. Lewis. 1 p. with docketing.
From Seth Williams. Forwarding a letter regarding digging wells and procuring water for the troops. 3 pp. with docketing.
From E.D. Keyes. Requesting that an additional squadron of cavalry be assigned to the 4th corps. 1 p. with docketing.
Letters to and from military officers of varying ranks.
From Seth Williams to the Office of the Provost Marshall. Ordering the Commissary of Subsistence at Ship Point to issue rations to the family of John R. Walter. 1 p. with docketing.
From W.A. Emory to Captain Morris. Recommending Captain Dandy be appointed a colonel. With a note from John J. Peck on the back. 2 pp.
From a colonel [illegible] to General Howe. Providing names for a detail. 1 p. with docketing.
Bill/receipt from William Laverey to the U.S. Government for 125 bushels of wheat. 1 p.
From H.A. Walker to Oswald Jackson. Reporting that no one from the 1st division has visited Fortress Monroe on any pass or order from the commanding officer. 1 p. with docketing.
From Charles E. Pease to Oswald Jackson. Reporting that the 5th Pennsylvania Cavalry is not under the command of General Van Allen. 1 p. with docketing.

From B.B. Foster to Captain Jackson. Sending a query from General Peck as to who will continue work on the fortifications now that General Couch's working party has been withdrawn. 1 p. with docketing.
From W.A. Emory to Foster. Requesting that the soon to be disbanded 8th N.Y. Militia hand over their arms and accoutrements to a group of newly arrived recruits. 1 p. with docketing.
From Charles E. Pease to Oswald Jackson. Requesting an order detailing fifty men for Post Guard. 1 p. with docketing.
From J.G. Farnsworth to Oswald Jackson. Requesting officers and men to form a guard for the wagon train at headquarters. 1 p.
From David Bower to General Haglee. Concerning the issuing of a receipt to Mr. Lavery for wheat he provided. 1 p. with docketing.

Printed form letter from James W. Ripley of the Ordnance Office to the commanding officer of the works at Yorktown, VA. Requesting an inventory of all the ordnance and ordnance stores at Yorktown. 1 p. with docketing.
From E.P.M. Kinney to John A. Dix. Reporting the murder of Captain D.C. Hannahs. 2 pp.
From William P. Hall to an unknown major. Enclosing passes for a Mrs. Newman, reporting that people are daily leaving Williamsburg for Richmond. 1 p. with docketing.
From Phineas Stanton to Captain George H. Johnston. Reporting progress on the works at Gloucester Point. 1 p. with docketing.

From W. Kreutzer to Captain George H. Johnston. Requesting that Colonel Durkee, Lt. Colonel Weed, and Major Clarke be ordered before a military commission as he believes they are unfit to hold their present positions. 1 p. with docketing.
From W.W.H. Davis to George H. Johnston. Requesting that his quartermaster be ordered to Alexandria to bring recruits, convalescents, and rifles. 1 p. with docketing.
From Riley Johnson to an unnamed general. Requesting that his company blacksmith, currently in the service of Major Floyd Clarkson, be ordered back to his company. 1 p. with docketing.
From L. Thomas to John A. Dix. Relating to extra commissioned and non-commissioned officers of batteries. 2 pp.
From Floyd Clarkson to Captain Jackson. Saying he cannot spare his blacksmith. 1 p. with docketing.
From Charles Durkee to George H. Johnston. Requesting that a board of survey be appointed to inspect his regiment's tents, as he believes they are unfit for winter use. 1 p. with docketing.

From Samuel G. Sewall to George H. Johnston. Reporting the numbers of cattle, sheep and horses captured for the U.S. Army from persons residing in the vicinity of Gloucester House, VA. 3 pp. with docketing.
From Leonard F. Hepburn to Henry W. Benson. Notifying Benson that he must report to General Davis at Fort Monroe. 1 p. with docketing.
From J.T. Seawell to Colonel Davis. Asking for information in regard to purchasing back his two horses. 1 p. with docketing.
From Henry C. Knoop to D.T. Van Buren. Requesting that Monroe T. Bennett be ordered to join his corps. 1 p. with docketing.
From C. N. Otis to George H. Johnston. Reporting that an attack is to be made on Gloucester Point tonight. 1 p. with docketing.
From Charles Durkee to George H. Johnston. Requesting that all men belonging to his command on detached service at Yorktown be returned to his regiment. 1 p. with docketing.
A note to a captain reporting all is quiet on his front. 1 p.
Court martial proceedings from approximately twenty military trials in the second half of 1862. Many of the trials have multiple documents associated with them.
Discharges, many by order of General George B. McClellan and signed by Assistant Adjutant General S[eth] Williams. Most were sent to General Erasmus Darwin Keyes. 38 items.
General orders concerning various military persons and activities. 9 items.
Requests for a leave of absence from the Army of the Potomac, addressed to various generals. 9 items.
Granted leaves of absence, many issued by General George B. McClellan, signed by Assistant Adjutant General S[eth] Williams and sent to General Erasmus Darwin Keyes. 51 items total.
Various lists of casualties, inventories, personnel, etc. Many associated with the 4th army corps. 23 items.
Papers relating to the recruiting service including special orders, lists, and nominations. 21 items.
Resignations from officers of the Army of the Potomac, mostly due to poor health. 24 items.

Special orders from the Army of the Potomac relating to assignments and appointments of individuals or small groups. Many are copies or extracts sent to Major General [Erasmus Darwin] Keyes and signed by S[eth] Williams, Assistant Adjutant General. 64 items.

Special orders from the Army of the Potomac relating to the regulation of conduct and operations in the army. Many were issued by command of General George B. McClellan, signed by Assistant Adjutant General S[eth] Williams, and sent to General [Erasmus Darwin] Keyes. 18 items.
Miscellaneous receipts and slips of paper. 7 items.

This file consists of various official documents of the Continental Army. Researchers should note that the Andre De Coppet Collection contains many other materials related to the Continental Army and Revolutionary War, which are filed under the names of specific authors and correspondents.

DS, Lancaster, Pennsylvania. Signed by 42 British officers of General John Burgoyne's army, taken as prisoners of the United States [known as Convention prisoners], agreeing to conditions of parole. 2 pp.

Muster rolls of various New England companies, signed by captains, with multiple under Colonels Samuel B. Webb, Edward Wigglesworth, and Henry Sherburne. Two are housed in the Box 46 (oversize) and signed by George Clinton. 37 items.
Pay rolls of various New England companies, signed by captains, with numerous under Colonels Samuel B. Webb and Henry Sherburne. 97 items, foldered by year with one in Box 46 (oversize).

Eleven bills for rations for regiments and individuals, receipted, from Massachusetts and Rhode Island. With an ADS from Ebenezer Hancock [Deputy Paymaster General] to Benjamin Stelle referring to ration abstracts. 12 items.
Warrants for the payment of various companies and officers. Each is signed by one of three generals: William Heath, Horatio Gates, or John Sullivan. 25 items.

Resolve that no British Prisoners be released until all accounts are settled for provisioning and clothing them. Passed in response to British Commander in Chief Sir William Howe's requirements that the Colonists provision the American prisoners. 2 pp.
Resolve requiring every officer commissioned by Congress to swear an oath of allegiance to the United States and declare no allegiance to George III. 1 p.

Resolve requiring commanding officers to furnish the Regimental Paymaster with detailed pay rolls at the end of every month; also calling for the hiring of a number of auditors to oversee the accounts. 2 pp.
