Consists of a November 1, 1783 report faulting the states for failing to keep up their representation in Congress, followed by an April 19, 1784 resolution to increase the representation of each state from two to three delegates. Signed Charles Thomson, Secretary. 2 pp.
Resolve to provide for officers who have been disabled in the service of the United States. Signed Charles Thomson, Secretary. 2 pp.
An Ordinance for the Establishment of the Mint of the United States of America; and for Regulating the Value and Alloy of Coi0. Signed Charles Thomson, Secretary. 1 p.

Copy of a handwritten resolution congratulating General Rochambeau and Admiral Des Touches on the Chesapeake expedition of the French fleet. Signed by Secretary Charles Thomson. With a French translation. 3 pp total.
Served as eight President of the United States from 1837-1841.
Filed by recipient.
ALS. Discussing a Major Spilman of North Carolina, who has requested some favor. 2 pp.
ALS. Introducing the bearer, William Darlington, who is deaf & dumb but of great intelligence and can help Cutts complete a job before the next meeting of Congress. 2 pp.
ALS, Lebanon Springs. Introducing Charles P. Kirkland of Utica. 2 pp.
ALS, New York. Asking her to forward an enclosure to a Miss Wadsworth. 1 p.
ALS, Belfast. Describing his visit to Ireland and discussing future travel plans. 10 pp.
ALS, Lindenwald. About a cactus and orange tree he is sending and enclosing a letter for her to read and enjoy [not included]. 5 pp.
ALS. Asking the Senate to postpone adjournment as the President [Andrew Jackson] will likely address Congress on the subject of Colonial Trade in the next few days.
ALS, Albany. Wishing him better health, saying that a promised letter about the Presidency is better suited to a discussion. 2 pp.
DS. Ordering the Secretary of State to affix the Seal of the United States to an order concerning a penalty incurred by the steamer Semaphone. 1 p.
Friend of Aaron Burr, served as his second in the duel with Alexander Hamilton. ALS to T. W. Oliott[?]. Explaining his failure to pay a note. 1 p.
ANS. Note of Van Rensselaer to the Trustees of the Albany Academy promising to pay back $100 with interest. 1 p.
ALS, New York. To his brother, Richard Varick. Reporting on clothing for officers, the British being driven from Boston, and the strength of New York; sending a new pair of shoes. 2 pp.
Letters to Richard Varick, his brother.

ALS, New York. Describing his service with the Fusiliers under Livingston and the building of fortifications at New York; saying the British evacuation from Boston has enthused the nation and left only the British fleet to be feared; mentioning rumors of the British on Bedloe's Island. 2 pp.

ALS, New York. Describing a dispute over whether [H.B] Livingston can rightfully and successfully command two companies; saying he is flattered that Dr. Middleton has left him in charge of his house and finances while he travels to Bermuda; reporting that captured Tories have refused to take an oath; with news of friends and family. 3 pp.

ALS, New York. Updating about the status of a dispute involving [H.B.] Livingston; expressing annoyance that the Doctor [Middleton] has not returned from the West Indies; reporting companies in New Jersey who refuse to take up arms; describing a troubling letter circulating New York; passing news of a lack of food in Bermuda. 3 pp.

ALS, New York. Saying he has been called as part of the draft, updating on Doctor [Middleton], complaining about the allegiances of Governor [William] Tryon [with reference to the Hickey plot], giving account of a trip to Long Island to apprehend an accused man. 2 pp.
American Revolutionary officer and politician in the New York/New Jersey region.
Filed by recipient.
ALS, Tusculum. On banking business, referring to the Manhattan and Branch directors, with mention of Oliver Wolcott. 2 pp.
ALS, Albany. Ordering him to send an account of the clothing he sent to General Schuyler so that the soldiers may be charged accordingly. 1 p.
ANS on the bottom of an April 10 letter from John Keese to Philip Schuyler. Directing Rensselaer to receive a cask of goods belonging to Oneida chiefs. 1 p.
ALS, New York. Referring to a claim on the Van Rensselaer family, the Merchants' Bank, and yellow fever in the city. 3 pp.
DS. Bill for court costs in the case of William Boyd versus Joshua Sears. Varick issued a tax and signed the document as Recorder. 1 p.
ADS. Sworn statement as attorney for the defendant in a case before the Court of Errors of the city of New York. Signed also by Robert Yates. 1 p.
DS. Transferring land in New Brunswick (NJ) from John Tench to Robert Bourne. Signed by Varick as mayor of New York. 4 pp.

American politician from Massachusetts, served in the House of Representatives. ALS, Washington. To Massachusetts Governor C[hristopher] Gore. Answer to a request for an alteration in the Post Office law. 3 pp.
Miscellaneous documents related to Virginia.
Letter to the Committee of Safety from commissioners appointed to recommend methods of payment to claimants who served in an expedition "against the Indians." Signed by the four commissioners. 2 pp.
DS. Provision return for the 1st Virginia Regiment and Company of Artillery, Winchester.
American merchant and politician from Connecticut. Letters filed by recipient.

ALS, Stamford. To Messrs. Arnold, Brown and Francis. In confidence, recommending that the Federalists of Rhode Island rally and appeal to the government of the United States in an effort to overthrow the state's current administration and become part of the union. 3 pp.
LS, Paris. Giving a list of expenses to be charged to different accounts. 1 p.
ANS, Danville. To General [P.G.T] Beauregard. Asking if he might see General Johnston if he came to Greensboro. ANS by Beauregard notes that Johnston will not arrive for another day. 1 p.
American statesman from Virginia. Letters filed by recipient.

ALS, Williamsburg. Referring to the arrival of the French fleet and the impending capture of [Benedict] Arnold, reporting the status of some vessels, and saying the Baron is extremely sorry for his late conduct in respect to Jefferson. 2 pp.

ALS, Philadelphia. Mentioning some business with the Board of War, saying the enemy is currently inactive at Elizabethtown but will not remain so, reporting that Americans are setting a "glorious example" by recruiting and feeding the army at private expense. 2 pp.

American Revolutionary officer and statesman. DS, Boston. Warrant ordering Ebenezer Hancock, Deputy Paymaster General of the Army of the United Colonies, to pay Asa Whetcomb a specified amount for the foot regiment under his command. Signed also by Joseph Ward and Asa Whetcomb. On the back is a table of the wages due the various officers of the regiment. 2 pp.
American Revolutionary officer and statesman. Letters filed by recipient.

LS, Milton. Discussing the advantages and disadvantages of various methods of taxation to raise money for government expenses and the question as to whether or not negroes should be counted in the poll tax. 5 pp.

ALS, Plymouth. Reporting on a whaling vessel with a disappointing return of only 100 barrels, describing the ship and the possibility of a sale, planning to settle accounts with Colonel Hancock and Major Otis. 1 p.

British naval officer. LS, Bermuda, on board H.M.S. Swiftsure. Marked "Duplicate." To Vice Admiral John Duckworth. Reporting on the French squadron and various British ships, saying that recruiting in the American Army suggests hostilities are more than probable. 2 pp.

George Washington was first President of the United States of America (1789-1797) and commander-in-chief of the Continental Army during the American Revolutionary War. This collection of letters and documents written by Washington includes correspondence with some of the most well-known early Americans including John Adams, Nathanael Greene, John Hancock, Thomas Jefferson, and James Madison.

The earliest items in the series are Virginia land surveys conducted by Washington in the 1750s. The bulk of the material dates from the years of the Revolutionary War (1775-1783). Many of the letters detail the countless important decisions Washington was forced to make as commander of America's revolutionary forces, from issues of staffing and rank to how to adequately provision soldiers with clothing and food. He wrote of his frustration with short enlistments and the need for more soldiers, and defended his decision to have the troops winter at Valley Forge.

The series also includes letters and documents from Washington's time as President. His letters address questions of constitutional and congressional powers, and highlight some of the ways the new country navigated international diplomacy. The documents section contains two and half pages of an undelivered inaugural address in Washington's hand.
A handful of personal letters and documents include lists of slaves divided between Washington and his brothers, and directions for the running of his Mount Vernon estate.

The correspondence is arranged alphabetically by name of correspondent. The Papers of George Washington (University of Virginia Press, 1976-2008), an extensive project to publish all of Washington's writings, has not been completed at the time of this writing (August 2008), though many volumes have been published. Those volumes that have been published were consulted during the preparation of this finding aid. Letters in this collection that are published contain a bracketed notation in the item description citing the series, volume, and page numbers. It should also be noted that the full text and footnotes of the volumes can also be accessed digitally at http://rotunda.upress.virginia.edu/pgwde.
Patrons will be given access to surrogate, photoduplicated copies of the Washington materials.
ALS. Referring to a picture sent by Adams, most likely of Washington himself. 1 p.

LS, Cambridge. Saying recent intelligence suggests the defense of the Continent will not be as hard as once thought; reporting General Howe has forced the enemy to evacuate Boston and they have left considerable stores behind; dispatching troops to New York in anticipation of the British fleet moving to the area. 3 pp. [Revolutionary War Series, Vol. 3: 497-498]

LS, Morristown. Agreeing that three Virginia companies should be combined into one, but refusing to promote Captain [Charles Mynn] Thruston, apparently to avoid being accused of partiality to Virginians. 3 pp. [Revolutionary War Series, Vol. 8: 442-443]

LS, Morristown. Expressing surprise that Colonel Morgan is at Hackensack, saying that Alexander can go to Baskenridge only if a proposed attack on Staten Island is cancelled, ordering Dayton & Ogden's corps to stay where they are for the moment. 1 p. [Revolutionary War Series, Vol. 10: 443]
Draft ALS (initials), Mount Vernon. Giving the price of 400 acres of his land in Gloucester County, with terms of sale. 1 p.

LS, Philadelphia, in the hand of Thomas Jefferson. To the U.S. consul at Morocco. Saying that in the event of an accident to John Paul Jones, recently appointed consul to Algiers, Barclay is authorized to take over his functions; mentioning payments to be made. 2 pp. [Presidential Series, Vol. 10: 450-1]
ANS, written in third person. Asking Bingham to deliver a letter to [Henry] Knox, wishing him a safe journey, and sending a copy of Sir John Sinclair's work on manures [not included]. 1 p.

LS. Acknowledging Bland's message received at daybreak; outlining the orders he gave for the Continental troops to march and meet the Convention troops; saying none of the officers may enter New York but their letters may. 1 p.

ALS. Answering their protest [to the Jay Treaty] by saying that he has always acted in the interest of the country as a whole and has been given the power to make treaties under the Constitution--"the guide which I never can abandon." 2 pp.

LS. Acknowledging Brodhead's letter of complaint about General [Lachlan] McIntosh, explaining his decision not to take action at this time since no formal charges have been brought against McIntosh, pointing out the delicacy of the situation and the need for impartial justice. 3 pp.
LS, Head of Elk. Making clear that Brodhead should have resigned his command at Fort Pitt prior to his trial, appointing Colonel Gibson in his place effective immediately. 1 p.

ALS, Philadelphia. Thanking him for taking initiative and handling some business involving Mr. Henry, asking about the result of his communications with Colonel [James] I[nne]s, inquiring after the probable outcome of the Assembly session. 2 pp.

ALS, Mount Vernon. Denouncing France, confirming his acceptance of the command of the American army, saying he has nominated Carrington for Quartermaster General, with his ideas of France's probable point of attack. [Retirement Series, Vol. 2: 416-7]

ALS, Valley Forge. Saying that a rumor of Canada's accession to the union is false; complaining about Virginia's failure to raise adequate troops; confidently asserting that there is no longer a faction of men seeking to see Washington superseded in command [The "Conway Cabal"]; dismissing the actions of the British Prime Minister; reporting his belief that the enemy will soon evacuate Philadelphia and move towards New York; mocking someone who attempted to write false letters under Washington's name which suggested he was an enemy to independence. 6 pp. [Revolutionary War Series, Vol. 15: 267-70]

Partial LS. Consisting of non-consecutive pages of a circular LS sent to the all states. The letter addresses a lack of support for the army, the uncertainty of British plans, and Washington's wish to end the war without overstepping his position. [A copy of the complete letter may be found in the folder. The recipient of this exact copy is unknown.] 4 pp.

LS. Thanking Clark for the intelligence he has gathered and sending a list of questions for his emissaries and spies to answer as best they can [list not included]. Saying the rumors of Lord Cornwallis' captivity are false. Asking who John Fox is. 1 p. [Revolutionary War Series, Vol. 12: 386]

LS, Morristown. Saying they must take the field early and defeat the enemy before they have a chance to call for reinforcements; thanking Clinton for promised reinforcements; asking for the names of four captains. 1 p. [Revolutionary War Series, Vol. 8: 143-4]

LS, Springfield. Discussing the measures he has taken to properly provision Fort Schuyler; expressing concern that Colonel [Goose] Van Schaick's troops are discontented, directing a restructuring of command at Fort Schuyler to alleviate the problem; commending Clinton for his expedition against Sir John [Johnston]; with mention of recent occurrences in Charleston. 4 pp.

LS, Verplank's Point. Referring to the case of a French soldier involved with the civil authorities; suggesting the Continental troops be withdrawn from northern New York; giving plans for the coming winter and asking for Clinton's input. 3 pp.
LS, Rocky Hill. Coordinating plans with Clinton and General [Henry] Knox to take over New York once the British evacuate; announcing that a definitive treaty has been signed. 2 pp.
ALS, New Windsor. Ordering Major Davis to report to George Clinton (Governor of New York) to help recruit men for the army in the Northern and Western part of the state. 2 pp.
Governor of Rhode Island.
LS, Cambridge Camp. Thanking Cooke for a message on his appointment to the chief command of the American army. [Revolutionary War Series, Vol. 1: 128-9]

ALS, Cambridge. Discussing supplies of beef and pork; reporting Bowen got the cannon he desired; forwarding the proceedings of a Congressional committee [not included]. 2 pp. [Revolutionary War Series, Vol. 2: 286]

LS, Morristown. Discussing state quotas for the army and the need for states to better provision their men. Demanding a better system for keeping track of prisoners exchanged with the enemy. 2 pp. [Revolutionary War Series, Vol. 8: 496-7]
LS. Objecting to a recent hasty verdict from a court martial which recommended a death sentence for five people, saying the offenders should be turned over to civil authorities. 2 pp.
Draft of a letter in Washington's hand written for his wife, signed "M. Washington." Thanking Fitzsimons for a gift of coffee. 2 pp.

LS. Regretting that a number of officers have decided to leave the service at this stage; giving directions for handling the discharge of Major Bradish; sending General Howe to take command in Glover's quarter; commenting on the scarcity of rum. 1 p.

ALS, New York. Thanking him for some intelligence; questioning whether Artemas Ward ("Genl W") is fit to command troops; saying fortifications are rapidly coming together; thanking God for an intercepted letter from Lord George Germains to Governor [Robert] Eden. 4 pp. [Revolutionary War Series, Vol. 4: 285-7]

ALS, Mount Vernon. Inquiring after some hounds; agreeing with the idea of adopting coinage of gold, silver & copper; discussing his support of greater Congressional power; responding to a report on western lands; and reporting on his efforts to improve navigation of the Potomac. 3 pp. [Confederation Series, Vol. 3: 193-195]

LS, Middlebrook. Reporting his estimates of the enemy's forces at New York and Rhode Island, updating on the strength and location of American troops, expressing doubt that the states will come through with promised reinforcements, and asking for suggestions for a plan of conduct in light of short supplies and depreciating money. 2 pp. [The same exact LS was sent to Henry Knox (see below).]

ALS, Passaic Falls. Appointing Greene to the command of the southern army in response to Major General [Horatio] Gates' recent failures [at the Battle of Camden]. Directing Greene to provide information for William Heath, his own replacement. 3 pp.
ALS. Responding to Greene's request to spend a little time at home before reporting for duty as commander of the southern army; denying the request as the British are already on the move. 2 pp.

LS, Preakness. Official orders for Greene to take command of the southern army aided by Baron de Steuben and [Henry] Lee, as well as oversee a court of inquiry into the conduct of [Horatio] Gates. 4 pp.
LS, New Windsor. Asking Greene to investigate the case of Captain [Joseph] Eggleston, who has been accused of unmilitary and unwarrantable conduct in dealing with a deserter, Peter Bainbridge. 1 p.

LS with autograph postscript, New Windsor. Describing his meeting with the Comte de Rochambeau and the decision to attack the enemy at New York. Updating on the movement and location of various troops with mention of Baron Steuben, the Marquis de Lafayette, and General [Anthony] Wayne. 7 pp.

LS, Philadelphia. Describing a plan [developed by Robert Morris] to provide clothes for officers of the American Army by issuing certificates redeemable for clothing at various merchants. After six months, the U.S. government would reimburse the merchants with real money. Explaining that since the southern army is already well outfitted, the plan will mainly affect the northern troops. 3 pp.

LS, Newburgh. Largely in cipher. Explaining that he is holding off on sending out new recruits in the hopes of receiving some intelligence from Europe; saying it would be too laborious and risky to send heavy stores and artillery over land to the South. 4 pp.

LS, New Windsor. Doubting the intentions of the British in sending Sir Guy Carleton to negotiate peace, directing that the army join with the French in celebrating the birth of the Dauphin, glad to hear Mrs. Greene has safely arrived to visit her husband. 3 pp.

LS, Newburgh. Reporting that the British appear to be preparing to send troops to the West Indies, revealing heretofore secret information that the French fleet is sailing to the West Indies as well, updating on both the Continental and British troops in the North. 11 pp.

LS, New Windsor. To the Governor of Rhode Island. Informing Greene that the New Jersey lines have followed the example of the Pennsylvania troops and mutinied; Major General Robert Howe has been sent to suppress them and will not compromise; urging Greene to do everything in his power to provide desperately needed supplies in the hopes of preventing any further trouble. 3 pp.

LS, Parker's Ford on Schuylkill. Thanking Congress for its confidence, saying he is crossing the Schuylkill, describing how a lack of provisions and bad weather recently prevented him from attacking the enemy as he had intended, hoping they will not gain Philadelphia. 2 pp. [Revolutionary War Series, Vol. 11: 268-70]
LS. Transmitting "act act for giving effect to the several acts therein mentioned, in respect to the state of North Carolina, and other purposes" [not included]. 1 p.

LS with autograph postscript, Philadelphia. Expressing surprise and annoyance that the finances and public affairs of the state of Virginia are so poor; saying it is not his business to decide which states have been most burdened by the war and therefore receive the most help from Congress; complaining about provision contracts; stating that the individual states must do their part for the war to end. 3 pp.

LS, West Point. To Hayes or [Silvanus] Seely. Planning for the possible arrival of Count D'Estaing. Ordering Hayes & Seely to procure information about the enemy's strength and movements on Staten Island, requesting they lay a train for transmitting intelligence from the island every day or two. Stressing how important the information may be to D'Estaing. 2 pp.

ANS below a letter written by Samuel Darby to William Heath. The letter gives dimensions for the construction of flat bottomed boats. Underneath, Washington suggested the boat bottoms be made of uncut planks for greater strength; with a small diagram of the "floor of the boat." 1 p.
ALS, marked "Private." Thanking Heath for his services in the army. 2 pp.

LS, Morristown. Lamenting the extreme difficulty they have experienced in raising enough men to fight the enemy. Discussing the merits and disadvantages of the draft, the serious problem created by short enlistments, and the need for better laws concerning substitution and desertion. 4 pp. [Revolutionary War Series, Vol. 9: 451-3]
ALS, Mount Vernon. Acknowledging a letter containing a gratifying account of a reception for [C.C] Pinckney in Petersburg. 1 p.

Draft ALS (initials), Philadelphia. Enclosing a letter for [James] Keith [not included], which authorizes him to receive money from William Wilson to pay Hooe, expressing his desire to have the business closed. 1 p. [Presidential Series, Vol. 12: 550]

ALS, New Windsor. To the President of Congress. Reporting on his recent meeting with the Comte de Rochambeau and the decision to focus on capturing New York; expressing concern about the danger of enemy invasion from Canada; explaining why Fort Schuyler was recently abandoned. 4 pp.
See Wayne, Anthony letter of the same date.

DS. Instructions for recruiting men into the army with added incentives that each non-commissioned soldier may received a bounty of 20 dollars and an annual suit of clothes, and officers who complete their terms will be awarded 100 acres of land. 2 pp. [These were circular instructions sent to multiple colonels. See Revolutionary War Series, Vol. 8: 44-45 for a list of the other known recipients.]

ADS. Washington's copy of a memo sent to Jay and Rufus King. The memo exonerates the two from any wrongdoing in the case of Citizen Genet, the French ambassador to the U.S. [who accused them of libel]. Washington requested that the memo not be made public or published while he remained in office. 2 pp. Also included is an 1836 letter from Jared Sparks [Washington's biographer] to J. K. Paulding, sending the above memo for Washington's autograph. 1 p.

LS, New Windsor. Reporting on the enemy's movement at Petersbugh and the hope that the Marquis de Lafayette will check the progress of General [Molesworth] Phillips; mentioning a delay in the marching the Pennsylvania line and New York troops recently sailed; assuring Jefferson that he and the Count de Rochambeau will develop a plan and support the Southern States. 2 pp.
ADS and ANS on same page. A statement of his account with David Kennedy, ending with a balance of 28 pounds for which Washington asks payment, with a note of Kennedy for this sum. 1 p.
See Jay, John.

LS, Middlebrook. Reporting his estimates of the enemy's forces at New York and Rhode Island, updating on the strength and location of American troops, expressing doubt that the states will come through with promised reinforcements, and asking Knox for suggestions for a plan of conduct in light of short supplies and depreciating money. 2 pp. [The same exact LS was sent to Nathanael Greene (see above). Due to a transcribing error this copy is dated 1778 but should read 1779 as does the Greene copy.]

LS, West Point. Acknowledging reports concerning the defense of West Point; saying that powder is scarce at the moment but more is expected; directing Knox to write to the Board and request the powder be forwarded as soon as it arrives; ordering him to also oversee the preparation of cannon balls of various sizes. 2 pp.

LS, West Point. Directing the placement of artillery at Fort Arnold and Kings-Ferry with a note that the latter should only receive the least valuable artillery; ordering the rest of the ordnance to be shipped to Albany; directing small companies of artificers to be withdrawn and compacted into larger groups as it will save on the expense of issuing provisions and may also improve the value of their labor. 3 pp.

LS. Giving instructions for the peace establishment of the army. Directing how many officers and troops should remain in service to provide for the security of stores & posts. Saying poor public finances call for a reduction in troops as soon as is safely possible. 5 pp.

Draft LS, Valley Forge. To the President of Congress. Reporting that the commissary department has had a "total failure" of supplies and may cause the dissolution of the entire army. Asking for vacant offices to be filled immediately. Explaining how important it is to be prudent in promoting the rank of officers, using General Woodford as an example. Saying he has thought long and hard about what to do with the troops for the winter and has acted as he thinks best by bringing them to Valley Forge. Lamenting the precarious position of New Jersey and promising to send a small detachment there for protection. 8 pp. [Revolutionary War Series, Vol. 12: 667-671]

ALS. Marked "Private." Agreeing with a plan to kidnap Benedict Arnold, emphasizing that he must not be killed since Washington plans to make a public example of him, warning that the kidnappers must be careful not to give themselves away by appearing too zealous or carrying too much money. 2 pp.

Draft ALS (initials), Mount Vernon. To his sister. Describing the disposition and character of his niece, Harriot, whom he is sending to stay with his sister while he and his wife are in Philadelphia. 3 pp. [Presidential Series, Vol. 11: 201-2]

ALS, Peekskill. To his brother-in-law. Complaining about the evil of short enlistments and the misuse of taxes; wondering why Virginians have not driven out Lord Cornwallis; explaining that a southern march would result in death and desertion in the troops; reporting that the French are marching from Rhode Island to Peekskill; mentioning that Mrs. Washington is sick. 4 pp.
ALS, Philadelphia. To his nephew. Giving close directions for the care of the crops and cattle at Mount Vernon, asking his nephew to keep him well informed. 7 pp.
LS. Sending intelligence that the British are advancing; ordering Lincoln to send out his scouts and have everything in readiness to move [just before Lincoln's attack on Stono Ferry]. 1 p.
ALS, New Windsor. Explaining the problems with short enlistments, discussing food for the troops, and bemoaning the dire need for clothing and the miserable state of Continental credit. 4 pp.

ALS, New York. Reporting confidentially that the size and health of the New York army is inadequate to face the enemy, who is expected to receive support from the Hessians. Saying he has petitioned Connecticut and New Jersey for reinforcements. 2 pp. [Revolutionary War Series, Vol. 5: 631-2]
ALS, Newburgh. Recommending [James] McHenry for secretary of legation in London or Paris. 1 p.

ALS, Mount Vernon. Giving his opinion on various issues being considered by Congress, stressing the need for the states to present a united front. Discussing the merits of inland navigation, roads, and canals in various states. 4 pp. [Confederation Series, Vol. 3: 419-421]
Draft ALS (initials). Presenting his side in a dispute over a land boundary. 3 pp. [Colonial Series, Vol. 8: 312-315]
ALS, Mount Vernon. Introducing a former Virginia officer, Mr. Stevens, who is traveling through Georgia. 1 p. [Confederation Series, Vol. 6: 286]
ALS, West Point. Defending his actions and explaining his reluctance in assuming responsibility for the Mercer estate following the death of [John] Tayloe. 7 pp.

ALS, Mount Vernon. Agreeing to accept six negroes in payment of a debt, asking for healthy men who can serve as ditchers and artificers; telling Mercer he will also accept wheat, corn, and Virginia military certificates as payment but only under the terms he has specified; expressing annoyance that Mercer deceived him about paying off his debt with money from a lawsuit; forwarding land deeds and asking not to be any further involved with them. 5 pp. [Confederation Series, Vol. 4: 226-8]

Draft ALS (initials), Mount Vernon. Stating his anger and frustration at Mercer's continued failure to pay a twenty-year-old debt, citing Mercer's extreme indebtedness to others, asking to meet and resolve the matter, threatening to take court action. 4 pp. [Presidential Series, Vol. 10: 572-5]

ALS, Mount Vernon. Hoping Morris will come visit Mount Vernon with his wife, saying he is no longer worried about whether Virginia will ratify the Constitution since it was ratified in Maryland by a large majority. 2 pp. [Confederation Series, Vol. 6: 259-260]

LS, Morristown. Expressing strong concerns about the safety of stores in Philadelphia as the enemy has been reinforced in Jersey and is therefore likely planning an attack on Philadelphia. Mentioning rumors of a portable bridge. Ordering that salt be the first item moved to a secure location, asking Morris to oversee [Carpenter] Wharton, who has promised to move the salt but may not be trustworthy. 2 pp. [Revolutionary War Series, Vol. 8: 416]

LS. Ordering Moylan to proceed to Bedford and take command of Colonel Sheldon's and Colonel Armand's forces to protect the country and its inhabitants. 1 p. [This copy of the letter is dated 1778, but a published draft copy records the date as 1779.]
LS. Answering inquiries as to their powers under the treaty, saying they can be little more than witnesses of the evacuation. 3 pp.
LS, New York. Reporting on the apprehension of Joseph Blanchard and Peter Puillon under suspicion of communicating with the enemy. 1 p. [Revolutionary War Series, Vol. 4: 221-3]
LS. Thanking Captain Betts and other members of the militia for their recent distinguished service; asking for a report on the enemy including damage caused and their recent movements. 2 pp.

LS, Peekskill. Saying that he will transmit Parsons' troubling letter to the State of Connecticut in the hopes that they will insure justice for the Connecticut troops. [Parsons was evidently concerned with issues of pay and subsistence for the troops.] 1 p.
ALS, Philadelphia. To the manager of Mount Vernon. Ordering Pearce to sell his flour, stating the price and credit terms. 1 p.

ALS, Mount Vernon. Thanking Peters for sending the seed of yellow bearded wheat, outlining his plans for planting grains in the coming season, mentioning troubles with blights and drought. 2 pp. [Retirement Series, Vol. 1: 268-9]
ALS (draft), Morristown. Asking for help in handling some legal business related to George Mercer and his mortgagees. 3 pp.
Served as secretary of state from 1795 to 1800.

ALS, Mount Vernon. Stating his suspicion of M. Adet, French minister to the U.S., who took an unnecessarily long time answering a protest from the U.S. government [concerning the capture of Mount Vernon by a French privateer]. Calling for stricter enforcement of the laws applying to French prizes in American ports. 2 pp.

ALS, Mount Vernon. Saying that the French complaints against the Anglo-American treaty stem from [James Monroe's] failure to correctly present the facts to them; approving [R.G. Van] Polanen as Dutch minister to the U.S.; commenting on instructions for American seamen to obtain passports. 3 pp.
ALS, Mount Vernon. Returning the Spanish treaty with his signature and an annexed proclamation [not included]. 1 p.

LS, signed also by Timothy Pickering. Formal notification of the removal of David Humphreys as minister to the Court of Portugal, with wishes for continued friendship and harmony between the two countries. 1 p.
LS, Peekskill. Requesting an immediate report on the number of men under Pray's command at Dobb's Ferry "particularly the number of officers & men in the garrison & on the water guard." 1 p.

LS, Valley Forge. To the President of Delaware. Urging him to institute a draft to fill Delaware's quota of men for the army. Asking him to provide them with proper and sufficient clothing as it is best not to rely heavily on imported items. 2 pp. [Revolutionary War Series, Vol. 13: 282-4]

LS, West Point. To the Governor of Pennsylvania. Reporting the expected arrival of Count D'Estaing; requesting 1500 fully outfitted troops from Pennsylvania, additionally requesting that the state provide all it can in the way of provisions and food for the army; explaining how detrimental a failure to comply may be; with mention that the French squadron is expected at any moment. 6 pp.

LS. Saying that it appears Canadian refugees and volunteers are not legally entitled to rations given out by the American army; expecting that contractors will provide food and supplies if the militia is called into service; with mention of General [John] Stark. 2 pp.
See Hayes, Samuel.

LS, Valley Forge. Ordering the execution of William Seed following a court martial; deferring sentence against Samuel Carter as New Jersey has its own set of laws for how to deal with inhabitants taking arms on the side of the enemy. 1 p. [Revolutionary War Series, Vol. 14: 515-6]
ALS, Philadelphia. Offering to sell land in Fayette County currently occupied by Shreve, outlining the terms of sale. 3 pp.

LS, Valley Forge. Approving of Smallwood's carrying off forage and destroying the remainder, ordering him to move all but the lightest pieces of artillery in anticipation of an enemy attack and the need for a quick retreat, asking for recruits from Maryland to be sent to join their regiments as fast as they are raised to avoid straggling and desertion. 1 p. [Revolutionary War Series, Vol. 14: 261-2]

LS. Notifying Smallwood that an inspectorship has been instituted to help establish uniformity of discipline and maneuvers in the army; Baron de Steuben is Inspector General and [Louis de] Fleury will oversee Smallwood's troops; with other notes on inspectorships and a comment that they must discontinue the use of music while marching. 2 pp. [Revolutionary War Series, Vol. 15: 7-8]
LS, Verplank's Point. Since Charleston has been evacuated, directing Smallwood to send Maryland recruits to Washington's command and stay in Maryland himself to superintend further recruiting. 1 p.
ALS, Mount Vernon. Asking if Smallwood is still interested in purchasing a tract of land in Charles County, offering to accept wheat & corn as payment. 1 p. [Confederation Series, Vol. 5: 354-5]

LS, Camp near Pott's Grove. Ordering Smith to march his troops to Fort Mifflin and provision it with food and ammunition for at least a month; saying Baron Arundt will be appointed chief in command there. 2 pp. [Revolutionary War Series, Vol. 11: 308]
Commissioner of Prisoners.
LS with autograph postscript. Promising that [Robert] Morris and the contractors [who provision the army] will in the future see that naval prisoners are given subsistence. 2 pp.
LS. Directing Smith to immediately report to Paulus Hook and New York to make arrangements with the British Commissary of Prisoners, with names of the party to escort him to the outpost. 1 p.

LS, Verplank's Point. Responding to request from the South Carolina delegates to keep General [Nathanael] Greene and his troops stationed in the South. Explaining that Greene's orders to move northward after the enemy evacuated Charleston were given with the assumption that Georgia, South Carolina, and North Carolina would each raise sufficient troops to protect themselves, which they have not done. Refusing to change his orders to Greene. 3 pp. Included is a copy of Washington's letter to Greene (March 18, 1782) explaining the reasons for moving troops from the South to the North. 3 pp. Also included is an undated resolution, believed to be in the hand of South Carolina delegate Arthur Middleton, requesting aid for the Southern states. 1 p.

Draft ALS, Philadelphia. Responding to a letter from Spotswood about the alien & sedition laws, arguing for their effectiveness and constitutionality. [Spotswood denied ever writing to Washington on the subject and suggested someone forged his signature on the letter Washington received.] 1 p. [Retirement Series, Vol. 3: 216-8]

LS, Philadelphia. Sympathizing with St. Clair's difficulties in recruiting and marching his troops, approving his plans against Wilmington, sending Congressional resolutions on the Yorktown victory and directing that they be read to the troops, directing Colonel Febinger to increase the Virginia troops. 2 pp.

ALS, Newburgh. Ordering St. Clair to return to his army command after his extended absence; explaining that eight of the nine commanding officers in his cantonment have requested leave and public duty requires they return and prepare the corps for the field. 2 pp.

ALS. Answering Steuben's queries as to the efficacy of his role as Inspector General, assuring him that the office is invaluable and he filled it honorably. 2 pp. [Included in the folder is a February 26, 1814 letter from Benjamin Walker to an unknown recipient, forwarding the above letter as a memento of Washington. 1 p.]

ALS, Philadelphia. Discussing salaries for the commissioners of the District of Columbia, questioning why [Andrew] Ellicott is discontented with [Thomas] Jefferson, and giving his opinion on an application from [Notley] Young, who apparently owned land that the government wanted to claim for the federal city. 4 pp. [Presidential Series, Vol. 12: 253-6]

ALS, Newburgh. Expressing happiness at the end of the war but warning that Congress must still develop a constitution "competent to the general purposes of government" if the nation has any hope of success. Congratulating Tilghman on his marriage. 2 pp.
ALS, Mount Vernon. Concerning his wish for the establishment of a national university and opposition by the legislature, thanking Tucker for his essay on the topic. 1 p.

LS, Morristown. Answering an inquiry about the protection of small frontier posts; saying the state has issued clothing for his regiment; refusing to authorize the delivery of raw hides as they are not within his jurisdiction. 1 p.
LS, New York. To the Governor of Georgia, transmitting an act imposing duties on tonnage [not included]. 1 p.

LS, New York. Mentioning rumors of Hessian & Hanoverian troops coming over with the enemy; expressing surprise that the vessels at Beverly are unfit for service; directing action in the case of some apprehended women & children and the sale of naval prizes at Beverly. [The letter also contains an 1833 note by Thomas Hopkinson describing its provenance.] 4 pp. [Revolutionary War Series, Vol. 4: 247-8]

ALS, Philadelphia. To his nephew. Reiterating his refusal of the executorship of Colonel Fairfax's estate, congratulating his nephew on his progress in his law career, encouraging honor and probity. 1 p.

ALS, Middlebrook. A lengthy letter primarily concerned with surveying and selling land, outlining a dispute with a Mr. Marshall and the possible sale of land to a Mr. Triplet; with directions for managing the work and wages of Lampshire and comments on depreciating money and rising prices. 11 pp.

ALS, Cambridge. Saying the enemy is shut up in Boston and has resorted to piracy to gain provisions; he ordered a group of men to Canada under Colonel Arnold; many men don't know how to use rifles; mentioning Captain Hugh Stevenson; hoping that his wife has company and comfort at Mount Vernon. At the bottom of this letter are two addendums: one thanking Mrs. Washington of Harewood (GW's sister-in-law) for her message and the other entreating his brother not to purchase a mill. 4 pp. [Revolutionary War Series, Vol. 2: 72-4]

ALS, Philadelphia. Questioning whether a carpenter once recommended by William might still be available since Mount Vernon's original carpenter was found to be incorrigible. Discussing possible working terms and living conditions for the man and his workers. 3 pp.

LS, Valley Forge. Giving explicit directions for driving cattle to Valley Forge and asking Wayne to oversee the movement and protection of some cannon. 3 pp. [Revolutionary War Series, Vol. 13: 700-701]

LS, Valley Forge. Congratulating Wayne on escaping Haddonfield before the enemy arrived, instructing him to cripple the enemy by driving off any cattle and destroying any forage that might be of benefit to them. 1 p. [Revolutionary War Series, Vol. 14: 42]
LS, Valley Forge. Ordering Wayne to immediately report to camp to consult with a Congressional committee about improvements in the army. 1 p. [Revolutionary War Series, Vol. 14: 190].

ALS, Morristown. Thanking Wayne for suggestions about how to improve the operation against Charleston, but saying that a lack of funds, supplies, and men hinders the American army from acting; thanking Wayne for helping the Maryland troops and hoping he will soon rejoin the Pennsylvania line. 2 pp.

ALS, Tappan. To Generals Wayne & [William?] Irvine. A lengthy letter explaining Washington's standpoint on the appointment of [William] McPherson to the Pennsylvania light corps, an appointment which has been highly contested and may lead to resignations by multiple disgruntled officers. 7 pp.
LS, Headquarters Robinson's. Directing General Irvine and the second brigade to move to West Point and the first brigade to remain in place. 1 p.
Williams' ALS to Washington. Sending compliments from Mrs. Carroll and promising to arrange for the transportation of some fruit trees. Docketed in Washington's hand. 1 p.

LS, Middlebrook. Giving directions for the distribution of clothing to the troops, noting which regiments and states are in need of clothing and which have already been sufficiently supplied and should not be given anything more than absolute necessities such as shoes. 2 pp. with separate address sheet. [Revolutionary War Series, Vol. 8:670-1]

AMs. Document dividing slaves between Mary, George, Samuel, John, and Charles Washington, including the names and values of the slaves. 1 p. with one corner missing. [This is believed to be a list of slaves that GWâ€™s father Augustine Washington left to his wife Mary Washington and their four sons. It was likely made in 1750. See Colonial Series, Vol. 7: 172-4 for more].
ADS. A survey conducted for George Hyatt containing both a description and a diagram of a tract of waste and ungranted land in Frederick County. 2 p.

ADsS. A collection of 19 surveys conducted for various persons, all but the last including a diagram. They are inlaid and bound together in a full morocco volume (Ms. No. 7). Researchers will be given access to photocopies of the surveys.
ADS. A survey conducted for Joseph Powell containing both a description and a diagram of a tract of waste and ungranted land in Frederick County. 2 p.

ADS. A survey conducted for John Parke, Sr. containing both a description and diagram of waste and ungranted land in Frederick County. On the back are notes about a disagreement between Parke and Levy Ashbrook over who has rights to the land. 3 pp.
ADS. A survey conducted for Benjamin Phipps containing both a description and a diagram of a tract of waste and ungranted land in Frederick County. 2 p.
ADS. A survey conducted for his brother, Lawrence, containing both a description and diagram of waste and ungranted land in Frederick County. 1 p.
ADS. A survey conducted for George Martin containing both a description and a diagram of a tract of waste and ungranted land. A note on the back says a deed was issued to Patrick Rice. 3 pp.
ADS. A survey conducted for Francis McBride containing a description of a tract of waste and ungranted land in Frederick County. 1 p.

AD, containing GW's signature and those of 3 witnesses. Document dividing the slaves of George's brother Lawrence between himself and his younger brothers. Labeled "1st Division." [Colonial Series, Vol. 1: 227-231]

AD. Document dividing the slaves of George's deceased brother Lawrence between himself and his brothers. Including the names and values of the slaves. Labeled "2nd Division." 1 p. [Colonial Series, Vol. 7: 172-174]
A deed issued by the trustees of the town of Alexandria (John Muir and Harry Piper) conveying lots to George Washington. Signed by Muir and Piper. 1 p.

DS. Deed for 6500 acres of land in Frederick County, Maryland. Washington served as attorney for the party of George Mercer, Richard Gravatt, and Mary Wroughton, signing their names as well as his own. The document contains numerous other signatures of interested parties and clerks. 2 pp.
DS. Authorizing the Quarter Master General to impress 40 teams with a sufficient number of cattle in order to fill an immediate need. 1 p.
ADS. Copy (in Washington's hand) of his bond to George Clinton for $5000 [for their joint purchase of land in Utica, NY]. 2 pp.
DS. Army discharge of Abraham Sickels of the First New York Regiment. Printed form with multiple other signatures. 2 pp.
DS. Army discharge of Thomas Sheehan of the New York Artillery Regiment. Printed form with multiple other signatures. 2 pp.

AMsS. Fragments of Washington's undelivered first inaugural address. [Before his inauguration as President, Washington asked Colonel David Humphreys to draft some remarks for the inaugural ceremony. Humphreys evidently responded with a lengthy speech, which Washington copied onto 73 pages. This speech was never used. In the 1820s, Washington biographer Jared Sparks came across the speech and decided that since it bore little resemblance to the actual speech given by Washington, it was not important to publish. He split up the manuscript and gifted pages and pieces of pages to friends and family. The entire manuscript has never been recovered, though parts of it have been pieced together. This collection includes all of pages 5, 6, 23, and 24, and the bottom third of pages 15 and 16. One of the fragments is bound in a volume with a note on its provenance. More information about other recovered pages is available in Presidential Series, Vol. 2: 152-177.]
DS, on vellum, signed also by Thomas Jefferson. Appointing David Humphreys minister [to Portugal]. 1 p.
DS, signed also by Thomas Jefferson [and said to be in his hand]. Appointing John Paul Jones consul to Algiers. 1 p.
DS, on vellum, signed also by Thomas Jefferson. Appointing David Humphreys commissioner to negotiate with the Dey of Algiers on behalf of captive citizens of the U.S. 1 p. with torn corner.
DS, signed also by Thomas Jefferson. Ship's papers for the schooner Amazond Dutch. 2 pp.
DS, on vellum, signed also by Edmund Randolph. Passport for David Humphreys. 1 p.

DS, signed also by Edmund Randolph and others. Ship's papers for the brigantine Goodhope, master Nicholas Thorndike, giving permission to carry coffee, sugar, indigo, rum, and tobacco from Salem to Hamburg. From printed in French, English, and Dutch. 1 p.
Two copies of an identical DS, signed also by Timothy Pickering. Appointing David Humphreys as minister to "the Court of his Catholic Majesty" [Spain]. 1 p.
Certifying George S. Washington and Lawrence Lewis as executors of the estate of the late George Washington. Issued by John Hewitt, Registrar of Wills. 1 p.

This series consists of the correspondence of Asa Waterman (1743-1789), who served as a commissary for the American government during the Revolutionary War. Asa Waterman was born May 1, 1743 in Norwich, Connecticut to Asa and Lucy Hyde Waterman. In 1777 he married Anne Cooke Sterry (1752-1837), daughter of Governor Cook of Providence, R.I. Before the outbreak of the war, Waterman served in various military posts and operated as a ship merchant. His experience in dealing goods undoubtedly contributed to his appointment as a commissary. Waterman was among the first commissaries in America, as the commissariat system was established during (and in response to) the Revolutionary War. Before then, the provisioning of any military troops in the American colonies was conducted by piecemeal contract with individual suppliers. As the fight for independence escalated, the Continental Congress decided a more stable system was needed to provide food, clothes, and weapons to the troops. Congress therefore established the office of the Commissary General of Stores and Provisions in June 1775. The structure and success of the commissariat system changed throughout the war. Initially, Joseph Trumbull (1737-1778) was appointed Commissary General and was given wide latitude to organize the commissariat system as he saw fit, with little input from Congress. By 1777 it became clear more standards and regulations were needed, causing Congress to reorganize the system. The department was split between a Commissary General of Issues and a Commissary General of Purchases, positions filled by William Buchanan and Jeremiah Wadsworth (1743-1804) respectively. When this proved faulty, yet another revision was made whereby each state was required to fulfill a quota of provisions. This last iteration of the commissariat operated under the direction of Ephraim Blaine (1741-1804). Stationed in Rhode Island, Asa Waterman appears to have started his tenure with the commissariat around the time of the split into separate issue and purchasing departments, though his titles and responsibilities reflect how unsuccessful the split proved to be. From October 1777 to June 1779, Waterman was Assistant Commissary of Issues, but he also helped with purchasing. In June 1779 he officially switched to Assistant Commissary of Purchases. When the commissariat was again reorganized into a state quota system, he remained in the service of Rhode Island until August 1780 at which point he returned to his hometown of Norwich, Connecticut, to serve as Deputy Commissary of Purchases. He appears to have remained in Norwich until his death there in early 1789. The correspondence in this series dates from Watermanâ€™s years in Rhode Island (1777-1780). Included are letters both to and from Waterman. The correspondents include military officers requesting provisions, private suppliers writing about the availability of certain goods, and most frequently other commissaries, notably Peter Coltâ€”Watermanâ€™s superior who was in charge of purchasing for the entire "Eastern Department" (comprised of New England and parts of New York). As a whole, the series highlights two major themes. The first is the difficulty of provisioning the troops with adequate, nutritious food due to a scarcity of staples (most often flour) and the problem of shipping goods at the risk of enemy seizure. Creative methods of "lengthening" food were encouraged (e.g. adding rice to flour to make it last longer). The second theme is the frequent reorganization of the commissariat system, resulting in new regulations that affected how and when troops could be supplied. The constant change in rules and salaries clearly frustrated Waterman, Colt, and other members of the Commissariat as evidenced by many of the letters in this series. The papers are arranged chronologically.
ALS to Waterman orchestrating an exchange of oats and salt. 1 leaf.
Copy of ALS by Waterman regarding the purchase of lime. 1 leaf.
ALS to Waterman regarding the shipment of lime. 1 leaf.
ANS to Waterman requesting provisions for prisoners. A supply of bread and pork was furnished. Quarter leaf.
ALS to Waterman regarding the shipment of beef, oats, and wagon wheel boxes. 1 leaf.
ALS to Waterman requesting a purchase of rum and sugar. 1 folded leaf.
ALS to Waterman regarding a scarcity of sugar. 1 leaf.
Note to Rhode Island Commissary (Peter) Phillips requesting rations by order of General Spencer. Request was fulfilled by Waterman, rations were entrusted to Comfort Wheaton, Captain of the Provost.
Note requesting rations for nine men by order of General Spencer. Fulfilled by Waterman.
List of names and numbers labeled "Weight of Provisions" received of Peter Phillips. 1 leaf.
ALS to Waterman regarding food, Waterman's role as purchaser for the commissary, and updates on General Washington and "the enemy." 1 folded leaf.
ALS to Waterman regarding new bonds and regulations issued by Congress to the Commissary Department. Also writes of the availability of flour. 1 folded leaf.

ALS to Waterman acknowledging the problem of a lack of cash in the Commissary Department. Also writes about the availability of flour and potential employment opportunities for two men. 1 folded leaf.
ALS to Waterman responding to a request for more provisions and discussing the chain of command in the Commissary Department. 1 folded leaf.
ALS to Waterman regarding changes in both the national and Rhode Island Commissary Departments. Also requests large amounts of salted beef, pork, and fish. 1 folded leaf.
Copy of ALS by Waterman describing a series of disagreements within the Commissary Department. 1 folded leaf.
ALS to Waterman directing the purchase of fish, beef, and pork. 1 folded leaf.
ALS to Waterman directing him to purchase and forward a cask. 1 leaf.

ALS to Waterman announcing the Congressional appointment of (Jeremiah) Wadsworth as head of commissariat purchasing and requesting Waterman continue as an assistant commissary for Rhode Island. 1 folded leaf.
ALS to Waterman requesting information about provisions received from Colonel Trumbull. 1 folded leaf.
ALS to Waterman concerning provisions for troops in Rhode Island. Also discusses the role of the individual state commissariats. 1 folded leaf.
Copy of ALS by Waterman asking for orders on a variety of matters. Mentions a scarcity of cash, continued disagreement among the commissaries, and difficulties posed by the war. 1 folded leaf.
Copy of ALS by Waterman demanding a copy of Child's account book of issues. 1 leaf.
Copy of ALS by Waterman requesting an immediate shipment of flour. 1 folded leaf.
Copy/draft of ALS by Waterman giving account of what provisions were provided to various troops. Continually stresses the scarcity of flour. 1 folded leaf.

ALS to Waterman regarding provisions; encourages the purchase of food from captured prize ships. A post script labeled "private" comically laments Waterman's superior, Mr. (Solomon) Southwick. 1 folded leaf.
ALS to Waterman explaining the danger of shipping supplies by land and proposing the use of a military fleet to ship provisions by water. 1 folded leaf.
ANS to Waterman orchestrating payment.
ALS to Waterman stating Halsey's intentions to quit his post due to continued frustrations with the Quarter Master's department. 1 folded leaf.
ANS to Peter Colt (or Waterman in his absence) concerning a fleet recently departed from Rhode Island. 1 folded leaf.
ALS to Waterman complaining of watered-down rum and questioning the safety of shipping by water. 1 folded leaf.
ALS to Peter Colt asking him to assess the risk of shipping goods by water due to rumors of an armed British fleet in the area. 1 leaf.
Copy of ALS from Waterman regarding various commissariat business in response to successes and failures in the war. 1 folded leaf.
ALS to Waterman requesting direction on whether to make a purchase. 1 folded leaf.
ALS to Waterman requesting rum, salt, and sugar. 1 folded leaf.
ALS to Waterman which accompanied a shipment of onions. 1 leaf.
ALS to Waterman which accompanied a shipment of onions and beats. 1 folded leaf.
ALS to Waterman reporting that a shipment of sugar was burned by the enemy and provisions of any kind are scarce. 1 leaf.
ALS to Waterman offering to meet to discuss the purchase of beef. 1 folded leaf.
ALS to Waterman describing who he can contact for certain provisions. 1 folded leaf.
ANS to Waterman explaining he was sent the wrong letter. Quarter leaf.
ALS to Waterman warning him not to let a troublesome Mr. Spalding out of his obligation. 1 leaf.
ALS to Waterman concerning missing shipments of flour. 1 folded leaf.
ANS agreeing to a contract for rum. 1 leaf.
ALS to Waterman giving directions regarding a shipment of goods. 1 leaf.
ALS to Waterman sending cash on behalf of Peter Colt. 1 folded leaf.
ANS to Waterman requesting they immediately settle accounts. 1 leaf.
Copy of ALS by Waterman informing Colt that the commissary is indebted thousands of pounds and in need of cash. 1 leaf.
Copy of ALS by Waterman requesting an immediate shipment of flour. 1 leaf.
ALS to Waterman regarding a legal investigation by the Court of Inquiry. 1 leaf.
Copy of ALS by Waterman regarding the balancing of various accounts. 1 folded leaf.
ALS to Waterman regarding a shipment of Madeira wine. 1 folded leaf.
Copy of ALS by Waterman concerning Major General Sullivan's orders to substitute potatoes and onions for milk & beer in the rations. Copy 1 of 3. 1 leaf.
Copy 2 of 3 (see above). 1 leaf.
Copy 3 of 3 (see above). 1 leaf.
ALS to Waterman hoping for the delivery of a hogshead of lime. 1 leaf.
Copy of ALS by Waterman concerning the purchase of goods off a prize ship. 1 folded leaf.
ALS to Waterman mentioning a troublesome Mr. Sullivan and discussing the purchase of goods from prize ships. 1 folded leaf.
Copy of ALS by Waterman discussing goods from prize ships and a scarcity of candles for the army. 1 leaf.
Copy of ALS by Waterman regarding rice. 1 leaf.
ALS to Waterman concerning a seized privateer ship containing goods that belonged to the U.S. government. 1 leaf
ALS to Waterman insisting that goods be insured at the risk of the government and not individuals. 1 folded leaf.
Three receipts signed by J. Wallace acknowledging receipt of rum. 1 leaf.
ALS from Amasa Learned to Messrs. Tobey & Proud requesting they send an account statement and bill to Asa Waterman. 1 leaf.
ALS to Waterman outlining a plan to supply the troops with salted meat. Also mentions the need to get flour from prize ships. 1 folded leaf.
ALS to Waterman requesting a bill for guns and shot. 1 leaf.
ALS to Waterman planning a visit to settle accounts with the Rhode Island Commissary. 1 folded leaf.
Copy of ALS by Asa Waterman to Messrs. Miller & Tracy inquiring about spirits and salt. 1 folded leaf.
ALS to Waterman regarding bundles of cash and settling accounts. 1 leaf.
ALS to Waterman requesting shipment of goods. 1 leaf.
ALS to Waterman requesting he be paid. 1 leaf.
Copy of ALS by Waterman explaining his purchase of vegetables for the troops and outlining a plan to keep salt stores away from the enemy. 1 folded leaf.
ALS to Waterman agreeing to ship the last of his salt bushels. 1 leaf.
Copy of ALS by Waterman detailing his search for salt and the storage of goods. 1 folded leaf.
Copy of ALS by Waterman concerning the barreling of beef, rendering tallow, West Indian goods, and an immediate need for cash. 1 folded leaf.
Copy of ALS by Waterman concerning a variety of goods and a disagreement about the price of salt. 1 folded leaf.
ALS to Waterman focusing on the effects of a scarcity of cash. 1 folded leaf.
ALS to Waterman regarding a shipment of lumber and shingles as well as a personal request for some goods from Newport. 1 leaf.
ALS to Waterman regarding orders for goods. 1 leaf.
ALS to Waterman asking for weekly updates on available goods and prices. 1 folded leaf.
ALS to Waterman requesting the immediate shipment of sugar and coffee. 1 folded leaf.
ALS to Waterman informing him of the availability of empty barrels. 1 folded leaf.
Copy of ALS by Waterman ordering heads of cattle to be barreled. 1 leaf.
ALS to Waterman responding to confusion about the barreling of beef. 1 leaf.
Copy of ALS by Waterman concerning the shipment and payment of various goods. 1 leaf.
Copy of ALS by Waterman asking for cash. 1 leaf.
Copy of ALS by Waterman concerning an empty magazine and the impossibility of buying on credit. 1 folded leaf.
ALS to Waterman, upset that he was not informed about an upcoming wedding. 1 folded leaf.
ALS to Waterman explaining changes in the employment structure of the commissariat. 1 folded leaf.
Note signed by Amaziah Bosworth acknowledging goods received of Joseph Cooke to be delivered to Waterman. Quarter leaf.
ALS to Waterman concerning a purchase of goods. 1 folded leaf.
ANS to Waterman requesting corn and rum. Half leaf.
Receipt. On back is a tally of work performed on a schooner. 1 leaf.
Copy of ALS by Waterman explaining his debts. 1 folded leaf.
Account of lumber. 1 leaf.
ALS to Stephen Mumford requesting immediate shipment of corn and/or meat. 1 leaf.
Copy of ALS by Waterman giving account of barrels of provisions received from a Mr. Baker. 1 folded leaf.
Copy of ALS by Waterman concerning supplier Mr. Baker. 1 leaf.
Copy of ALS by Waterman explaining the proper way to acquire supplies. 1 folded leaf (torn).
Account statement between Thomas Allen and Waterman & Hyde. 1 folded leaf.
ALS to Waterman concerning stores for the winter. 1 folded leaf.
Memorandum authorizing the purchase of blankets, velvet, wallpaper, and rock salt. 1 leaf.
List of owners of schooner Lovely and accounts of goods received from her second cruise. 1 folded leaf.
American Revolutionary officer and statesman.
Filed by recipient.

ALS, Camp at White Plains. Complaining about the lack of clothing for the Pennsylvania troops, saying that the shutting of Pennsylvania's ports has left them severely crippled as compared to other states, saying that the state Clothier General issues clothes so erratically that it leaves the men looking like "jail birds and caitiffs." 4 pp. with separate address sheet.
LS, Greenville. Ordering brushes, mane combs, grass hooks, and lashing rope for the use of the light dragoon under his command. On the back, Paul McDermott signed that the items were received. 2 pp.

ALS (draft), Camp at Liberty Pole. Dramatically defending his conduct in dealing with Pennsylvania field officers who threatened to leave the army upon the appointment of Major [William] MacPherson as commander of the Light Infantry. 4 pp.

LS, Mt. Joy. To the President [Governor] of Pennsylvania. Describing the difficulty in recruiting Pennsylvanians to the army and saying a draft may be necessary, reporting a rumor that the enemy is congregating its forces, entreating Wharton to provide linens and clothing for the soldiers as nine out of ten deaths and desertions "are owing to diet and nakedness." 2 pp.

did.unittitle: Documents Relating to the Georgia Campaign

scopecontent.p: Letters and documents related to Wayne's campaign in Georgia.
Oath signed by 35 men admitting error in joining the British and agreeing to serve in the American Army henceforth. 3 pp.

Letter from Rebecca Read to Wayne. Complaining that a group of Americans posing as British plundered her home and took slaves, horses, alcohol, and clothes, and threatened to burn her house down. 3 pp.

Letter from Simon Munro to Alexander McGillivray, Deputy Superintendent of the Upper Creek Indian nation. Writing from Savannah, complaining that a man named Wetherford stole a horse, killed a hog, and enticed away a negro from his plantation. 2 pp. [Wayne apparently investigated the matter.]
Parole for Joseph Connell, agreeing to report to the headquarters of the American army and not to say anything prejudicial to the interest of America. 1 p.

Letter to Mr. Johnston requesting that he print an "address, remonstrances, and petition of the city of London to the King of Great Britain," in the hopes of "opening the eyes of the deluded inhabitants of Savannah." 4 pp.
Letter from Rebecca Read to Wayne. Congratulating him on taking possession of Savannah, sending a gift of two ducks and two geese. 1 p.

Letter from British Loyalist Ferg. Bethune to his wife, Judy. Marked "Intercepted Letter, 1782." The letter describes being trapped in Savannah by rebel (American) troops, and provides updates on various British victories including winning the support of the Emperor of Germany and the Empress of Russia. 4 pp.

Served as the first president of New Hampshire from 1776 to 1785. LS, Exeter. To Josiah Bartlett. Detailing the military expenses of New Hampshire and requesting reimbursement from Congress and money to clothe the soldiers. 2 pp.
American statesman from New Hampshire and Massachusetts. None of his letters contain the names of the recipients; filed by date.
ALS, Baltimore. Concerning personal financial business. 2 pp.
ALS, Washington. On personal banking and business issues with mention of debates about the Bank [of the United States]. 2 pp.
ALS, Washington. About loans and other personal business, mentioning Hancock Bank, and asking for the new register and a list of members of the General Court. 3 pp.
Webster's signature on the front of an envelope addressed to Nathaniel Silsbee.
ALS, Washington. Answering an inquiry about printed copies of the speeches from the Hayne-Webster debate. 1 p.
Served as U.S. secretary of the Navy from 1861 to 1869. Letters filed by recipient.
LS, Navy Department. Ordering Foote to convene a committee to investigate the conduct of Commodore George Preble, dismissed for letting an armored steamer elude his blockade around Mobile. 2 pp.
ALS, Washington. Marked "Private." Congratulating him on his election and discussing the difficulties facing the president. 4 pp. with original envelope.

Signer of the Declaration of Independence. ALS (initials), Philadelphia. To Dr. [Joshua] Brackett. Speaking against "Mr. D" [Silas Deane], passing a report that General [Benjamin] Lincoln has gained advantages in Georgia, and hoping to confirm a rumor that French Fleets have captured some Irish transports bound for America. 2 pp.

White was a prominent coal trader in the Philadelphia region. ALS from Eleazer Wyer to White, President of the Delaware Coal Company. Informing White that two shipments of coal have recently arrived and payment will be sent shortly. Giving a statement of coal sales for November; hoping to keep prices up. 1 p.
U.S. military officer.
Filed by recipient.
LS, Greenville. Ordering the Shawnee Indians to be supplied with bread, butter, and whiskey. 1 p.
ALS, New Orleans. Ordering him to enter into a proposed contract with Mr. Mather and to draw on the Secretary of War for payments. 1 p.

ALS, Mount Pleasant. Defending the character of Benedict Arnold, sharing an unconfirmed report from Canada that the enemy has left St. Johns due to the arrival of a French fleet, and criticizing the New Hampshire militia for hiring mercenaries. 2 pp.
DS. An order for a quart of whiskey for a Delaware Indian. 1 p.
DS. An order for stationery supplies: paper, quills, inkpowder, and wafers. 1 p.
Willoughby was a British penal reformer. Two letters to Lord Sydney (Thomas Townshend), Secretary of State.
ALS, Berners Street. Inquiring about the deportation of felons to America. 2 pp.

ALS, Berners Street. Sending a copy of a resolution of the High Sheriff and Grand Jury of Oxford County thanking Lord Sydney for his help in deporting some accused felons to America. Letter and resolution 1 p. each.

Woodrow Wilson served as president of Princeton University (1902-1911), Governor of New Jersey (1911-1913), and twenty-eighth president of the United States (1913-1921); this series includes letters written from all three offices. The letters particularly highlight his involvement in publishing and reviewing written works on political science and history. Of note are nearly thirty letters written to illustrator Howard Pyle, which demonstrate Wilson's passion for history and desire to be as historically accurate as possible in the text and illustrations of his own works.
Filed by recipient.
TLS, Washington. Saying he rarely reads The Outlook due to its unfriendly stance towards his administration, but thanking Baldwin for a copy of "Uncle Sam's Tin Halo." 1 p.
TLS, New Jersey. Explaining that he is unavailable for an interview but saying that his inclination to talk about motives and conduct makes him a poor subject for an interview anyway. 1 p.
TLS, Princeton, NJ. Thanking Bickford for a letter and forwarding his signature in thanks. 1 p.
TLS, Princeton, NJ. Thanking Bridgman for an extract from the Congregationalist and Christian World containing an editorial suggested by Wilson's address at Hartford. 1 p.
ALS, Bryn Mawr. Agreeing to help Bridgman with a plan, but clarifying that he is not a specialist in the application of political science to state policy. 2 pp.

TLS, Washington. To Margaret Brooks, Marguerite Lewin, Anita Brooks, and Bessie Quinton. Sending thanks for a message from a group of girls whom he passed each morning in Plainfield, N.H., as he went to play golf. 1 p. with original envelope.
Editor of The Dial.

ALS, Bryn Mawr. Declining the offer to review "Franklin in France" since he has already committed to writing an extended review of Mason's translation of Van Holst's monograph on the Constitution. 2 pp.
ALS, Princeton, NJ. Forwarding a review of [Henry] Sigdwick's The Elements of Politics. 1 p. [A printed copy of the review is available in the folder.]
TLS, Princeton, NJ. Declining an offer to write on the subject of "English at Princeton." Suggesting Dr. Murray, head of the English Department at Princeton, as an alternative. 1 p.
TLS, Washington. Thanking Burroughs for his message of January 31, saying it was received the same day as Germany's notification [of unrestricted U-boat warfare]. 1 p. with original envelope.

TLS, Princeton, NJ. Expressing his mortification that he was absent from Princeton on the day appointed for an interview with Chambers, explaining that he telegraphed his cancellation and assumed it had been received. 1 p.
TLS, New Jersey. Declining an invitation to speak before the graduating class of the Montclair State Normal School. 1 p.
TLS, New Jersey. Saying the appointment by the trustees of Princeton University of George B. McClellan was spontaneous and unrelated to politics. 1 p.

TLS, Washington. Saying the next two years of his administration will prove that the first two have been very beneficial to the country; declining the suggestion to reconsider tariff schedules; discussing the effect of war on immigration. 2 pp. with original envelope.

TLS, Washington. Speaking of his interest in the New Era Movement of the Presbyterian Church in the U.S.A., saying the movement is both a true interpretation of the gospel and an instrument of service to the nation. 1 p.
TLS, Washington. Expressing concern over the mistreatment of some women in an Ohio, asking Clarkson to have the State and County Councils of Defense investigate the matter. 1 p.
TLS, Princeton, NJ. Answering questions about the history of the study of political science at Princeton University. 2 pp.
TLS, Princeton, NJ. Discussing "college ideals" and a disturbing trend towards emphasizing extracurricular activities over serious study, hoping for a restored focus on mental training. 2 pp.

ALS, Princeton, NJ. Discussing alternate dates for a lecture before the Women's Club [of Worcester], offering a choice of subjects: patriotism, Americanism, political liberty, or Alexis de Tocqueville. 3 pp.
ALS, Princeton, NJ. Arranging his visit to Worcester, requesting to dine at the "Bay State." 2 pp.
LS, Princeton, NJ. Declining and invitation from a senior class because of other engagements. 2 pp.

TLS, Washington. Expressing his disappointment at the suggestion that a serious mistake was made in nominating Mr. Teifen for the postmastership in Trenton, Michigan. Promising to have the Postmaster General consider the matter. 1 p.
TLS, Washington. Agreeing to consider her suggestion. 1 p. with original envelope.
Duneka worked at Harper & Brothers publishing firm.
TLS, Washington. Saying he cannot possibly prepare a new chapter for the history. 1 p.

TLS, Washington. Agreeing to let Duneka publish his essay, "When a Man Comes to Himself," provided he can republish it in a collection of essays he is planning. 1 p. [See Documents file for a manuscript version of the essay.]

TLS, Washington. Agreeing to let Duneka publish his essay "On Being Human." Warning Duneka that it is a literary piece and will not be as popular as "When a Man Comes to Himself," which was a moral homily and more universally appealing. 1 p.
TLS, Washington. Saying he leads an extremely busy life but will try to meet with Duneka next Wednesday. 1 p.
TLS, Princeton, NJ. Acknowledging a paper on tariff reform but saying that the present time is not proper for a manifesto in favor of free trade. 1 p.
TLS, Washington. Saying he is forwarding Ford's letter to the Secretary of War to prevent an injustice being done. 1 p.
ALS, Washington. Saying he is gratified that her husband is working for the federal government. 1 p. with original envelope.
TLS, Princeton, NJ. Expressing interest in a proposal to erect a statue of Dr. John Witherspoon in Washington, saying Witherspoon is worthy of such a memorial. 1 p. with original envelope.
TLS, Princeton, NJ. Thanking Foster for forwarding $4000, the balance of the Witherspoon Memorial Fund, to be devoted to the John Witherspoon Scholarship at Princeton University. 2 pp.
Professor at Amherst College.
ALS, Princeton, NJ. Thanking the professor for his request to summarize Wilson's critical work and giving a statement as to the nature of history and facts. 3 pp. with original envelope.
ALS, Princeton, NJ. Thanking the professor for a copy of Working Principles of Rhetoric, in which Wilson's own work is used as illustration. 1 p.

ALS, New York. Accepting an invitation to stay with her in Tarrytown, saying he does not yet have a printed syllabus for his upcoming lectures, recommending books on Aristotle. 1 p. [See Documents file for a printed copy of the completed syllabus.]
ALS, Princeton, NJ. Discussing his progress and process in writing a book; agreeing with Hart's plans to include maps in the publication. 3 pp.

ALS, Princeton, NJ. Concerning maps for the book he is writing, asking that "Union" be substituted for "Loyal" on the maps and requesting that lighter colors be used to make them easier to read. 2 pp.
TLS, Washington. Sending thanks for a gift selected by Hirsh's secretary and for the letter of friendship which accompanied it. 1 p. with original envelope.
TLS, Washington. Saying it would not be appropriate for him to attend to the installation of the permanent directors of the Woodrow Wilson Foundation, alluding to ill health. 1 p.
TLS, Washington. Acknowledging a letter about the French Spoliation claims, saying Congress cannot take up the matter this session but perhaps in the future. 1 p.
ALS, Princeton, NJ. Forwarding an essay [to be used in the Century Magazine] based on a train conversation with Johnson [essay not included]. 1 p.
TLS, New Jersey. Directing Jordan to notify the committee that a planned conference must be postponed. 1 p.

TLS, Washington. Regretting that he will not be able to attend a dinner for George W. Guthrie, recently appointed U.S. minister to Japan; mentioning his pleasure that Japanese minister Baron Chinda will be attending. 2 pp.
TLS, Washington. Acknowledging her patriotism, saying that he cannot destroy or cancel her bonds but suggesting she devote their proceeds to the Red Cross or similar war relief efforts. 2 pp.
TLS, Princeton, NJ. Saying his address in Philadelphia was not printed in full but the greater part of it may be found in the New York Sun of November 19th. 1 p.
TLS, Bermuda. Thanking him for sending articles on the "difficult police question," promising to read them. 1 p.
TLS, Princeton, NJ. Declining an invitation to speak before the Bristol County Teachers Association. 1 p. with original envelope.
TLS, Princeton, NJ. A cordial letter of thanks for an offer of guidance.
TLS, Washington. Thanking Merrill for his approval. 1 p.
TLS, Washington. Responding to Moscoso's offer to translate Wilson's textbook, The State, into Spanish; forwarding the idea to his publisher. 1 p. with original envelope.
TLS, Princeton, NJ. Arranging to meet Price and a Mr. Archer in Princeton. 1 p.

Pyle illustrated two of Wilson's books: George Washington and History of the American People. Wilson's correspondence with Pyle concerns the details of the scenes he was commissioned to illustrate. The folder also includes tissue paper copies of seven letters sent from Pyle to Wilson.
TLS with autograph postscript, Princeton, NJ. Discussing early Virginia statesman and whether any portraits of them exist. 1 p.
TLS, Princeton, NJ. Forwarding the most recent part of his manuscript, hoping Pyle is familiar with Mary Philipse. 2 pp.
ALS, Princeton, NJ. Forwarding a magazine with a portrait of Mary Philipse [not included]. 1 p.
TLS, Princeton, NJ. Suggesting Pyle illustrate Great Meadows, the Braddock affair, and Mount Vernon; suggesting Pyle hire a photographer to make a view of Great Meadows. 2 pp.
TLS, Princeton, NJ. Forwarding the third part of his manuscript [not included].
TLS, Princeton, NJ. Clarifying when George and Martha Washington returned to Mount Vernon after their wedding, referring Pyle to Lossing's book on the Revolution. 3 pp.
TLS, Princeton, NJ. Praising Pyle's completed illustrations, saying he hopes to frame them. 1 p.
TLS, Princeton, NJ. Addressing small details for Pyle's illustrations and giving a description of Virginia statesman Edmund Pendleton. 2 pp.
TLS, Princeton, NJ. Affirming the details of George and Martha Washington's wedding, stating his preference that they be illustrated at the church and not traveling on the road. 3 pp.
TLS, Princeton, NJ. Asking Pyle if he would illustrate a hunting dinner or breakfast at Mount Vernon, describing which historical figures should appear in the scene. 2 pp.

TLS, Princeton, NJ. Suggesting illustrations for the yet unwritten fourth part of his work on Washington, including an interior scene of home life at Mount Vernon and a scene of Benedict Arnold depicting "the darkest hour of the war." 3 pp.

TLS, Baltimore. Suggesting more scenes for illustration including a meeting between the Virginia and Massachusetts delegates to the Continental Congress, the grand arrival of Martha Washington at Cambridge, and a meeting between Washington and Charles Lee at the Battle of Monmouth. 4 pp.
TLS, Baltimore. Expressing his desire to avoid war scenes of George Washington and instead focus on the his character and environment. 5 pp.
TLS, Baltimore. Agreeing to Pyle's suggestions for illustrations. 2 pp.
TLS, Baltimore. Sending the fourth part of his work, asking Pyle to forward it to Mr. Alden once he has read it. 1 p.
