TLS, Princeton, NJ. Regretfully declining Pyle's invitation to visit Wilmington, discussing his ideas for illustrations including a farewell scene at Fraunces Tavern, Washington and his mother at a ball, and an interior at Mount Vernon. 4 pp.

TLS with autograph postscript, Princeton, NJ. Agreeing with Pyle's decision not to illustrate a ballroom scene, suggesting Washington's entry into New York as a possible subject, saying he is more than satisfied with the other illustrations. 3 pp.
ALS, Princeton. Assuring Pyle that the publisher will accept his illustrations. 2 pp.
TLS. Promising to send the fifth part of his work. 1 p.
ALS, Princeton, NJ. Sending the fifth Washington article, pointing out possible scenes for illustration. 1 p.
TLS, Princeton, NJ. Agreeing that an illustration of the disbanding of the army will be most interesting, promising to send the sixth installment of his writing in a week. 1 p.
TLS, Princeton, NJ. Agreeing with Pyle's decision not to illustrate Washington and Carleton; promising to send part six of his manuscript within the week. 1 p.
LS, Princeton, NJ. Writing to Pyle on behalf of the President of the Mount Vernon Association, asking for advice about appropriate period furnishings for Mount Vernon. 4 pp.
TLS, Princeton, NJ. Expressing his delight that Pyle has agreed to illustrate his History [of the American People]; planning for a possible visit to Wilmington. 1 p.
TLS, Princeton, NJ. Arguing for the historical accuracy of Captain Phips and the Treasure Ship, asking Pyle to illustrate the incident as Wilson feels it is romantic and picturesque. 1 p.
TLS, Princeton, NJ. Encouraging Pyle to choose the scenes for illustrating the Revolution as Wilson does not have strong feelings on the matter. 1 p.
TLS, Princeton, NJ. Responding to Pyle's request to include a last minute illustration of John Paul Jones. 1 p.
Typed description of a visit to Mount Vernon by John Hunter and R.H. Lee. 1 p.

ANS. A presentation inscription taken from the fly leaf of one of Wilson's books in which he characterizes his writing as honestly conceived and written with conviction and thanks his friend for his kind judgment. 1 p.

ANS. A presentation inscription taken from the fly leaf of Wilson's George Washington. Speaking of Renick as a fellow Virginian and Wilson's hope that the volume will always remind him of their abiding friendship. 1 p.
TLS, Trenton, NJ. Thanking Ritchie for sending congratulations, promising to consider his suggestion. 1 p.
TLS, Princeton, NJ. Agreeing that children should not play violent games during school recess. 1 p.

TLS, Princeton, NJ. Agreeing to explore the possibility of free tuition for Rosewater Scholars but questioning whether the engineering courses at Princeton qualify under the strictures of Rosewater's father's will. 1 p.

TLS, New Jersey. Saying he is complimented that Rowland has chosen him as the subject of his oration, suggesting Rowland consult Poole's Index to Periodical Literature to find articles about Wilson. 1 p.

ALS, Clarksville, Tenn. Discussing a book he is writing and his wish to serve as chair of political science; giving a lengthy explanation of his approach to the study of politics and his belief that "the true philosophy of government can be extracted only from the true history of government." 13 pp.
ALS, Princeton, NJ. Making fun of [James Ford] Rhodes' abilities as an historian, mocking his comparison between Lincoln and Socrates; with mention of Wilson's Division and Reunion. 3 pp.
TLS, Princeton, NJ. Expressing his belief that five hours of schooling is too much for children but if it must be done a double session is better than a single. 1 p.

TLS, Washington. Saying he cannot declare another day for peace [he proclaimed October 4, 1914 as a day of prayer for peace throughout the U.S.] but is not opposed to people assembling for the same purpose on other days. 1 p. with original envelope.
TLS, Princeton, NJ. Promising to visit the Museum of Safety at the earliest possible opportunity. 1 p.
In addition to Wilson's letters to Verdery, the folder also contains transcriptions of two letters Verdery wrote to Wilson.
TLS, Princeton, NJ. Thanking Verdery for his telegram congratulating Wilson on his nomination. 1 p. with original envelope.
TLS, Princeton, NJ. Thanking Verdery for his kind praises of Wilson's speech at the Southern Dinner, agreeing to look over the stenographer's notes and make corrections. 1 p. with original envelope.
TLS, New Jersey. Acknowledging [William Jennings] Bryan is a potential hazard. 1 p. with original envelope.
TLS, Washington. Sending thanks for a message of friendship and saying he is getting better; expressing his confidence in the present state of affairs. 1 p. with original envelope.
TLS, Princeton, NJ. Declining a lecture. 1 p.
Served as Mayor of Toledo and U.S. Minister to Belgium.
TLS, Trenton, NJ. Thanking him for his support during Wilson's campaign.
TLS, Washington. Thanking Whitlock for a copy of his new book. 1 p.
TLS, Washington. Thanking Whitlock for his message of friendship and approval. 1 p.
TLS, Washington. Asking Whitlock to forward a letter to Senator van den Peereboom. 1 p.
Woodrow Wilson's father.
ALS, Middletown, CT. Expressing concern over his father's health, reporting on a lecture he gave at Brown University and his plans to spend six weeks in Baltimore. 4 pp.

ALS, Middletown, CT. Reporting that he was ill his last weeks in Baltimore but has recovered since coming home; saying he plans to accept an appointment at Princeton University as well as keep his present arrangement with Johns Hopkins; saying the older he gets the more he misses his father. 4 pp.
TLS, Washington. Saying that the work of General and Mrs. Ballington Booth with the Volunteers of America deserves complete and ungrudging support. 1 p.

Printed copy of the syllabus from Wilson's six part lecture series on "Great Leaders of Political Thought," sponsored by the American Society for the Extension of University Teaching. On the back is a penciled note, possibly in Wilson's hand: "J.K.A. Will you second major's motion?" 12 pp.
AMsS. "When a Man Comes to Himself." 19 pp.
American general in the War of 1812. DS. Ordering James W. Bryson to oversee the construction of 100 common tents to be made from suitable linen or duck. 1 p.

Confederate general and statesman. ALS, Manchester, VA. To Nahum Capen. Arguing that the Union should be dissoluble to avoid a central despotism; describing poverty, stripped lands, and a "population unused to labor" in Virginia; wishing for restoration and not merely reconstruction. 1 p.

Served as president of the College of New Jersey [now Princeton] from 1768 to 1794. ALS, Princeton. To William Semple, merchant in Philadelphia. Asking Semple to lend his wife some money as he has none on hand and has been disappointed by the failure of Dr. Johnston. 1 p.

American physician and military officer. TLS, New York City. To Professor Albert Bushnell Hart. Saying he will gladly receive Hart's book on the European War and he hopes it will awaken interest in the necessity of preparation as "we are living in a fools' paradise." 1 p.
Traveler and politician.

The letters were noted as being sent under the direction of William Pitt [British Prime Minister and Secretary of State]. Many of the letters include forwards of The London Gazette Extraordinary [hereafter Gazette].

LS, Whitehall. Forwarding an extract of a letter sent from Brigadier General Forbes to the Commander of the British forces in North America. The letter announces that the British have successfully expelled the French from Fort Dusquesne (Pittsburgh) and convinced the Indians to remain neutral. 3 pp. total
LS, Whitehall. Forwarding the March 7 Gazette [attached] and reporting that Mr. Keith, late Lord Marshall, is to have his pardon. Letter 1 p., printed Gazette 2 pp.
LS, Whitehall. Sending the June 14 Gazette containing an account of the surrender of Guadalupe. Letter 1 p. Printed Gazette 8 pp.

LS, Whitehall. Enclosing the September 7 & 10 Gazette containing news of Admiral [Edward] Boscawen's having taken and destroyed five French ships. Letter 1 p. Printed Gazettes 4 pp. Also included is a copy of a letter from Lieutenant Coventry to Lieutenant Governor [James] DeLancey giving an account of the defeat of the French near Niagara and the reduction of the fort. 3 pp.
LS, Whitehall. Forwarding the June 27 Gazette. Letter 1 p. Printed Gazette 2 pp.
LS, Whitehall. Forwarding the October 6 Gazette. Letter 1 p. Printed Gazette 8 pp.
LS, Whitehall. Forwarding the Gazette from July 18 to July 21, containing news of the surrender of Pondicherry to Colonel Coote and successes in the West Indies. Letter 1 p. Printed Gazettes 8 pp.
LS, Whitehall. Forwarding the March 23 Gazette reporting the success of the expedition at Martinique. Letter 1 p. Printed Gazette 7 pp.
LS, Whitehall. Forwarding the April 2 Gazette detailing General Monckton's success in Martinique. Letter 1 p. Printed Gazette 7 pp.

ALS from Mackenzie to Arthur Villettes, Turin. Mentioning some diplomatic business; lamenting the death of the king but celebrating the anticipated reign of the prince; recommending Shippen & Allen, two Philadelphia gentleman traveling in Europe. 3 pp.

American theologian. ALS, Princeton. To David Benedict. Responding to a request for a likeness of Princeton president John Witherspoon, with mention of various other presidents including Dickinson, Burr, and Davies. 3 pp.
New York politician and Judge in Ulster County. DS. Authorizing an attorney's license for Polydore B. Wisner. 1 p. with seal and ribbon.
Miscellaneous advertisements and promotional materials from various businesses including a water-cure hotel, cloth store, eighteenth-century hat maker, and lottery salesmen. 10 items.

Contains autographs and inscriptions of President Lincoln, Vice President Hannibal Hamlin, Secretary of War Simon Cameron, General U.S. Grant, Lew Wallace, Charles Sumner, Rutherford B. Hayes, and other notables of the period. Possibly kept by a R.P. Gillingham. Includes 1 ALS from G. Bancroft, dated 1846 and 1 ALS dated 1854, tipped in at back.
Miscellaneous bills and receipts dating from a 150-year span, covering everything from court fees and pew taxes to goods & services. Many are from Boston. 53 items.
Miscellaneous documents related to British shipping.

Invoice of stores on board the Thomas & Richard transport, Cuthbert Parker, Master, to be transported to His Majesty's stores at New York by Navy Boards Warrant. Sent to William Fowler, Naval Officer at New York. 8 pp.

Printed license issued August 26, 1812 allowing Thomas Nelson & others to import specified cargo from the United States to the port of Cadiz (Spain). On the back is an autograph notation by consul Andrew Allen, certifying the intention of Nelson to sail the brig Hannah from Portsmouth, NH to Norfolk, VA to load up with flour, and then proceed to the port of Cadiz. 3 pp. total.

Printed form certifying that Benjamin Jefson served on board His Majesty's Ship Shannon from 1808 until his death in 1813 at the age of fifteen. Signed by Captain P. B. V. Broke. On the back is a record of his prize money and his father's signature verifying receipt of the money owed his late son. 2 pp.

This file consists of miscellaneous broadsides. Researchers should note that additional groups of broadsides can be found under Continental Congress, Massachusetts, and Rhode Island. All are housed in the same box.
Lord Camden's Speech on the New England Fishery Bill. Printed by S. Southwick, Newport. Probable date.
His Majesty's Most Gracious Speech to Both Houses of Parliament, on Thursday the 26th Day of October, 1775. Outlining his stance toward the rebellious colonies.
A Proclamation for a General Fast, by order of the Council and House of Representatives of the State of New Hampshire. Printed by Zechariah Fowle, Exeter, New Hampshire.
Copy of a letter announcing the signing of the Treaty of Paris. Printed by Henry Barber.
Resolve of Congress prohibiting states from paying the federal government with bills or credit. Signed Charles Thompson, Secretary.
Announcing a treaty of peace between America and Great Britain [ending the War of 1812].
Vindiciae Hibernicae. Enlisting subscribers for the purchase of a book vindicating the Irish nation. Issued by publishers R. P. and Thomas Desilver.
Contemporary Ms, listing 16 districts, including the Southwest and Northwest territories. From the Jefferson-Humphreys papers. 1 p. [ Item is missing as of fall 2008.]

Compiler unknown. Containing extracts from various books and publications including: proposals for carrying on an effectual war in America against the French & Spaniards; memoirs of the Lord High Chancellors, Lord Keepers, and Lord Commissioners of the Great Seal of Great Britain; extracts from The History of Hertfordshire; extracts about the history of England. 66 pp., bound.

One folder containing early American currency and items related to the same. The De Coppet collection at Princeton also includes several hundred pieces of paper money housed in the Princeton Numismatic Collection, Firestone Library. These are chiefly issues of the American colonies before the Revolution and of the Continental Congress. The collection is in the process of online cataloguing and digitization; those pieces catalogued to date can be found through a search by donor at the Numismatic Collection. For more information contact the Curator of Numismatics.

Miscellaneous currency. Included are multiple bills issued by "The United Colonies" in 1775 (printed by Hall and Sellers), a 1779 Massachusetts-Bay bill, a 1780 United States bill, and 1863 Alabama Bills issued under the Confederate States. 11 items.
Two small account books containing tables for converting old tenor into lawful money. One is labeled as belonging to Thomas Gill, Jr.

Miscellaneous insurance contracts. Included are policies insuring cargo on brigantines Marquis La Fayette and Harriet, a Philadelphia policy for insuring houses from loss by fire, three documents from the Massachusetts Fire Insurance Company, and rate quotes from the New York Life Insurance and Trust Company. 8 items. The Massachusetts Fire Insurance Company documents are housed in the Box 46 (oversize).

Collection of prints and photographs of many notable Americans represented in this collection. 2 folders, filed alphabetically. One oversize portrait of Abraham Lincoln is housed in Box 46 (oversize).

Miscellaneous stock certificates certifying the purchase of shares in: privateer ship Orlando, the Kennebec Steam Navigation Company, the Boston Water Power Company, the Springfield Joint Stock Company, and the Boston Locomotive Works. 8 items.
Miscellaneous documents, filed by name.
DS. Voucher and signed reimbursement for postage paid on letters of public service. 1 p.
DS. Petitioning the Rhode Island Assembly for a new trial, alleging mistreatment by court auditors. 1 p.

Professor of Chemistry and Natural History at Bethany College, [West] Virginia. ALS to A[ugustus] A[ddison] Gould. Informing Gould that his book on zoology is used as a textbook at Bethany College; asking whether he might write an accompanying volume on human physiology. 2 pp.
DS, Troy. A public denunciation of Samuel Starr. On the back is a very faded illustration of H. Van Schaick's land. 1 p.

ALS, New London CT. To J. A. Rockwell. Requesting a copy of the President's message and congressional reports from 1848, as well as a account of the Navy's contracts for oakum. With negative comments on the nomination of a Mr. Cleveland. 1 p.

These boxes contain materials saved by Andre De Coppet regarding the provenance and purchase of items in this collection. Most of the material consists of clippings from auction catalogues and letters from dealers. The material is organized alphabetically by name of subject; for example, provenance information for George Washington letters is filed under "Washington, George."
